Dante made Virgil his guide in Hell and the greater part of Purgatory in The Divine Comedy	In which of Dante's works was Virgil a guide through Hell and Purgatory?
From at least the 3rd century, Christian thinkers interpreted Eclogues 4, which describes the birth of a boy ushering in a golden age, as a prediction of Jesus' birth	Which of Virgil's works was said by some to have predicted Jesus' birth?
In the 12th century, starting around Naples but eventually spreading widely throughout Europe, a tradition developed in which Virgil was regarded as a great magician	Where did the tradition start which regarded Virgil as a great magician?
The legend of Virgil in his Basket arose in the Middle Ages, and is often seen in art and mentioned in literature as part of the Power of Women literary topos, demonstrating the disruptive force of female attractiveness on men	During which time period did the legend of Virgil in his Basket arise?
While Virgil was already the object of literary admiration and veneration before his death, in the Middle Ages his name became associated with miraculous powers, and for a couple of centuries his tomb was the destination of pilgrimages and veneration	During which time period did Virgil's name become associated with miraclous powers?
In the Late Empire and Middle Ages Vergilius was spelled Virgilius	Besides Virgilius, which other spelling is permitted in modern usage?
The Alps ; French: Alpes ; German: Alpen ; Slovene: Alpe ) are the highest and most extensive mountain range system that lies entirely in Europe, stretching approximately 1,200 kilometres across eight Alpine countries: Austria, France, Germany, Italy, Liechtenstein, Monaco, Slovenia, and Switzerland	What Country are the Alps located in?
The altitude and size of the range affects the climate in Europe; in the mountains precipitation levels vary greatly and climatic conditions consist of distinct zones	What affects the climate in Europe? 
A mummified man, determined to be 5,000 years old, was discovered on a glacier at the Austrian–Italian border in 1991	How old was the mummified man discovered at the Austrian-Italian bored?
At present the region is home to 14 million people and has 120 million annual visitors	The alps is home to how many people?
The English word Alps derives from the Latin Alpes 	The English word Alps derives from what Latin Word? 
This may be consistent with the theory that in Greek Alpes is a name of non-Indo-European origin 	There is a theory that in Greek Alpes is a name of what origin? 
It's likely that alb and albus have common origins deriving from the association of the tops of tall mountains or steep hills with snow	Alb can also mean what? 
In modern languages the term alp, alm, albe or alpe refers to a grazing pastures in the alpine regions below the glaciers, not the peaks	The term alp, alm, albe or alpe refers to what in modern languages? 
The Alps are a crescent shaped geographic feature of central Europe that ranges in a 800 km arc from east to west and is 200 km in width	What are the crescent shaped geographic feature of central Europe?
The highest portion of the range is divided by the glacial trough of the Rhone valley, with the Pennine Alps from Mont Blanc to the Matterhorn and Monte Rosa on the southern side, and the Bernese Alps on the northern	The highest portion of the Alp's range is divided by what? 
The variances in nomenclature in the region spanned by the Alps makes classification of the mountains and subregions difficult, but a general classification is that of the Eastern Alps and Western Alps with the divide between the two occurring in eastern Switzerland according to geologist Stefan Schmid, near the Splügen Pass	What makes the classification of the mountains and subregions difficult?
The highest peaks of the Western Alps and Eastern Alps, respectively, are Mont Blanc, at 4,810 m and Piz Bernina at 4,049 metres 	The highest peak of the Western Alps is where? 
Series of lower mountain ranges run parallel to the main chain of the Alps, including the French Prealps in France and the Jura Mountains in Switzerland and France	Where are the French Prealps located? 
The Alps have been crossed for war and commerce, and by pilgrims, students and tourists	What have been crossed for war and commerce? 
Crossing the Italian-Austrian border, the Brenner Pass separates the Ötztal Alps and Zillertal Alps and has been in use as a trading route since the 14th century	What seperates the Otztal Alps and Zillertal Alps?
Important geological concepts were established as naturalists began studying the rock formations of the Alps in the 18th century	Who began studying the rock formations of the Alps
The formation of the Alps was an episodic process that began about 300 million years ago	When did the formation of the alps began?
Under extreme compressive stresses and pressure, marine sedimentary rocks were uplifted, creating characteristic recumbent folds, or nappes, and thrust faults	What was uplifted from extreme compressive stresses and pressure? 
The Alpine orogeny occurred in ongoing cycles through to the Paleogene causing differences in nappe structures, with a late-stage orogeny causing the development of the Jura Mountains	What caused the development of the Jura Mountains? 
According to geologist Stefan Schmid, because the Western Alps underwent a metamorphic event in the Cenozoic Era while the Austroalpine peaks underwent an event in the Cretaceous Period, the two areas show distinct differences in nappe formations	What is Stefan Schmid's profession?
"Peaks in France, Italy and Switzerland lie in the ""Houillière zone"", which consists of basement with sediments from the Mesozoic Era"	What area do peaks in France, Italy, and Switzerland lie in? 
In simple terms the structure of the Alps consists of layers of rock of European, African and oceanic origin	Layers of rock from Europe, Africa and the ocean make up what?
The core regions of the Alpine orogenic belt have been folded and fractured in such a manner that erosion created the characteristic steep vertical peaks of the Swiss Alps that rise seemingly straight out of the foreland areas	What happened to the Alpine orogenic belt that gave it the steep vertical peak?
"The Union Internationale des Associations d'Alpinisme has defined a list of 82 ""official"" Alpine summits that reach at least 4,000 m "	What group defined a list of 82 official Apline summits that reach 4,000m?
While Mont Blanc was first climbed in 1786, most of the Alpine four-thousanders were climbed during the first half of the 19th century; the ascent of the Matterhorn in 1865 marked the end of the golden age of alpinism	When was Mont Blanc first climbed?
The first British Mont Blanc ascent was in 1788; the first female ascent in 1819	When was the first British Mont Blanc ascent? 
The Alps are a source of minerals that have been mined for thousands of years	What have been mined in the Alps for thousands of years? 
Alpine crystals have been studied and collected for hundreds of years, and began to be classified in the 18th century	How long have Alpine crystals been studied and collected? 
In the Miocene Epoch the mountains underwent severe erosion because of glaciation, which was noted in the mid-19th century by naturalist Louis Agassiz who presented a paper proclaiming the Alps were covered in ice at various intervals—a theory he formed when studying rocks near his Neuchâtel home which he believed originated to the west in the Bernese Oberland	Where did the mountains undergo serve erosion?
Agassiz studied glacier movement in the 1840s at the Unteraar Glacier where he found the glacier moved 100 m per year, more rapidly in the middle than at the edges	Where did Agassiz study during the 1840s?
The Inn valley is an example of a valley carved by glaciers during the ice ages with a typical terraced structure caused by erosion	What is an example of a valley carved by glaciers during the ice ages? 
Alpine glaciers can be straight rivers of ice, long sweeping rivers, spread in a fan-like shape , and curtains of ice that hang from vertical slopes of the mountain peaks	How do Piedmont glaciers appear?
Sometimes a piece of glacier will detach or break resulting in flooding, property damage and loss of life	What causes flooding, property damage, and loss of life?
High levels of precipitation cause the glaciers to descend to permafrost levels in some areas whereas in other, more arid regions, glaciers remain above about the 3,500 m level	What cause the glaciers to descend to permafrost levels in some areas? 
The Alps provide lowland Europe with drinking water, irrigation, and hydroelectric power	What provides Europe with drinking water, irrigation, and hydroelectric power?
Major European rivers flow from Switzerland, such as the Rhine, the Rhone, the Inn, the Ticino and the Po, all of which have headwaters in the Alps and flow into neighbouring countries, finally emptying into the North Sea, the Mediterranean Sea, the Adriatic Sea and the Black Sea	The Rhine, the Rhone, the Inn, the Ticino and the Po rivers flow from what Country?
In Germany, the medieval St	Where is the medieval St. Bartholomew Chapel located?
Scientists have been studying the impact of climate change and water use	Who have been studying the impact of climate change and water use?
The Alps are a classic example of what happens when a temperate area at lower altitude gives way to higher-elevation terrain	What are a classic example of what happens when a temperate area at lower altitude gives way to higher-elevation terrain?
The severe weather in the Alps has been studied since the 18th century; particularly the weather patterns such as the seasonal foehn wind	Since when has the severe weather in the Alps been studied? 
The areas that are not arid and receive high precipitation experience periodic flooding from rapid snowmelt and runoff	What areas experience periodic flooding from rapid snowmelt and runoff?
The Alps are split into five climatic zones, each with different vegetation	How many zones are the Alps split into?
Various models of climate change have been projected into the 22nd century for the Alps, with an expectation that a trend toward increased temperatures will have an effect on snowfall, snowpack, glaciation, and river runoff	What has been projected into the 22nd century for the Alps?
Thirteen thousand species of plants have been identified in the Alpine regions	How many species of plants have been identified in the Alpine regions?
Above the forestry, there is often a band of short pine trees , which is in turn superseded by Alpenrosen, dwarf shrubs, typically Rhododendron ferrugineum or Rhododendron hirsutum 	What is often above the forestry?
Alpine plants such the Alpine gentian grow in abundance in areas such as the meadows above the Lauterbrunnental	What grows in abundance in areas such as the meadows above the Lauterbrunnental?
At these higher altitudes, the plants tend to form isolated cushions	What do the plants tend to form at higher altitudes? 
The extreme and stressful climatic conditions give way to the growth of plant species with secondary metabolites important for medicinal purposes	What gives way to the growth of plant species with secondary metabolites important for medicinal purposes?
Human interference has nearly exterminated the trees in many areas, and, except for the beech forests of the Austrian Alps, forests of deciduous trees are rarely found after the extreme deforestation between the 17th and 19th centuries	What has nearly exterminated the trees in many areas?
The Alps are a habitat for 30,000 species of wildlife, ranging from the tiniest snow fleas to brown bears, many of which have made adaptations to the harsh cold conditions and high altitudes to the point that some only survive in specific micro-climates either directly above or below the snow line	How many species of wildlife habitat the Alps?
The largest mammal to live in the highest altitudes are the alpine ibex, which have been sighted as high as 3,000 m 	What is the largest mammal to live in the highest altitudes?
Many rodents such as voles live underground	Where do many rodents live?
Reptiles such as adders and vipers live up to the snow line; because they cannot bear the cold temperatures they hibernate underground and soak up the warmth on rocky ledges	Why do reptiles only live up to the snow line?
A number of species of moths live in the Alps, some of which are believed to have evolved in the same habitat up to 120 million years ago, long before the Alps were created	How long have some species of moths believed to have evolved from the same habitat?
Some of the species of moths and insects show evidence of having been indigenous to the area from as long ago as the Alpine orogeny	Some species of moths and insects show evidence of what?
About 10,000 years ago, when the ice melted after the last glacial period, late Paleolithic communities were established along the lake shores and in cave systems	When were late Paleolithic communities established along the lake shores?
In 1991 a mummy of a neolithic body, known as Ötzi the Iceman, was discovered by hikers on the Similaun glacier	Who was Otzi the Iceman?
Celtic tribes settled in Switzerland between 1000 to 1500 BC	When did Celtic tribes settle in Switzerland? 
During the Second Punic War in 218 BC, the Carthaginian general Hannibal probably crossed the Alps with an army numbering 38,000 infantry, 8,000 cavalry, and 37 war elephants	When was the Second Punic War?
The Roman expansion brought the defeat of the Allobrogi in 121 BC and during the Gallic Wars in 58 BC Julius Caesar overcame the Helvetii	What brought the defeat of the Allobrogi?
Christianity was established in the region by the Romans, and saw the establishment of monasteries and churches in the high regions	Who established Christianity in the region?
Much of the medieval period was a time of power struggles between competing dynasties such as the House of Savoy, the Visconti in northern Italy and the House of Habsburg in Austria and Slovenia	Much of the medieval period was a time of what?
During the Napoleonic Wars in the late 18th century and early 19th century, Napoleon annexed territory formerly controlled by the Habsburgs and Savoys	What wars took place during the late 18th century and early 19th century?
After the fall of Napoléon, many alpine countries developed heavy protections to prevent any new invasion	When did many alpine countries develop heavy protection to prevent new invasion?
In the 19th century, the monasteries built in the high Alps during the medieval period to shelter travelers and as places of pilgrimage, became tourist destinations	What became tourist destinations during the 19th century?
Radiocarbon dated charcoal placed around 50,000 years ago was found in the Drachloch cave above the village of Vattis in the canton of St	How old was the charcoal placed in the Drachloch cave?
Charles VII of France ordered his chamberlain to climb Mont Aiguille in 1356	Where was Charles VII from?
"Conrad Gessner was the first naturalist to ascend the mountains in the 16th century, to study them, writing that in the mountains he found the ""theatre of the Lord"""	Who was the first naturalist to ascend the mountains?
Jean-Jacques Rousseau was the first of many to present the Alps as a place of allure and beauty, banishing the prevalent conception of the mountains as a hellish wasteland inhabited by demons	Who was the first of many to present the Alps as a place of allure and beauty?
In 1816 Byron, Percy Bysshe Shelley and his wife Mary Shelley visited Geneva and all three were inspired by the scenery in their writings	Percy and Mary Shelley were inspired by what region's scenery?
Austrian-born Adolf Hitler had a lifelong romantic fascination with the Alps and by the 1930s established a home in the Obersalzberg region outside of Berchtesgaden	Where was Adolf Hitler born?
By 1940 the Third Reich had occupied many of the Alpine countries	By 1940 who occupied many of the Alpine countries?
Ski troops were trained for the war, and battles were waged in mountainous areas such as the battle at Riva Ridge in Italy, where the American 10th Mountain Division encountered heavy resistance in February 1945	Who were trained for the war?
The population of the region is 14 million spread across eight countries	What is the population of the Alpine region?
Much of the Alpine culture is unchanged since the medieval period when skills that guaranteed survival in the mountain valleys and in the highest villages became mainstays, leading to strong traditions of carpentry, woodcarving, baking and pastry-making, and cheesemaking	Much of what has not changed since the medieval period?
Farming had been a traditional occupation for centuries, although it became less dominant in the 20th century with the advent of tourism	What has been a traditional occupation for centuries?
Cheesemaking is an ancient tradition in most Alpine countries	What is an ancient tradition in most Alpine countries?
In the high villages people live in homes built according to medieval designs that withstand cold winters	What do people in high villages build their homes according to?
Food is passed from the kitchen to the stube, where the dining room table is placed	The food is passed from the kitchen to where? 
Roofs are traditionally constructed from Alpine rocks such as pieces of schist, gneiss or slate	What are roofs traditionally constructed from? 
At present the Alps are one of the more popular tourist destinations in the world with many resorts such Oberstdorf, in Bavaria, Saalbach in Austria, Davos in Switzerland, Chamonix in France, and Cortina d'Ampezzo in Italy recording more than a million annual visitors	What's one of the most popular tourist destinations in the world? 
The tourism industry began in the early 19th century when foreigners visited the Alps, traveled to the bases of the mountains to enjoy the scenery, and stayed at the spa-resorts	When did the tourism industry begin? 
In the first half of the 20th century the Olympic Winter Games were held three times in Alpine venues: the 1924 Winter Olympics in Chamonix, France; the 1928 Winter Olympics in St	Where were the Winter Olympics held in 1924?
I	When were the Winter Olympics held in Albertville, France? 
During the post-World War I period ski-lifts were built in Swiss and Austrian towns to accommodate winter visitors, but summer tourism continued to be important; by the mid-20th century the popularity of downhill skiing increased greatly as it became more accessible and in the 1970s several new villages were built in France devoted almost exclusively to skiing, such as Les Menuires	When were ski-lifts built in Swiss and Austrian towns?
The region is serviced by 4,200 km of roads used by 6 million vehicles	How much area is devoted to roads in the Alpine region?
Some high mountain villages, such as Avoriaz , Wengen, and Zermatt are accessible only by cable car or cog-rail trains, and are car free	Where is the village of Avoriaz located? 
Many passes are closed in winter	When are many passes in the Alps closed? 
:Glossary The transmission of genes to an organism's offspring is the basis of the inheritance of phenotypic traits	What is the basis of inheritance of phenotypic traits?
Genes can acquire mutations in their sequence, leading to different variants, known as alleles, in the population	What do mutations in a gene sequence lead to?
For example, regulatory regions of a gene can be far removed from its coding regions, and coding regions can be split into several exons	What can regulatory regions of a gene be far removed from?
The existence of discrete inheritable units was first suggested by Gregor Mendel 	Who first suggested the existence of discrete inheritable units?
Prior to Mendel's work, the dominant theory of heredity was one of blending inheritance, which suggested that each parent contributed fluids to the fertilisation process and that the traits of the parents blended and mixed to produce the offspring	What was the dominant theory of heredity prior to Mendel's work?
"The word gene is derived from the Ancient Greek word γένος meaning ""race, offspring"""	What ancient Greek word is the word 'gene' derived from?
Deoxyribonucleic acid was shown to be the molecular repository of genetic information by experiments in the 1940s to 1950s	What was shown to be the molecular repository of genetic information by experiments in the 1940s to 1950s?
In 1972, Walter Fiers and his team at the University of Ghent were the first to determine the sequence of a gene: the gene for Bacteriophage MS2 coat protein	When was the first sequence of a gene determined?
The theories developed in the 1930s and 1940s to integrate molecular genetics with Darwinian evolution are called the modern evolutionary synthesis, a term introduced by Julian Huxley	In what time span were the theories to integrate molecular genetic with Darwinian evolution developed?
The vast majority of living organisms encode their genes in long strands of DNA 	What do the vast majority of living organisms encode their genes in?
Two chains of DNA twist around each other to form a DNA double helix with the phosphate-sugar backbone spiralling around the outside, and the bases pointing inwards with adenine base pairing to thymine and guanine to cytosine	What is the backbone of a DNA double helix made of?
Due to the chemical composition of the pentose residues of the bases, DNA strands have directionality	What causes the directionality of DNA strands?
The expression of genes encoded in DNA begins by transcribing the gene into RNA, a second type of nucleic acid that is very similar to DNA, but whose monomers contain the sugar ribose rather than deoxyribose	How does the expression of genes encoded in DNA begin?
The total complement of genes in an organism or cell is known as its genome, which may be stored on one or more chromosomes	What is the total complement of genes in an organism or cell known as?
The majority of eukaryotic genes are stored on a set of large, linear chromosomes	Where are the majority of eukaryotic genes stored?
Prokaryotes typically store their genomes on a single large, circular chromosome	What are prokaryotes?
Whereas the chromosomes of prokaryotes are relatively gene-dense, those of eukaryotes often contain regions of DNA that serve no obvious function	What type of organism has relatively gene dense chromosomes?
The structure of a gene consists of many elements of which the actual protein coding sequence is often only a small part	Often, how large a part of the structure of a gene is the protein coding sequence?
Firstly, flanking the open reading frame, all genes contain a regulatory sequence that is required for their expression	What do all genes contain that is required for their expression?
These act by binding to transcription factors which then cause the DNA to loop so that the regulatory sequence become close to the RNA polymerase binding site	How do regulatory regions act?
The transcribed pre-mRNA contains untranslated regions at both ends which contain a ribosome binding site, terminator and start and stop codons	What is at both ends of the transcribed pre-mRNA?
Many prokaryotic genes are organized into operons, with multiple protein-coding sequences that are transcribed as a unit	What are most prokaryotic genes organized into?
Regulatory regions of a gene such as enhancers do not necessarily have to be close to the coding sequence on the linear molecule because the intervening DNA can be looped out to bring the gene and its regulatory region into proximity	What is an example of a regulatory region of a gene that does not have to close to the coding sequence?
This model has been refined since the discovery of genes that can encode multiple proteins by alternative splicing and coding sequences split in short section across the genome whose mRNAs are concatenated by trans-splicing	What discovery caused the model that one gene makes one protein to be refined?
A broad operational definition is sometimes used to encompass the complexity of these diverse phenomena, where a gene is defined as a union of genomic sequences encoding a coherent set of potentially overlapping functional products	What sort of definition can be used to conveniently encompass the complexity of diverse phenomena?
In all organisms, two steps are required to read the information encoded in a gene's DNA and produce the protein it specifies	How many steps are required to read the information encoded in a gene's DNA and produce the specified protein?
The nucleotide sequence of a gene's DNA specifies the amino acid sequence of a protein through the genetic code	What specifies the amino acid sequence of a protein?
Transcription produces a single-stranded RNA molecule known as messenger RNA, whose nucleotide sequence is complementary to the DNA from which it was transcribed	What does transcription produce?
In prokaryotes, transcription occurs in the cytoplasm; for very long transcripts, translation may begin at the 5' end of the RNA while the 3' end is still being transcribed	Where does transcription occur in prokaryotes?
Translation is the process by which a mature mRNA molecule is used as a template for synthesizing a new protein	What is the process by which a mature mRNA molecule is used as a template for synthesizing a new protein called?
Genes are regulated so that they are expressed only when the product is needed, since expression draws on limited resources	When are genes expressed?
A typical protein-coding gene is first copied into RNA as an intermediate in the manufacture of the final protein product	What is first copied into RNA as an intermediate in the manufacture of the final protein product?
Some viruses store their entire genomes in the form of RNA, and contain no DNA at all	In what form do some viruses store their entire genome?
Organisms inherit their genes from their parents	Where do organisms inherit their genes from?
According to Mendelian inheritance, variations in an organism's phenotype are due in part to variations in its genotype 	According to Mendelian inheritance, what is part of the cause of variations in an organism's phenotype?
Alleles at a locus may be dominant or recessive; dominant alleles give rise to their corresponding phenotypes when paired with any other allele for the same trait, whereas recessive alleles give rise to their corresponding phenotype only when paired with another copy of the same allele	Where can alleles be located in order to be either dominant or recessive?
The growth, development, and reproduction of organisms relies on cell division, or the process by which a single cell divides into two usually identical daughter cells	What does the growth, development, and reproduction of organisms rely on?
After DNA replication is complete, the cell must physically separate the two copies of the genome and divide into two distinct membrane-bound cells	What is one thing the cell must do once DNA replication is compete?
The duplication and transmission of genetic material from one generation of cells to the next is the basis for molecular inheritance, and the link between the classical and molecular pictures of genes	The duplication and transmission of genetic material from one generation of cells to the next is the basis for what?
During the process of meiotic cell division, an event called genetic recombination or crossing-over can sometimes occur, in which a length of DNA on one chromatid is swapped with a length of DNA on the corresponding sister chromatid	When can an event called genetic recombination or crossing-over sometimes occur?
DNA replication is for the most part extremely accurate, however errors do occur	What is it called when errors occur in DNA replication?
When multiple different alleles for a gene are present in a species's population it is called polymorphic	What is it called when multiple different alleles for a gene are present in a species's population?
Most mutations within genes are neutral, having no effect on the organism's phenotype 	What are mutations that have no effect on an organism's phenotype called?
Genes with a most recent common ancestor, and thus a shared evolutionary ancestry, are known as homologs	What are genes with a most recent common ancestor called?
The relationship between genes can be measured by comparing the sequence alignment of their DNA	What does comparing the sequence alignment of genes' DNA measure?
The most common source of new genes in eukaryotic lineages is gene duplication, which creates copy number variation of an existing gene in the genome	What is the most common source of new genes in eukaryotic lineages?
"De novo or ""orphan"" genes, whose sequence shows no similarity to existing genes, are extremely rare"	What is a gene whose sequence shows no similarity to existing genes called?
Horizontal gene transfer refers to the transfer of genetic material through a mechanism other than reproduction	What is the transfer of genetic material through a mechanism other than reproduction known as?
The genome size, and the number of genes it encodes varies widely between organisms	What is one characteristic that varies widely between organisms?
Although the number of base-pairs of DNA in the human genome has been known since the 1960s, the estimated number of genes has changed over time as definitions of genes, and methods of detecting them have been refined	Since when has the number of base pairs of DNA in the human genome been known?
Essential genes are the set of genes thought to be critical for an organism's survival	What are the set of genes which are thought to be crucial for the survival of an organism?
Housekeeping genes are critical for carrying out basic cell functions and so are expressed at a relatively constant level 	What type of genes are necessary for performing basic cell functions?
Gene nomenclature has been established by the HUGO Gene Nomenclature Committee for each known human gene in the form of an approved gene name and symbol , which can be accessed through a database maintained by HGNC	What committee has established gene nomenclature for every known human gene?
Genetic engineering is the modification of an organism's genome through biotechnology	What is known as the modification of an organism's genome through biotechnology?
Genetic engineering is now a routine research tool with model organisms	What has become a common research tool with model organisms?
For multicellular organisms, typically the embryo is engineered which grows into the adult genetically modified organism	For what sort of organisms is the embryo normally engineered?
Guinea-Bissau , officially the Republic of Guinea-Bissau ), is a country in West Africa	What is the official name for Guinea-Bissau?
Guinea-Bissau was once part of the kingdom of Gabu, as well as part of the Mali Empire	What kingdom was Guinea-Bissau once part of?
Only 14% of the population speaks Portuguese, established as the official language in the colonial period	What percentage of the population speaks Portuguese?
Guinea-Bissau is a member of the United Nations, African Union, Economic Community of West African States, Organisation of Islamic Cooperation, the Latin Union, Community of Portuguese Language Countries, La Francophonie and the South Atlantic Peace and Cooperation Zone	What Islamic organization does Guinea-Bissau belong to?
Portuguese Guinea was known as the Slave Coast, as it was a major area for the exportation of African slaves by Europeans to the western hemisphere	What area was known as the Slave Coast?
Early reports of Europeans reaching this area include those of the Venetian Alvise Cadamosto's voyage of 1455, the 1479–1480 voyage by Flemish-French trader Eustache de la Fosse, and Diogo Cão	When was Alvise Cadamosto's voyage?
Although the rivers and coast of this area were among the first places colonized by the Portuguese, who set up trading posts in the 16th century, they did not explore the interior until the 19th century	What areas were the first places colonized by the Portuguese?
For a brief period in the 1790s, the British tried to establish a rival foothold on an offshore island, at Bolama	Who tried to establish a rival foothold at Bolama?
An armed rebellion beginning in 1956 by the African Party for the Independence of Guinea and Cape Verde under the leadership of Amílcar Cabral gradually consolidated its hold on then Portuguese Guinea	What group started an armed rebellion in Guinea-Bissau?
Independence was unilaterally declared on 24 September 1973	When was independence declared?
Luís Cabral, brother of Amílcar and co-founder of PAIGC, was appointed the first President of Guinea-Bissau	Who was the first President of Guinea-Bissau?
The country was controlled by a revolutionary council until 1984	Who controlled the country prior to 1984?
In September 2003, a military coup was conducted	When was a military coup conducted?
In June 2005, presidential elections were held for the first time since the coup that deposed Ialá	After the coup, when were presidential elections held?
"Despite reports of arms entering the country prior to the election and some ""disturbances during campaigning,"" including attacks on government offices by unidentified gunmen, foreign election monitors described the 2005 election overall as ""calm and organized"""	What was reported to be entering the country prior to the election?
Three years later, PAIGC won a strong parliamentary majority, with 67 of 100 seats, in the parliamentary election held in November 2008	When was the parliamentary election held?
On 2 March 2009, however, Vieira was assassinated by what preliminary reports indicated to be a group of soldiers avenging the death of the head of joint chiefs of staff, General Batista Tagme Na Wai	Who was assassinated on 2 March 2009?
On the evening of 12 April 2012, members of the country's military staged a coup d'état and arrested the interim president and a leading presidential candidate	When was a coup d'etat staged?
Guinea-Bissau is a republic	What country is listed as a republic?
At the legislative level, a unicameral Assembleia Nacional Popular is made up of 100 members	How many members compose the legislature?
"João Bernardo ""Nino"" Vieira was elected in 2005 as President of Guinea-Bissau as an independent, being declared winner of the second round by the CNE "	Who was elected as President in 2005?
Vieira's death did not trigger widespread violence, but there were signs of turmoil in the country, according to the advocacy group Swisspeace	What was NOT triggered by Vieira's death?
In 2012, President Rachide Sambu-balde Malam Bacai Sanhá died	When did President Sanha die?
Guinea-Bissau is divided into eight regions and one autonomous sector 	How many regions does Guinea-Bissau contain?
Guinea-Bissau is bordered by Senegal to the north and Guinea to the south and east, with the Atlantic Ocean to its west	What country is on the north border of Guinea-Bissau?
At 36,125 square kilometres , the country is larger in size than Taiwan or Belgium	Guinea-Bissau is larger than what two countries?
The average rainfall for Bissau is 2,024 millimetres (79	What is the average rainfall in Bissau, in millimetres?
More than two-thirds of the population lives below the poverty line	How much of the population lives below the poverty line?
A long period of political instability has resulted in depressed economic activity, deteriorating social conditions, and increased macroeconomic imbalances	Political instability has resulted in what type of economic activity?
Guinea-Bissau has started to show some economic advances after a pact of stability was signed by the main political parties of the country, leading to an IMF-backed structural reform program	What did the main political parties sign to help the economy?
After several years of economic downturn and political instability, in 1997, Guinea-Bissau entered the CFA franc monetary system, bringing about some internal monetary stability	In what year did Guinea-Bissau start to bring some internal monetary stability to the country?
Beginning around 2005, drug traffickers based in Latin America began to use Guinea-Bissau, along with several neighboring West African nations, as a transshipment point to Europe for cocaine	When did drug traffickers begin to use Guinea-Bissau?
According to the 2010 revison of the UN World Population Prospects, Guinea-Bissau's population was 1,515,000 in 2010, compared to 518,000 in 1950	What was the population of Guinea-Bissau in 1950?
Portuguese natives comprise a very small percentage of Guinea-Bissauans	What natives comprise a very small percentage of the population?
44% speak Kriol, a Portuguese-based creole language, which is effectively a national language of communication among groups	What percentage of the population speaks Kriol?

The brain is an organ that serves as the center of the nervous system in all vertebrate and most invertebrate animals	What is the center of the nervous system in all creatures?
The brain acts on the rest of the body both by generating patterns of muscle activity and by driving the secretion of chemicals called hormones	Hormones secreted are driven by what organ in the body?
Recent models in modern neuroscience treat the brain as a biological computer, very different in mechanism from an electronic computer, but similar in the sense that it acquires information from the surrounding world, stores it, and processes it in a variety of ways, analogous to the central processing unit in a computer	Which part of a computer does the brain most resemble?
This article compares the properties of brains across the entire range of animal species, with the greatest attention to vertebrates	Animals with a spine are called what?
"Some aspects of brain structure are common to almost the entire range of animal species; others distinguish ""advanced"" brains from more primitive ones, or distinguish vertebrates from invertebrates"	Animals without a spine are called what?
The simplest way to gain information about brain anatomy is by visual inspection, but many more sophisticated techniques have been developed	The easiest way to learn about brain anatomy is by what?
The brains of all species are composed primarily of two broad classes of cells: neurons and glial cells	Brains of organisms are made up mostly of what two classes of cells?
Axons transmit signals to other neurons by means of specialized junctions called synapses	Axons send signals to other neurons by junctions known as what?
The human brain has been estimated to contain approximately 100 trillion synapses; even the brain of a fruit fly contains several million	How many synapses does the human brain supposedly contain?
Most of the space in the brain is taken up by axons, which are often bundled together in what are called nerve fiber tracts	Axons grouped together are known as what?
Except for a few primitive organisms such as sponges and cnidarians , all living multicellular animals are bilaterians, meaning animals with a bilaterally symmetric body shape 	Creatures that have a diffuse nerve net are called what?
There are a few types of existing bilaterians that lack a recognizable brain, including echinoderms, tunicates, and acoelomorphs 	A name for a group of primitive flatworms is what?
The brains of arthropods and cephalopods arise from twin parallel nerve cords that extend through the body of the animal	Arthropods and cephalopods have brains that come from a pair of what?
There are several invertebrate species whose brains have been studied intensively because they have properties that make them convenient for experimental work:	Which brains are easier to work on, vertebrates or invertebrates?
The first vertebrates appeared over 500 million years ago , during the Cambrian period, and may have resembled the modern hagfish in form	How long ago did the first vertebrate organisms appear?
In general, smaller animals tend to have larger brains, measured as a fraction of body size	Do predators have larger or smaller brains compared to their prey?
In its earliest form, the brain appears as three swellings at the front end of the neural tube; these swellings eventually become the forebrain, midbrain, and hindbrain 	The forebrain during development is known as what?
Living brain tissue is pinkish on the outside and mostly white on the inside, with subtle variations in color	Brain tissue that is living is what color on the outside?
Neuroanatomists usually divide the vertebrate brain into six main regions: the telencephalon , diencephalon , mesencephalon , cerebellum, pons, and medulla oblongata	People who study the anatomy of the central nervous system are known as what?
"The brain of a shark shows the basic components in a straightforward way, but in teleost fishes , the forebrain has become ""everted"", like a sock turned inside out"	The forebrain is everted in what type of fishes?
On average, a mammal has a brain roughly twice as large as that of a bird of the same body size, and ten times as large as that of a reptile of the same body size	A mammal's brain is how many times larger than a birds relative to body size?
The cerebral cortex is the part of the brain that most strongly distinguishes mammals	What part of the brain most strongly differentiates mammals from other vertebrates?
The superior colliculus, which plays a major role in visual control of behavior in most vertebrates, shrinks to a small size in mammals, and many of its functions are taken over by visual areas of the cerebral cortex	The superior colliculus is related to what sensual control of vertebrates?
The most widely accepted way of comparing brain sizes across species is the so-called encephalization quotient , which takes into account the nonlinearity of the brain-to-body relationship	Comparing brain sizes among different creatures is used most commonly by what?
The visual processing network of primates includes at least 30 distinguishable brain areas, with a complex web of interconnections	Primates have a visual processing network of how many brain areas?
As the embryo transforms from a round blob of cells into a wormlike structure, a narrow strip of ectoderm running along the midline of the back is induced to become the neural plate, the precursor of the nervous system	The precursor of the nervous system is called what in vertebrates?
The tip of a growing axon consists of a blob of protoplasm called a growth cone, studded with chemical receptors	A growth cone of an axon is made up of a blob of what?
In humans and many other mammals, new neurons are created mainly before birth, and the infant brain contains substantially more neurons than the adult brain	The infant brain contains more of what type of cells in the brain than the adult brain?
The electrical properties of neurons are controlled by a wide variety of biochemical and metabolic processes, most notably the interactions between neurotransmitters and receptors that take place at synapses	The electrical properties of neurons are controlled by what?
Neurotransmitters are chemicals that are released at synapses when an action potential activates them—neurotransmitters attach themselves to receptor molecules on the membrane of the synapse's target cell, and thereby alter the electrical or chemical properties of the receptor molecules	Chemicals called neurotransmitters are released at what part of the brain?
The two neurotransmitters that are used most widely in the vertebrate brain are glutamate, which almost always exerts excitatory effects on target neurons, and gamma-aminobutyric acid , which is almost always inhibitory	GABA is the abbreviation for what?
Serotonin, for example—the primary target of antidepressant drugs and many dietary aids—comes exclusively from a small brainstem area called the Raphe nuclei	Serotonin comes from what part of the brain?
When large numbers of neurons show synchronized activity, the electric fields that they generate can be large enough to detect outside the skull, using electroencephalography or magnetoencephalography 	An EEG of the brain stands for what?
Glial cells play a major role in brain metabolism by controlling the chemical composition of the fluid that surrounds neurons, including levels of ions and nutrients	What type of cells have a huge role in brain metabolism?
In primates, however, the percentage is much higher—in humans it rises to 20–25%	The energy used for metabolism of the brain in humans is what percentage?
From an evolutionary-biological perspective, the function of the brain is to provide coherent control over the actions of an animal	The function of the brain from an evolutionary-biological thought is what?
The invention of electronic computers in the 1940s, along with the development of mathematical information theory, led to a realization that brains can potentially be understood as information processing systems	Computers were invented in what decade in history?
"One of the most influential early contributions was a 1959 paper titled What the frog's eye tells the frog's brain: the paper examined the visual responses of neurons in the retina and optic tectum of frogs, and came to the conclusion that some neurons in the tectum of the frog are wired to combine elementary responses in a way that makes them function as ""bug perceivers"""	The scientific paper, What the frog's eye tells the frog's brain was released in what year?
However, having said this, the Human Brain Project is trying to build a realistic, detailed computational model of the entire human brain	What is the project called that is trying to build a realistic, detailed computer model of the human brain?
Moreover, other animals may develop existing sensory systems in new ways, such as the adaptation by bats of the auditory sense into a form of sonar	What type of animal has a sense that adapted into sonar?
Each sensory system begins with specialized receptor cells, such as light-receptive neurons in the retina of the eye, vibration-sensitive neurons in the cochlea of the ear, or pressure-sensitive neurons in the skin	Light-receptive neurons are located in what part of the eye?
Except for the muscles that control the eye, which are driven by nuclei in the midbrain, all the voluntary muscles in the body are directly innervated by motor neurons in the spinal cord and hindbrain	What part of the body is controlled by nuclei in the midbrain?
At the lowest level are motor areas in the medulla and pons, which control stereotyped movements such as walking, breathing, or swallowing	Which motor areas of the brain control breathing and swallowing?
"In addition to all of the above, the brain and spinal cord contain extensive circuitry to control the autonomic nervous system, which works by secreting hormones and by modulating the ""smooth"" muscles of the gut"	The brain and spinal cord work together to control what system of the body?

There are two types of sleep: REM sleep and NREM sleep, which repeat in slightly varying patterns throughout a sleep episode	What type of sleep involves dreaming?

The field of neuroscience encompasses all approaches that seek to understand the brain and the rest of the nervous system	What field of science studies the brain and the central nervous system?

Neurophysiologists study the chemical, pharmacological, and electrical properties of the brain: their primary tools are drugs and recording devices	What do neurophysiologists study?

In the first half of the 20th century, advances in electronics enabled investigation of the electrical properties of nerve cells, culminating in work by Alan Hodgkin, Andrew Huxley, and others on the biophysics of the action potential, and the work of Bernard Katz and others on the electrochemistry of the synapse	Work in the first half the 20th century in electrical properties of nerve cells were by what two main scientists?

In the 21st century, these trends have continued, and several new approaches have come into prominence, including multielectrode recording, which allows the activity of many brain cells to be recorded all at the same time; genetic engineering, which allows molecular components of the brain to be altered experimentally; genomics, which allows variations in brain structure to be correlated with variations in DNA properties and neuroimaging	Multielectrode recording allows what?

Zhejiang , formerly romanized as Chekiang, is an eastern coastal province of China	What was Zhejiang formerly romanized as?
The province's name derives from the Zhe River , the former name of the Qiantang River which flows past Hangzhou and whose mouth forms Hangzhou Bay	What is the former name of the Qiantang River?
Zhejiang was the site of the Neolithic cultures of the Hemudu and Liangzhu	What kind of cultures were the Hemudu and Liangzhu?
Instead, this area was populated by peoples collectively known as the Hundred Yue, including the Dongyue and the Ouyue	Who populated the areas of Zhejiang in the 2nd millennium BC?
Kuaiji Commandery was the initial power base for Xiang Liang and Xiang Yu's rebellion against the Qin Empire which initially succeeded in restoring the kingdom of Chu but eventually fell to the Han	What was the initial power base for Xiang Liang and Xiang Yu's rebellion?
At the beginning of the Three Kingdoms era , Zhejiang was home to the warlords Yan Baihu and Wang Lang prior to their defeat by Sun Ce and Sun Quan, who eventually established the Kingdom of Wu	When was the beginning of the Three Kingdoms era?
Zhejiang was part of the Wu during the Three Kingdoms	When was Zhejiang part of the Wu?
Despite the continuing prominence of Nanjing , the settlement of Qiantang, the former name of Hangzhou, remained one of the three major metropolitan centers in the south to provide major tax revenue to the imperial centers in the north China	What was Nanjing formerly known as?
Following the fall of Wu and the turmoil of the Wu Hu uprising against the Jin dynasty , most of elite Chinese families had collaborated with the non-Chinese rulers and military conquerors in the north	When was the Jin Dynasty?
Zhejiang, as the heartland of the Jiangnan , remained the wealthiest area during the Six Dynasties , Sui, and Tang	When did the Six Dynasties end?
The Song dynasty reëstablished unity around 960	When did the Song dynasty reestablish unity around?

The term high definition once described a series of television systems originating from August 1936; however, these systems were only high definition when compared to earlier systems that were based on mechanical systems with as few as 30 lines of resolution	"The term ""high definition"" originally described televisions systems from what year?"
The British high-definition TV service started trials in August 1936 and a regular service on 2 November 1936 using both the Baird 240 line sequential scan and the Marconi-EMI 405 line interlaced systems	Who started trials in August 1936?

Since the formal adoption of digital video broadcasting's widescreen HDTV transmission modes in the early 2000s; the 525-line NTSC systems, as well as the European 625-line PAL and SECAM systems, are now regarded as standard definition television systems	When was widescreen HDTV transmission modes formally adopted?

Several systems were proposed as the new standard for the US, including the Japanese MUSE system, but all were rejected by the FCC because of their higher bandwidth requirements	Why did the FCC reject systems such as MUSE?
The limited standardization of analog HDTV in the 1990s did not lead to global HDTV adoption as technical and economic constraints at the time did not permit HDTV to use bandwidths greater than normal television	What constraints kept HDTV from being widely adopted in the 90's?
Early HDTV commercial experiments, such as NHK's MUSE, required over four times the bandwidth of a standard-definition broadcast	How much more bandwith was required from early HDTV commercial experiments than an SD broadcast?
Japan remained the only country with successful public broadcasting of analog HDTV, with seven broadcasters sharing a single channel	How many broadcasters did Japan have sharing a single channel?

HDTV technology was introduced in the United States in the late 1980s and made official in 1993 by the Digital HDTV Grand Alliance, a group of television, electronic equipment, communications companies consisting of AT&T Bell Labs, General Instrument, Philips, Sarnoff, Thomson, Zenith and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology	When was HDTV introduced in the US?
The first HDTV transmissions in Europe, albeit not direct-to-home, began in 1990, when the Italian broadcaster RAI used the HD-MAC and MUSE HDTV technologies to broadcast the 1990 FIFA World Cup	When did the first HDTV transmissions happen in Europe?
The first regular broadcasts started on January 1, 2004 when the Belgian company Euro1080 launched the HD1 channel with the traditional Vienna New Year's Concert	When did regular broadcasts start in Europe?
"Euro1080, a division of the former and now bankrupt Belgian TV services company Alfacam, broadcast HDTV channels to break the pan-European stalemate of ""no HD broadcasts mean no HD TVs bought means no HD broadcasts"	Euro1080 was a division of what former company?
These first European HDTV broadcasts used the 1080i format with MPEG-2 compression on a DVB-S signal from SES's Astra 1H satellite	What format did the first European HDTV broadcast use?
Despite delays in some countries, the number of European HD channels and viewers has risen steadily since the first HDTV broadcasts, with SES's annual Satellite Monitor market survey for 2010 reporting more than 200 commercial channels broadcasting in HD from Astra satellites, 185 million HD capable TVs sold in Europe , and 20 million households watching HD satellite broadcasts 	According to the 2010 Satellite Monitor market survey, how many HD capable TV's were sold in Europe?

It has been used for thousands of years for both fuel and as a construction material	In addition to being used to build things, what has wood been used for over thousands of years?
The Earth contains about 434 billion cubic meters of growing stock forest, 47% of which is commercial	How many cubic meters of growing stock forest are there on the planet?
A 2011 discovery in the Canadian province of New Brunswick uncovered the earliest known plants to have grown wood, approximately 395 to 400 million years ago	What year were the earliest plants that grew wood discovered?
People have used wood for millennia for many purposes, primarily as a fuel or as a construction material for making houses, tools, weapons, furniture, packaging, artworks, and paper	What has been the primary purpose of wood for millennia other than fuel?
Wood, in the strict sense, is yielded by trees, which increase in diameter by the formation, between the existing wood and the inner bark, of new woody layers which envelop the entire stem, living branches, and roots	Where does wood come from?
If there are differences within a growth ring, then the part of a growth ring nearest the center of the tree, and formed early in the growing season when growth is rapid, is usually composed of wider elements	If a growth ring has differences over one season, would the part nearest the tree's center be narrower or wider?
A knot is a particular type of imperfection in a piece of wood; it will affect the technical properties of the wood, usually reducing the local strength and increasing the tendency for splitting along the wood grain, but may be exploited for visual effect	What is the sort of circular imperfection in a piece of wood called?
In the tree a knot is either the base of a side branch or a dormant bud	Other than the base of a side branch, what tree feature causes a knot?
During the development of a tree, the lower limbs often die, but may remain attached for a time, sometimes years	What will the lower limbs of a tree usually do during development?
In grading lumber and structural timber, knots are classified according to their form, size, soundness, and the firmness with which they are held in place	What's the process in which knots are classified called?
Stiffness and elastic strength are more dependent upon the sound wood than upon localized defects	What is wood's breaking strength susceptible to? 
In some decorative applications, wood with knots may be desirable to add visual interest	What positive visual component can knots sometimes add to decorative pieces?
Heartwood is wood that as a result of a naturally occurring chemical transformation has become more resistant to decay	"What's another word for ""duramen""?"
Heartwood is often visually distinct from the living sapwood, and can be distinguished in a cross-section where the boundary will tend to follow the growth rings	In what part of a tree's cross-section is heartwood visible?
Sapwood is the younger, outermost wood; in the growing tree it is living wood, and its principal functions are to conduct water from the roots to the leaves and to store up and give back according to the season the reserves prepared in the leaves	"What term is interchangeable with ""sapwood""?"
Some species begin to form heartwood very early in life, so having only a thin layer of live sapwood, while in others the change comes slowly	If a tree starts forming heartwood right away, will its sapwood layer be thin or thick?
Within the same species the cross-sectional area of the sapwood is very roughly proportional to the size of the crown of the tree	What part of a tree is the cross-sectional area of the sapwood approximately proportional to?
When a tree is very young it is covered with limbs almost, if not entirely, to the ground, but as it grows older some or all of them will eventually die and are either broken off or fall off	What usually covers the whole trunk of a very young tree?
Every broken limb or root, or deep wound from fire, insects, or falling timber, may afford an entrance for decay, which, once started, may penetrate to all parts of the trunk	What do broken limbs and deep wounds open a door for in a tree?
If a tree grows all its life in the open and the conditions of soil and site remain unchanged, it will make its most rapid growth in youth, and gradually decline	In what stage of its life does a tree usually grow the fastest?
Different pieces of wood cut from a large tree may differ decidedly, particularly if the tree is big and mature	When a big tree is cut up, will the pieces of wood differ or all be the same?
In species which show a distinct difference between heartwood and sapwood the natural color of heartwood is usually darker than that of the sapwood, and very frequently the contrast is conspicuous 	When trees have a visible difference in color between sapwood and heartwood, which is darker?
Some experiments on very resinous Longleaf Pine specimens indicate an increase in strength, due to the resin which increases the strength when dry	What type of tree has resin that makes it stronger when it dries?
Since the latewood of a growth ring is usually darker in color than the earlywood, this fact may be used in judging the density, and therefore the hardness and strength of the material	Which of the wood in a growth ring is usually darker?
Abnormal discoloration of wood often denotes a diseased condition, indicating unsoundness	What condition does an abnormal color usually indicate in wood?
Wood that is thoroughly air-dried retains 8–16% of the water in the cell walls, and none, or practically none, in the other forms	What does wood retain in its cell walls despite being air-dried?
The general effect of the water content upon the wood substance is to render it softer and more pliable	Often the water in wood makes it more pliable and what else?
Drying produces a decided increase in the strength of wood, particularly in small specimens	What will drying often increase in wood?
The greatest strength increase due to drying is in the ultimate crushing strength, and strength at elastic limit in endwise compression; these are followed by the modulus of rupture, and stress at elastic limit in cross-bending, while the modulus of elasticity is least affected	"What type of ""ultimate"" strength is one of the two types increased the most by drying wood?"
Wood is a heterogeneous, hygroscopic, cellular and anisotropic material	Along with hygroscopic, cellular, and anisotropic, how is the material of wood described?
In coniferous or softwood species the wood cells are mostly of one kind, tracheids, and as a result the material is much more uniform in structure than that of most hardwoods	What type of cells makes up most wood cells in coniferous trees?
The structure of hardwoods is more complex	Is the structure of hardwood simple or complex?
In ring-porous species, such as ash, black locust, catalpa, chestnut, elm, hickory, mulberry, and oak, the larger vessels or pores are localised in the part of the growth ring formed in spring, thus forming a region of more or less open and porous tissue	What species of hardwood are hickory and mulberry trees?
In diffuse-porous woods the pores are evenly sized so that the water conducting capability is scattered throughout the growth ring instead of being collected in a band or row	What kind of woods have pores that are uniformly sized?
In temperate softwoods there often is a marked difference between latewood and earlywood	What kind of softwoods often have significant differences in their earlywood and latewood?
If a heavy piece of pine is compared with a lightweight piece it will be seen at once that the heavier one contains a larger proportion of latewood than the other, and is therefore showing more clearly demarcated growth rings	Comparing a heavy and a lightweight piece of wood from a pine, which would have a greater proportion of latewood?
It is not only the proportion of latewood, but also its quality, that counts	Having a high proportion of latewood isn't all that matters; what else is important?
The quality of the site where the tree grows undoubtedly affects the character of the wood formed, though it is not possible to formulate a rule governing it	What facet of wood is affected to some degree by the place where the tree grows?
In ring-porous woods each season's growth is always well defined, because the large pores formed early in the season abut on the denser tissue of the year before	What kind of woods always have very clearly marked seasonal growth?
In the case of the ring-porous hardwoods there seems to exist a pretty definite relation between the rate of growth of timber and its properties	Ring-porous hardwoods have a clear relationship between their properties and what other factor?
In ring-porous woods of good growth it is usually the latewood in which the thick-walled, strength-giving fibers are most abundant	Which specific type of wood within ring-porous woods have more fibers to make it strong?
"Wide-ringed wood is often called ""second-growth"", because the growth of the young timber in open stands after the old trees have been removed is more rapid than in trees in a closed forest, and in the manufacture of articles where strength is an important consideration such ""second-growth"" hardwood material is preferred"	What term is sometimes used for wood with wide rings?
In the diffuse-porous woods, the demarcation between rings is not always so clear and in some cases is almost invisible to the unaided eye	What kind of wood often has ring divisions that can't even be seen by looking at it?
In diffuse-porous woods, as has been stated, the vessels or pores are even-sized, so that the water conducting capability is scattered throughout the ring instead of collected in the earlywood	What kind of wood has all similarly sized vessels?
"Structural material that resembles ordinary, ""dicot"" or conifer wood in its gross handling characteristics is produced by a number of monocot plants, and these also are colloquially called wood"	"What's another term used for ""conifer"" wood?"
The single most revealing property of wood as an indicator of wood quality is specific gravity , as both pulp yield and lumber strength are determined by it	Which property of wood reveals the most about its quality?
Wood density is determined by multiple growth and physiological factors compounded into “one fairly easily measured wood characteristic” 	Along with growth, what kind of factors determine the density of wood?
Variation is to be expected	What should be anticipated because of the many factors that influence wood's density?
It is common to classify wood as either softwood or hardwood	What term do we use for the wood that comes from pine trees?
There is a strong relationship between the properties of wood and the properties of the particular tree that yielded it	What kind of relationship exists between a tree's properties and its wood's properties?
The chemical composition of wood varies from species to species, but is approximately 50% carbon, 42% oxygen, 6% hydrogen, 1% nitrogen, and 1% other elements by weight	What approximate percentage of carbon does wood have?
Aside from water, wood has three main components	How many main components make up wood, not counting water?
In chemical terms, the difference between hardwood and softwood is reflected in the composition of the constituent lignin	What component of wood determines whether it is hardwood or softwood?
Aside from the lignocellulose, wood consists of a variety of low molecular weight organic compounds, called extractives	What's the name for the low molecular weight organic compounds in wood?
Hardwood is preferred over softwood because it creates less smoke and burns longer	What type of wood is preferred as fuel?
Elm in particular was used for this purpose as it resisted decay as long as it was kept wet 	What wood is decay-resistant when wet?
Wood to be used for construction work is commonly known as lumber in North America	What term is used in North America for wood used in construction?
New domestic housing in many parts of the world today is commonly made from timber-framed construction	What type of construction is often used now to build homes in much of the world?
In buildings made of other materials, wood will still be found as a supporting material, especially in roof construction, in interior doors and their frames, and as exterior cladding	What might wood be used for in a building made from brick or other materials?
"Engineered wood products, glued building products ""engineered"" for application-specific performance requirements, are often used in construction and industrial applications"	What holds together an engineered wood product?
These products include glued laminated timber , wood structural panels , laminated veneer lumber and other structural composite lumber products, parallel strand lumber, and I-joists	What category do composite panels, strand board, and plywood all fit into?
Wood unsuitable for construction in its native form may be broken down mechanically or chemically and used as a raw material for other building materials, such as engineered wood, as well as chipboard, hardboard, and medium-density fiberboard 	What material results from chemically breaking down wood?
Wood has always been used extensively for furniture, such as chairs and beds	What category of products usually made from wood includes chairs?
Moisture content electronic monitoring can also enhance next generation wood protection	What could we monitor electronically that could help inform new methods of wood protection?
It has been used to make sculptures and carvings for millennia	Along with sculptures, what type of art have people been making out of wood for centuries?

According to most scholars, the ancient Land of Punt and its inhabitants formed part of the ethnogenesis of the Somali people	What ancient land was connected to the modern Somali people?
In the classical era, several ancient city-states such as Opone, Essina, Sarapion, Nikon, Malao, Damo and Mosylon near Cape Guardafui, which competed with the Sabaeans, Parthians and Axumites for the wealthy Indo-Greco-Roman trade, also flourished in Somalia	Near what headland was Mosylon located?
The birth of Islam on the opposite side of Somalia's Red Sea coast meant that Somali merchants, sailors and expatriates living in the Arabian Peninsula gradually came under the influence of the new religion through their converted Arab Muslim trading partners	What body of water separated Somalia from the land where Islam was born?
The Sultanate of Ifat, led by the Walashma dynasty with its capital at Zeila, ruled over parts of what is now eastern Ethiopia, Djibouti, and northern Somalia	What dynasty ruled the Sultanate of Ifat?
In the Middle Ages, several powerful Somali empires dominated the regional trade including the Ajuran Sultanate, which excelled in hydraulic engineering and fortress building, the Sultanate of Adal, whose general Ahmad ibn Ibrahim al-Ghazi was the first commander to use cannon warfare on the continent during Adal's conquest of the Ethiopian Empire, and the Sultanate of the Geledi, whose military dominance forced governors of the Omani empire north of the city of Lamu to pay tribute to the Somali Sultan Ahmed Yusuf	What Somali polity of the Middle Ages was known for its fortresses?

The Late Middle Ages was marked by difficulties and calamities including famine, plague, and war, which significantly diminished the population of Europe; between 1347 and 1350, the Black Death killed about a third of Europeans	When did the Black Death end?

International Gothic was a courtly style that reached much of Europe in the decades around 1400, producing masterpieces such as the Très Riches Heures du Duc de Berry	Around what year did the International Gothic style flourish?
The large external sculptural schemes of Early Gothic churches gave way to more sculpture inside the building, as tombs became more elaborate and other features such as pulpits were sometimes lavishly carved, as in the Pulpit by Giovanni Pisano in Sant'Andrea	Who carved the Pulpit in Sant'Andrea?

Phonology is a branch of linguistics concerned with the systematic organization of sounds in languages	What is phonology a branch of?
The word phonology can also refer to the phonological system of a given language	What part of a language can phonology as a word also refer to?
Phonology is often distinguished from phonetics	What branch of linguistics is phonology distinguished from?
"The word phonology comes from the Greek φωνή, phōnḗ, ""voice, sound,"" and the suffix -logy "	What language does phonology as a word come from?
The history of phonology may be traced back to the Ashtadhyayi, the Sanskrit grammar composed by Pāṇini in the 4th century BC	What type of grammar was phonology first a part of?
The Polish scholar Jan Baudouin de Courtenay introduced the concept of the phoneme in 1876, and his work, though often unacknowledged, is considered to be the starting point of modern phonology	When was the phoneme as a concept introduced?
One of its leading members was Prince Nikolai Trubetzkoy, whose Grundzüge der Phonologie , published posthumously in 1939, is among the most important works in the field from this period	What was Nikolai Trubetzkoy's publication?
In 1968 Noam Chomsky and Morris Halle published The Sound Pattern of English , the basis for generative phonology	When was The Sound Pattern of English published?
Natural phonology is a theory based on the publications of its proponent David Stampe in 1969 and in 1979	Whose publications started the theory of Natural phonology?
In 1976 John Goldsmith introduced autosegmental phonology	Who founded autosegmental phonology?
Government phonology, which originated in the early 1980s as an attempt to unify theoretical notions of syntactic and phonological structures, is based on the notion that all languages necessarily follow a small set of principles and vary according to their selection of certain binary parameters	When was Government phonology first seen?
In a course at the LSA summer institute in 1991, Alan Prince and Paul Smolensky developed optimality theory—an overall architecture for phonology according to which languages choose a pronunciation of a word that best satisfies a list of constraints ordered by importance; a lower-ranked constraint can be violated when the violation is necessary in order to obey a higher-ranked constraint	When did Prince and Smolensky develop their theory?
Broadly speaking, government phonology has a greater following in the United Kingdom, whereas optimality theory is predominant in the United States	What followed government phonology?
An integrated approach to phonological theory that combines synchronic and diachronic accounts to sound patterns was initiated with Evolutionary Phonology in recent years	What is Evolutionary Phonology an integrated approach to?
An important part of traditional, pre-generative schools of phonology is studying which sounds can be grouped into distinctive units within a language; these units are known as phonemes	What are the units called that traditional phonology studies?
Part of the phonological study of a language therefore involves looking at data and trying to deduce what the underlying phonemes are and what the sound inventory of the language is	What type of language study involves trying to deduce underlying phonomes?
This is one of the main factors of historical change of languages as described in historical linguistics	What kind of linguistics describes how factors of languages change in history?
The findings and insights of speech perception and articulation research complicate the traditional and somewhat intuitive idea of interchangeable allophones being perceived as the same phoneme	How do speech perception and articulation findings and insights affect previous and more traditional ideas?
Different linguists therefore take different approaches to the problem of assigning sounds to phonemes	What are assigned to phonemes by different linguists?
Since the early 1960s, theoretical linguists have moved away from the traditional concept of a phoneme, preferring to consider basic units at a more abstract level, as a component of morphemes; these units can be called morphophonemes, and analysis using this approach is called morphophonology	When did theoretical linguists turn away traditional phoneme concepts?
In addition to the minimal units that can serve the purpose of differentiating meaning , phonology studies how sounds alternate, i	What do phonemes differentiate? 
Phonology also includes topics such as phonotactics and phonological alternation as well as prosody, the study of suprasegmentals and topics such as stress and intonation	Under what topic is suprasegmentals studied?
The principles of phonological analysis can be applied independently of modality because they are designed to serve as general analytical tools, not language-specific ones	Instead of being language-specific what kind of tools are the principles of phonological analysis designed to be?

A general purpose computer has four main components: the arithmetic logic unit , the control unit, the memory, and the input and output devices 	The ALU of a computer stands for what?
Inside each of these parts are thousands to trillions of small electrical circuits which can be turned off or on by means of an electronic switch	"In positive logic representation a ""1"" represents when a circuit is what?"
The control unit manages the computer's various components; it reads and interprets the program instructions, transforming them into control signals that activate other parts of the computer	What are other names for a control unit for a computer?
A key component common to all CPUs is the program counter, a special memory cell that keeps track of which location in memory the next instruction is to be read from	A special memory cell of a CPU is called what?
Since the program counter is just another set of memory cells, it can be changed by calculations done in the ALU	In what part can the program counter be changed by calculations?
The sequence of operations that the control unit goes through to process an instruction is in itself like a short computer program, and indeed, in some more complex CPU designs, there is another yet smaller computer called a microsequencer, which runs a microcode program that causes all of these events to happen	In some CPU designs there is tinier computer called what?
The control unit, ALU, and registers are collectively known as a central processing unit 	The CPU is an abbreviation for what?
The set of arithmetic operations that a particular ALU supports may be limited to addition and subtraction, or might include multiplication, division, trigonometry functions such as sine, cosine, etc	Some trigonometry functions are what?
Logic operations involve Boolean logic: AND, OR, XOR, and NOT	Boolean logic consists of what?
Superscalar computers may contain multiple ALUs, allowing them to process several instructions simultaneously	Computers that have multiple ALUs are called what?
"Each cell has a numbered ""address"" and can store a single number"	How many numbers can a cell of a computer's memory hold?
In almost all modern computers, each memory cell is set up to store binary numbers in groups of eight bits 	A group of 8 bits is called what?
The CPU contains a special set of memory cells called registers that can be read and written to much more rapidly than the main memory area	What part of the computer has memory cells called registers?
RAM can be read and written to anytime the CPU commands it, but ROM is preloaded with data and software that never changes, therefore the CPU can only read from it	What type of memory can a CPU only read from?
In more sophisticated computers there may be one or more RAM cache memories, which are slower than registers but faster than main memory	RAM cache memory is slower than what?

Seemingly, multitasking would cause a computer that is switching between several programs to run more slowly, in direct proportion to the number of programs it is running, but most programs spend much of their time waiting for slow input/output devices to complete their tasks	Multitasking would seemingly cause a computer to run in what fashion?

The Times is a British daily national newspaper based in London	The Times is based in what major British city?
The Times is the first newspaper to have borne that name, lending it to numerous other papers around the world, including The Times of India , The Straits Times , The New York Times , The Irish Times , Le Temps , the Cape Times , the Los Angeles Times , The Seattle Times , The Manila Times , The Daily Times , El Tiempo , The Canberra Times , and The Times 	What year did The Times of India start?

In 1815, The Times had a circulation of 5,000	In 1815, The Times had a circulation of how many people?

New Delhi is a municipality and district in Delhi which serves as the capital and seat of government of India	In what territory is New Delhi located?
The foundation stone of the city was laid by George V, Emperor of India during the Delhi Durbar of 1911	In what year was the foundation stone of New Delhi laid?
