Oklahoma i/ˌoʊkləˈhoʊmə/ , Pawnee: Uukuhuúwa, Cayuga: Gahnawiyoˀgeh) is a state located in the South Central United States	What is the Cherokee name for Oklahoma?
The name Oklahoma comes from the Choctaw phrase okla humma, literally meaning red people	What language does the name Oklahoma come from?
Oklahoma is the 20th largest state in the United States, covering an area of 69,898 square miles , with 68,667 square miles of land and 1,281 square miles of water	Where does Oklahoma rank by land area?
The border between Texas and New Mexico was set first as a result of a survey by Spain in 1819	When was the border between TX and NM first determined?
Oklahoma is between the Great Plains and the Ozark Plateau in the Gulf of Mexico watershed, generally sloping from the high plains of its western boundary to the low wetlands of its southeastern boundary	What plateau is Oklahoma near?
Oklahoma has four primary mountain ranges: the Ouachita Mountains, the Arbuckle Mountains, the Wichita Mountains, and the Ozark Mountains	How many major mountain ranges are in Oklahoma?
The semi-arid high plains in the state's northwestern corner harbor few natural forests; the region has a rolling to flat landscape with intermittent canyons and mesa ranges like the Glass Mountains	What is an example of a mesa range?
Forests cover 24 percent of Oklahoma and prairie grasslands composed of shortgrass, mixed-grass, and tallgrass prairie, harbor expansive ecosystems in the state's central and western portions, although cropland has largely replaced native grasses	How much of Oklahoma is covered in forests?
The state holds populations of white-tailed deer, mule deer, antelope, coyotes, mountain lions, bobcats, elk, and birds such as quail, doves, cardinals, bald eagles, red-tailed hawks, and pheasants	What types of birds does Oklahoma have a lot of?
With 39,000 acres , the Tallgrass Prairie Preserve in north-central Oklahoma is the largest protected area of tallgrass prairie in the world and is part of an ecosystem that encompasses only 10 percent of its former land area, once covering 14 states	How large is the Tallgrass Prairie Preserve?
Oklahoma is located in a humid subtropical region	What is Oklahoma's main climate region?
As an example, on November 11, 1911, the temperature at Oklahoma City reached 83 °F in the afternoon , then an Arctic cold front of unprecedented intensity slammed across the state, causing the temperature to crash 66 degrees, down to 17 °F at midnight ; thus, both the record high and record low for November 11 were set on the same date	What is Oklahoma's record high temperature for Nov 11?
The humid subtropical climate of central, southern and eastern Oklahoma is influenced heavily by southerly winds bringing moisture from the Gulf of Mexico	What parts of Oklahoma are in a humid subtropical climate?
Over almost all of Oklahoma, winter is the driest season	Which season is the most dry in Oklahoma?
All of the state frequently experiences temperatures above 100 °F or below 0 °F , though below-zero temperatures are rare in south-central and southeastern Oklahoma	What parts of Oklahoma rarely see below-zero temperatures?

Oklahoma is the nation's third-largest producer of natural gas, fifth-largest producer of crude oil, and has the second-greatest number of active drilling rigs, and ranks fifth in crude oil reserves	What is Oklahoma's rank among states producing crude oil?
According to Forbes magazine, Oklahoma City-based Devon Energy Corporation, Chesapeake Energy Corporation, and SandRidge Energy Corporation are the largest private oil-related companies in the nation, and all of Oklahoma's Fortune 500 companies are energy-related	Which largest private oil companies are based in Oklahoma City?
The state has a rich history in ballet with five Native American ballerinas attaining worldwide fame	How many famous Native American ballerinas came from Oklahoma?
"In Sand Springs, an outdoor amphitheater called ""Discoveryland"	Where is 'Discoveryland!'?
Prominent theatre companies in Oklahoma include, in the capital city, Oklahoma City Theatre Company, Carpenter Square Theatre, Oklahoma Shakespeare in the Park, and CityRep	What major theater groups are in Oklahoma City?
Oklahoma is in the nation's middle percentile in per capita spending on the arts, ranking 17th, and contains more than 300 museums	How many museums are in Oklahoma?
The Egyptian art collection at the Mabee-Gerrer Museum of Art in Shawnee is considered to be the finest Egyptian collection between Chicago and Los Angeles	Where does Oklahoma have a fine Egyptian art collection?
Oklahoma's centennial celebration was named the top event in the United States for 2007 by the American Bus Association, and consisted of multiple celebrations saving with the 100th anniversary of statehood on November 16, 2007	When was Oklahoma's centennial year?
During a 10-day run in Oklahoma City, the State Fair of Oklahoma attracts roughly one million people along with the annual Festival of the Arts	How long is the State Fair of Oklahoma?
Norman is also host to the Medieval Fair of Norman, which has been held annually since 1976 and was Oklahoma's first medieval fair	When did the Medieval Fair of Norman begin?
With an educational system made up of public school districts and independent private institutions, Oklahoma had 638,817 students enrolled in 1,845 public primary, secondary, and vocational schools in 533 school districts as of 2008	How many students were in Oklahoma's public schools in 2008?
The state is among the best in pre-kindergarten education, and the National Institute for Early Education Research rated it first in the United States with regard to standards, quality, and access to pre-kindergarten education in 2004, calling it a model for early childhood schooling	Who said Oklahoma's pre-K program is the best in the US?
Oklahoma holds eleven public regional universities, including Northeastern State University, the second-oldest institution of higher education west of the Mississippi River, also containing the only College of Optometry in Oklahoma and the largest enrollment of Native American students in the nation by percentage and amount	How many public universities does Oklahoma have?
In the 2007–2008 school year, there were 181,973 undergraduate students, 20,014 graduate students, and 4,395 first-professional degree students enrolled in Oklahoma colleges	How many undergrad students were in Oklahoma in 2007?

The NBA's New Orleans Hornets became the first major league sports franchise based in Oklahoma when the team was forced to relocate to Oklahoma City's Ford Center, now known as Chesapeake Energy Arena, for two seasons following Hurricane Katrina in 2005	Which NBA team temporarily relocated to Oklahoma?
The state has four schools that compete at the highest level of college sports, NCAA Division I	How many NCAA Division I colleges does Oklahoma have?

The state has two primary newspapers	How many major newspapers does Oklahoma have?
More than 12,000 miles of roads make up the state's major highway skeleton, including state-operated highways, ten turnpikes or major toll roads, and the longest drivable stretch of Route 66 in the nation	How many miles of highways are in Oklahoma?
Oklahoma's largest commercial airport is Will Rogers World Airport in Oklahoma City, averaging a yearly passenger count of more than 3	What is the largest commercial airport in Oklahoma?
Two inland ports on rivers serve Oklahoma: the Port of Muskogee and the Tulsa Port of Catoosa	How many ports does Oklahoma have?
Oklahoma's judicial branch consists of the Oklahoma Supreme Court, the Oklahoma Court of Criminal Appeals, and 77 District Courts that each serves one county	How many district courts does Oklahoma have?
The executive branch consists of the Governor, their staff, and other elected officials	Who is in the executive branch?
The state is divided into 77 counties that govern locally, each headed by a three-member council of elected commissioners, a tax assessor, clerk, court clerk, treasurer, and sheriff	How many county commissioners does each Oklahoma county have?
Thirty-nine Native American tribal governments are based in Oklahoma, each holding limited powers within designated areas	How many tribal governments are in Oklahoma?
After the 1948 election, the state turned firmly Republican	What political party rose to power in Oklahoma in 1948?
House of Representatives was reduced from six to five representatives, each serving one congressional district	How many US House reps did Oklahoma have before the 2000 census?

The history of India includes the prehistoric settlements and societies in the Indian subcontinent; the blending of the Indus Valley Civilization and Indo-Aryan culture into the Vedic Civilization; the development of Hinduism as a synthesis of various Indian cultures and traditions; the rise of the Śramaṇa movement; the decline of Śrauta sacrifices and the birth of the initiatory traditions of Jainism, Buddhism, Shaivism, Vaishnavism and Shaktism; the onset of a succession of powerful dynasties and empires for more than two millennia throughout various geographic areas of the subcontinent, including the growth of Muslim dynasties during the Medieval period intertwined with Hindu powers; the advent of European traders resulting in the establishment of the British rule; and the subsequent independence movement that led to the Partition of India and the creation of the Republic of India	In what geographic area was the country of India established?
Evidence of Anatomically modern humans in the Indian subcontinent is recorded as long as 75,000 years ago, or with earlier hominids including Homo erectus from about 500,000 years ago	For how long have modern humans lived on the Indian subcontinent?
Most of the subcontinent was conquered by the Maurya Empire during the 4th and 3rd centuries BCE	What empire conquered most of the subcontinent in the 3rd and 4th centuries BC?
The most significant event between the 7th and 11th century was the Tripartite struggle centered on Kannauj that lasted for more than two centuries between the Pala Empire, Rashtrakuta Empire, and Gurjara Pratihara Empire	Between what centuries was the Tripartite struggle focused on Kannauj?
Muslim rule started in parts of north India in the 13th century when the Delhi Sultanate was founded in 1206 CE by the Central Asian Turks	What group founded the Delhi Sultanate in the 13th century?
From the late 18th century to the mid-19th century, large areas of India were annexed by the British East India Company of British Empire	What company annexed large areas of India in the 18th and 19th centuries?
"Romila Thapar notes that the division into Hindu-Muslim-British periods of Indian history gives too much weight to ""ruling dynasties and foreign invasions"", neglecting the social-economic history which often showed a strong continuity"	Who remarked Indian history is too devoted to the ranking of dynasties and invasions?
Isolated remains of Homo erectus in Hathnora in the Narmada Valley in central India indicate that India might have been inhabited since at least the Middle Pleistocene era, somewhere between 500,000 and 200,000 years ago	By what era was India inhabited by humans of some form?
The Mesolithic period in the Indian subcontinent was followed by the Neolithic period, when more extensive settlement of the subcontinent occurred after the end of the last Ice Age approximately 12,000 years ago	What geologic period came after the Mesolithic period in India?
The Mature Indus civilisation flourished from about 2600 to 1900 BCE, marking the beginning of urban civilisation on the subcontinent	When did the Mature Indus Civilization thrive? 
The Vedic period is named after the Indo-Aryan culture of north-west India, although other parts of India had a distinct cultural identity during this period	For what culture is the Vedic period named?
At the end of the Rigvedic period, the Aryan society began to expand from the northwestern region of the Indian subcontinent, into the western Ganges plain	When did the Aryan culture begin its expansion?
The Kuru kingdom was the first state-level society of the Vedic period, corresponding to the beginning of the Iron Age in northwestern India, around 1200 – 800 BCE, as well as with the composition of the Atharvaveda 	What was the first state size society in the Vedic period?
In addition to the Vedas, the principal texts of Hinduism, the core themes of the Sanskrit epics Ramayana and Mahabharata are said to have their ultimate origins during this period	What were the principle texts of Hinduism?
During the time between 800 and 200 BCE the Shramana-movement formed, from which originated Jainism and Buddhism	What philosophical movement appeared during 800-200 BCE?
In the later Vedic Age, a number of small kingdoms or city states had covered the subcontinent, many mentioned in Vedic, early Buddhist and Jaina literature as far back as 500 BCE	By what age had many small states covered the subcontinent?
"Early ""republics"" such as the Vajji confederation centered in the city of Vaishali, existed as early as the 6th century BCE and persisted in some areas until the 4th century CE"	Where was the Vajji confederation located?
The 7th and 6th centuries BC witnessed the composition of the earliest Upanishads	When were the earliest Upanishads composed?
Increasing urbanisation of India in 7th and 6th centuries BCE led to the rise of new ascetic or shramana movements which challenged the orthodoxy of rituals	What did the shramana movements challenge?
Magadha formed one of the sixteen Mahā-Janapadas or kingdoms in ancient India	Of what was Magadha one of sixteen?
The earliest reference to the Magadha people occurs in the Atharva-Veda where they are found listed along with the Angas, Gandharis, and Mujavats	Where is the earliest mention of Magadha people?
In 530 BC Cyrus the Great, King of the Persian Achaemenid Empire crossed the Hindu-Kush mountains to seek tribute from the tribes of Kamboja, Gandhara and the trans-India region 	What Persian king wanted tribute from the tribes of northern India?
By 326 BC, Alexander the Great had conquered Asia Minor and the Achaemenid Empire and had reached the northwest frontiers of the Indian subcontinent	When did Alexander the Great reach India?
The Maurya Empire was the first empire to unify India into one state, and was the largest on the Indian subcontinent	What was the first empire to unify India?
The Arthashastra and the Edicts of Ashoka are the primary written records of the Mauryan times	What are the basic written records of the Mauryans?
During the Sangam period Tamil literateure flourished from the 3rd century BCE to the 4th century CE	During what period did Tamil literature thrive?
3	How many Tamil dynasties ruled during the Sangam period?
The Śātavāhana Empire was a royal Indian dynasty based from Amaravati in Andhra Pradesh as well as Junnar and Prathisthan in Maharashtra	What empire covered most of India from 230 BCE?
The Shunga Empire or Shunga Empire was an ancient Indian dynasty from Magadha that controlled vast areas of the Indian subcontinent from around 187 to 78 BCE	What was the time span of the Shunga Empire?
During the reign of Khārabēḷa, the Chedi dynasty of Kaḷinga ascended to eminence and restored the lost power and glory of Kaḷinga, which had been subdued since the devastating war with Ashoka	What Kalingan ruler brought the Chedi dynasty back into power?
The Kushan Empire expanded out of what is now Afghanistan into the northwest of the subcontinent under the leadership of their first emperor, Kujula Kadphises, about the middle of the 1st century CE	From what area did the Kushan Empire come?
Classical India refers to the period when much of the Indian subcontinent was reunited under the Gupta Empire (c	By what is India under the Gupta Empire referered?
The Gupta period marked a watershed of Indian culture: the Guptas performed Vedic sacrifices to legitimize their rule, but they also patronized Buddhism, which continued to provide an alternative to Brahmanical orthodoxy	What did the Guptas promote in their reigns?
Kadamba was an ancient royal dynasty of Karnataka, India that ruled northern Karnataka and the Konkan from Banavasi in present-day Uttara Kannada district	During what time did Kadamba rule northern Karnataka?
The Hephthalites , also known as the White Huns, were a nomadic confederation in Central Asia during the late antiquity period	What type of trib were the Hephthalites?
After the downfall of the prior Gupta Empire in the middle of the 6th century, North India reverted to small republics and small monarchical states ruled by Gupta rulers	In which century did the Gupta Empire fall?
From the fifth century to the thirteenth, Śrauta sacrifices declined, and initiatory traditions of Buddhism, Jainism or more commonly Shaivism, Vaishnavism and Shaktism expanded in royal courts	What declined from the 5th to the 13th centuries
Although Buddhism did not disappear from India for several centuries after the eighth, royal proclivities for the cults of Vishnu and Shiva weakened Buddhism's position within the sociopolitical context and helped make possible its decline	What cults weakened Buddhism in India?
From the 8th to the 10th century, three dynasties contested for control of northern India: the Gurjara Pratiharas of Malwa, the Palas of Bengal, and the Rashtrakutas of the Deccan	How many dynasties fought for control from the 8th to the 10th century?
The Chalukya Empire ) was an Indian royal dynasty that ruled large parts of southern and central India between the 6th and the 12th centuries	When did the Chalukya Empire rule?
Founded by Dantidurga around 753, the Rashtrakuta Empire ruled from its capital at Manyakheta for almost two centuries	When was the Rastrakuta Empire started?
The Pala Empire flourished during the Classical period of India, and may be dated during 750–1174 CE	During what span of time did the Pala Empire thrive?

Several Islamic kingdoms under both foreign and, newly converted, Rajput rulers were established across the north western subcontinent over a period of a few centuries	In what areas of India were Islamic kingdoms formed over a period of centuries?
The Kabul Shahi dynasties ruled the Kabul Valley and Gandhara from the decline of the Kushan Empire in the 3rd century to the early 9th century	Until what century did the Kabul Shahi dynasties rule the Kabul Valley?
Jayapala saw a danger in the consolidation of the Ghaznavids and invaded their capital city of Ghazni both in the reign of Sebuktigin and in that of his son Mahmud, which initiated the Muslim Ghaznavid and Hindu Shahi struggles	In what id Jayapala see a danger to his dynasty?
In the year 1001, soon after Sultan Mahmud came to power and was occupied with the Qarakhanids north of the Hindu Kush, Jaipal attacked Ghazni once more and upon suffering yet another defeat by the powerful Ghaznavid forces, near present-day Peshawar	In what year was Jaipal again soundly defeated by the Muslims?
In evaluating the impact of Islam on the sub-continent, one must note that the northwestern sub-continent was a frequent target of tribes raiding from Central Asia	From where did raiders come to attack the agrarian Indians?
The subsequent Slave dynasty of Delhi managed to conquer large areas of northern India, while the Khilji dynasty conquered most of central India but were ultimately unsuccessful in conquering and uniting the subcontinent	What conquered large areas of northern India?
A Turco-Mongol conqueror in Central Asia, Timur , attacked the reigning Sultan Nasir-u Din Mehmud of the Tughlaq Dynasty in the north Indian city of Delhi	What Turko-Mongol attacked and defeated the Sultan of Tughlaq dynasty?
The Empire was established in 1336 by Harihara I and his brother Bukka Raya I of Sangama Dynasty	In what year was Sangama Dynasty formed?
For two and a half centuries from the mid 13th, the politics in the Northern India was dominated by the Delhi Sultanate and in the Southern India by the Vijayanagar Empire which originated as a political heir of the erstwhile Hoysala Empire and Pandyan Empire	From the mid 13th century, what dominated politics in northern India?
Ahom Kingdom was a kingdom and tribe which rose to prominence in present-day Assam early in the thirteenth century	What kingdom came to power in Assam?
In 1526, Babur, a Timurid descendant of Timur and Genghis Khan from Fergana Valley , swept across the Khyber Pass and established the Mughal Empire, which at its zenith covered modern day Afghanistan, Pakistan, India and Bangladesh	What empire did Babur found in northern India?
The Mughal dynasty ruled most of the Indian subcontinent by 1600	By what date did the Mughal dynasty rule most of India?
The Mughals suffered several blows due to invasions from Marathas and Afghans	What groups invaded and damaged the Mughals?
The Mughals were perhaps the richest single dynasty to have ever existed	What was the richest of all the dynasties?
The post-Mughal era was dominated by the rise of the Maratha suzerainty as other small regional states emerged, and also by the increasing activities of European powers	The rise of what dynasty followed the era of the Mughals?
By the early 18th century, the Maratha Kingdom had transformed itself into the Maratha Empire under the rule of the Peshwas 	By when had the Maratha kingdom become an empire?
The Punjabi kingdom, ruled by members of the Sikh religion, was a political entity that governed the region of modern-day Punjab	Followers what religion were the rulers of the Punjabi Kingdom?
However, most of them were bound to pay regular tribute to the Marathas	To what Kingdom did many small kingdoms pay tribute?

As a result of the three Carnatic Wars, the British East India Company gained exclusive control over the entire Carnatic region of India	What whole region did the East India company get control over after the Carnatic Wars?
The Indian rebellion of 1857 was a large-scale rebellion by soldiers employed by the British East India in northern and central India against the Company's rule	What did the soldiers rebel against in the Indian Rebellion of 1857?
In the aftermath, all power was transferred from the East India Company to the British Crown, which began to administer most of India as a number of provinces	To what entity was all the power of the East India Company transferred?
After 1857, the colonial government strengthened and expanded its infrastructure via the court system, legal procedures, and statutes	What did the Colonial government expand by legal means?
"In 1905, Lord Curzon split the large province of Bengal into a largely Hindu western half and ""Eastern Bengal and Assam"", a largely Muslim eastern half"	What administer divided the province of Bengal in half?
The Bengali Renaissance refers to a social reform movement during the nineteenth and early twentieth centuries in the Bengal region of India during the period of British rule dominated by English educated Bengali Hindus	What was the social reform movement centered in Bengal in the 19th to early 20th century?
During this period, Bengal witnessed an intellectual awakening that is in some way similar to the Renaissance in Europe during the 16th century, although Europeans of that age were not confronted with the challenge and influence of alien colonialism	What did the Bengali Renaissance resemble?
During the British Raj, famines in India, often attributed to failed government policies, were some of the worst ever recorded, including the Great Famine of 1876–78 in which 6	What were said to have been caused by government policy failures?

The first step toward Indian self-rule was the appointment of councillors to advise the British viceroy in 1861 and the first Indian was appointed in 1909	What appointments were the first step in Indian self-rule?

From 1920 leaders such as Mahatma Gandhi began highly popular mass movements to campaign against the British Raj using largely peaceful methods	What leader started a mass movement against British rule?
The Muslims had always been a minority within the subcontinent, and the prospect of an exclusively Hindu government made them wary of independence; they were as inclined to mistrust Hindu rule as they were to resist the foreign Raj, although Gandhi called for unity between the two groups in an astonishing display of leadership	What position did Muslims have in the Indian population?
Gamal Abdel Nasser Hussein ; 15 January 1918 – 28 September 1970) was the second President of Egypt, serving from 1956 until his death	What number president of Egypt was Nasser?
His funeral in Cairo drew five million mourners and an outpouring of grief across the Arab world	How many mourners attended Nasser's funeral?
His presidency also encouraged and coincided with an Egyptian cultural boom, and launched large industrial projects, including the Aswan Dam and Helwan City	Name two infrastructure projects Nasser spearheaded.
Nasser's father was a postal worker born in Beni Mur in Upper Egypt and raised in Alexandria, and his mother's family came from Mallawi, el-Minya	What was Nasser's father's occupation?
In 1928, Nasser went to Alexandria to live with his maternal grandfather and attend the city's Attarin elementary school	What elementary school did Nasser attend?
When his father was transferred to Cairo in 1933, Nasser joined him and attended al-Nahda al-Masria school	What school did Nasser attend in Cairo?
Nasser's involvement in political activity increased throughout his school years, such that he only attended 45 days of classes during his last year of secondary school	How many days did Nasser attend classes in his senior year?
Nasser spent most of his spare time reading, particularly in 1933 when he lived near the National Library of Egypt	What did Nasser do in his spare time?
Nasser was greatly influenced by Egyptian nationalism, as espoused by politician Mustafa Kamel, poet Ahmed Shawqi, and his anti-colonialist instructor at the Royal Military Academy, Aziz al-Masri, to whom Nasser expressed his gratitude in a 1961 newspaper interview	What political theory fascinated Nasser?
"From his readings, Nasser, who frequently spoke of ""dignity, glory, and freedom"" in his youth, became enchanted with the stories of national liberators and heroic conquerors; a military career became his chief priority"	What was Nasser's goal?
Convinced that he needed a wasta, or an influential intermediary to promote his application above the others, Nasser managed to secure a meeting with Under-Secretary of War Ibrahim Khairy Pasha, the person responsible for the academy's selection board, and requested his help	What's another term for influential intermediary?
In 1941, Nasser was posted to Khartoum, Sudan, which was part of Egypt at the time	In what year was Nasser posted to Sudan?
In May 1948, following the British withdrawal, King Farouk sent the Egyptian army into Palestine, with Nasser serving in the 6th Infantry Battalion	Where was the Egyptian army sent in 1948?
The Egyptian singer Umm Kulthum hosted a public celebration for the officers' return despite reservations from the royal government, which had been pressured by the British to prevent the reception	What Egyptian singer performed at the return of Nasser's brigade?
After the war, Nasser returned to his role as an instructor at the Royal Military Academy	What did Nasser do after the war ended?
Nasser's return to Egypt coincided with Husni al-Za'im's Syrian coup d'état	What people had a coup around the time Nasser returned to Egypt?
In the 1950 parliamentary elections, the Wafd Party of el-Nahhas gained a victory—mostly due to the absence of the Muslim Brotherhood, which boycotted the elections—and was perceived as a threat by the Free Officers as the Wafd had campaigned on demands similar to their own	What group boycotted the 1950 elections?
On 11 October 1951, the Wafd government abrogated the 1936 Anglo-Egyptian Treaty, which had given the British control over the Suez Canal until 1956	What treaty did the Wafd government abrogate?
Sirri Amer was close to King Farouk, and was nominated for the presidency of the Officer's Club—normally a ceremonial office—with the king's backing	Who was nominated to the presidency of the Officer's Club?
On 25 January 1952, a confrontation between British forces and police at Ismailia resulted in the deaths of 40 Egyptian policemen, provoking riots in Cairo the next day which left 76 people dead	In what year did riots cause the political situation in Egypt to rapidly deteriorate? 
The Free Officers' intention was not to install themselves in government, but to re-establish a parliamentary democracy	What type of government did the Free Officer's want to establish?
On 18 June 1953, the monarchy was abolished and the Republic of Egypt declared, with Naguib as its first president	Who was the first president of the Republic of Egypt?
Preceding the reform law, in August 1952, communist-led riots broke out at textile factories in Kafr el-Dawwar, leading to a clash with the army that left nine people dead	What group rioted at the textile factories?
In January 1953, Nasser overcame opposition from Naguib and banned all political parties, creating a one-party system under the Liberation Rally, a loosely structured movement whose chief task was to organize pro-RCC rallies and lectures, with Nasser its secretary-general	What was Nasser's first title in the Liberation Rally?
On 25 February 1954, Naguib announced his resignation after the RCC held an official meeting without his presence two days prior	Who resigned in 1954?
The RCC succeeded in provoking the beneficiaries of the revolution, namely the workers, peasants, and petty bourgeois, to oppose the decrees, with one million transport workers launching a strike and thousands of peasants entering Cairo in protest in late March	What group went on strike as a result of the turmoil?
The assassination attempt backfired, quickly playing into Nasser's hands	What event did Nasser exploit to his advantage?
Nasser's street following was still too small to sustain his plans for reform and to secure him in office	What was too small to keep Nasser in power?
"Nasser made secret contacts with Israel in 1954–55, but determined that peace with Israel would be impossible, considering it an ""expansionist state that viewed the Arabs with disdain"""	What country did Nasser make secret agreements with?
Simultaneous with Israel's February raid, the Baghdad Pact was formed between some regional allies of the UK	What agreement ran contrary to Nasser's efforts?
"Nasser mediated discussions between the pro-Western, pro-Soviet, and neutralist conference factions over the composition of the ""Final Communique"" addressing colonialism in Africa and Asia and the fostering of global peace amid the Cold War between the West and the Soviet Union"	What document was meant to resolve lingering issues of colonialism?
"Following Bandung, Nasser officially adopted the ""positive neutralism"" of Yugoslavian president Josip Broz Tito and Indian Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru as a principal theme of Egyptian foreign policy regarding the Cold War"	What political philosophy did Nasser adopt?
"In January 1956, the new Constitution of Egypt was drafted, entailing the establishment of a single-party system under the National Union , a movement Nasser described as the ""cadre through which we will realize our revolution"""	In what year did Egypt get a new constitution?
Nasser's nomination for the post and the new constitution were put to public referendum on 23 June and each was approved by an overwhelming majority	Who could approve or reject candidates for the National Assembly?
After the three-year transition period ended with Nasser's official assumption of power, his domestic and independent foreign policies increasingly collided with the regional interests of the UK and France	With what two nations did Nasser's foreign policy clash?
Nasser was informed of the British–American withdrawal via a news statement while aboard a plane returning to Cairo from Belgrade, and took great offense	How did Nasser react to the news the the US and UK had blocked construction of th Aswan Dam?
On 26 July 1956, Nasser gave a speech in Alexandria announcing the nationalization of the Suez Canal Company as a means to fund the Aswan Dam project in light of the British–American withdrawal	What did Nasser propose to do with funds from the nationalized Suez Canal?
The nationalization announcement was greeted very emotionally by the audience and, throughout the Arab world, thousands entered the streets shouting slogans of support	How did the Arab world react to news of the nationalization of the Suez Canal?
France and the UK, the largest shareholders in the Suez Canal Company, saw its nationalization as yet another hostile measure aimed at them by the Egyptian government	What nations were outraged by the nationalization scheme?
On 29 October 1956, Israeli forces crossed the Sinai Peninsula, overwhelmed Egyptian army posts, and quickly advanced to their objectives	In what year did battle over the Suez Canal commence?
Despite the commanded withdrawal of Egyptian troops, about 2,000 Egyptian soldiers were killed during engagement with Israeli forces, and some 5,000 Egyptian soldiers were captured by the Israeli Army	How many Egyptian soldiers died during the fighting?
Between 750 and 1,000 Egyptians were killed in the battle for Port Said	How many Egyptians died in the battle for Port Said?
Eisenhower administration condemned the tripartite invasion, and supported UN resolutions demanding withdrawal and a United Nations Emergency Force to be stationed in Sinai	What leader did Nasser applaud?
"The Cairo-based Voice of the Arabs radio station spread Nasser's ideas of united Arab action throughout the Arabic-speaking world and historian Eugene Rogan wrote, ""Nasser conquered the Arab world by radio"	What radio station furthered Nasser's agenda?
In January 1957, the US adopted the Eisenhower Doctrine and pledged to prevent the spread of communism and its perceived agents in the Middle East	What was the policy meant to contain communism in the middle east?
Relations between Nasser and King Hussein deteriorated in April when Hussein implicated Nasser in two coup attempts against him—although Nasser's involvement was never established—and dissolved al-Nabulsi's cabinet	What leader accused Nasser of trying to overthrow him?
By the end of 1957, Nasser nationalized all remaining British and French assets in Egypt, including the tobacco, cement, pharmaceutical, and phosphate industries	What nations' assets did Nasser nationalize in 1957?
As political instability grew in Syria, delegations from the country were sent to Nasser demanding immediate unification with Egypt	What country wanted to join with Egypt?
While Nasser was in Syria, King Saud planned to have him assassinated on his return flight to Cairo	Who tried to assassinate Nasser?
A day after announcing the attempt on his life, Nasser established a new provisional constitution proclaiming a 600-member National Assembly and the dissolution of all political parties	How many members were in the National Assembly?
In Lebanon, clashes between pro-Nasser factions and supporters of staunch Nasser opponent, then-President Camille Chamoun, culminated in civil strife by May	Who was Nasser's opponent in Lebanon?
On 14 July, Iraqi army officers Abdel Karim Qasim and Abdel Salam Aref overthrew the Iraqi monarchy and, the next day, Iraqi prime minister and Nasser's chief Arab antagonist, Nuri al-Said, was killed	What two men overthrew the Iraqi monarchy?
He put Syria under Sarraj, who effectively reduced the province to a police state by imprisoning and exiling landholders who objected to the introduction of Egyptian agricultural reform in Syria, as well as communists	Who did Nasser appoint to run Syria?
Relations between Nasser and Qasim grew increasingly bitter on 9 March, after Qasim's forces suppressed a rebellion in Mosul, launched a day earlier by a pro-Nasser Iraqi RCC officer backed by UAR authorities	What Iraqi leader clashed with Nasser?
Opposition to the union mounted among some of Syria's key elements, namely the socioeconomic, political, and military elites	What Syrian social group opposed the UAR?
On 28 September 1961, secessionist army units launched a coup in Damascus, declaring Syria's secession from the UAR	What Syrian anti-Nasser group lauched a coup?
Nasser's regional position changed unexpectedly when Yemeni officers led by Nasser supporter Abdullah al-Sallal overthrew Imam Badr of North Yemen on 27 September 1962	What country experienced a coup in 1962?
On 8 February 1963, a military coup in Iraq led by a Ba'athist–Nasserist alliance toppled Qasim, who was subsequently shot dead	What groups completed a coup in Iraq?
In January 1964, Nasser called for an Arab League summit in Cairo to establish a unified Arab response against Israel's plans to divert the Jordan River's waters for economic purposes, which Syria and Jordan deemed an act of war	What river did the Israelis want to divert?

Nasser played a significant part in the strengthening of African solidarity in the late 1950s and early 1960s, although his continental leadership role had increasingly passed to Algeria since 1962	What continent did Nasser help to attain political stability?
In 1961, Nasser sought to firmly establish Egypt as the leader of the Arab world and to promote a second revolution in Egypt with the purpose of merging Islamic and socialist thinking	What country did Nasser want to be the leader of the Arab world?
In late 1961, Nasser established the Presidential Council and decreed it the authority to approve all senior military appointments, instead of leaving this responsibility solely to Amer	What military entity did Nasser create in 1961?
In early 1962 Nasser again attempted to wrest control of the military command from Amer	From whom did Nasser want to seize control of Egypt's military?
In October 1961, Nasser embarked on a major nationalization program for Egypt, believing the total adoption of socialism was the answer to his country's problems and would have prevented Syria's secession	What political ideology did Nasser wholeheartedly back in 1961?
As a result of the 1962 measures, government ownership of Egyptian business reached 51 percent, and the National Union was renamed the Arab Socialist Union 	What percentage of business did the Egyptian government own in 1962?
He was the only candidate for the position, with virtually all of his political opponents forbidden by law from running for office, and his fellow party members reduced to mere followers	What was Nasser's political opposition like in the 1965 election?

The Roman Catholic Church celebrates his feast day not on the date of his death, June 3, as is usual, nor even on the day of his papal inauguration but on 11 October, the day of the first session of the Second Vatican Council	When is his feast day celebrated?

Temporal measurement, chronometry, takes two distinct period forms: the calendar, a mathematical tool for organizing intervals of time, and the clock, a physical mechanism that counts the passage of time	What is a mathematical tool used for organizing intervals of time?
Artifacts from the Paleolithic suggest that the moon was used to reckon time as early as 6,000 years ago	Artifacts from which era suggest that the moon was used to reckon time around 6,000 years ago?
The most precise timekeeping device of the ancient world was the water clock, or clepsydra, one of which was found in the tomb of Egyptian pharaoh Amenhotep I 	What was the most accurate clock-like device in the ancient world?
The hourglass uses the flow of sand to measure the flow of time	Which device uses the flow of sand to measure time?
The most accurate timekeeping devices are atomic clocks, which are accurate to seconds in many millions of years, and are used to calibrate other clocks and timekeeping instruments	Which timekeeping devices are the most accurate?

John von Neumann ; December 28, 1903 – February 8, 1957) was a Hungarian-American pure and applied mathematician, physicist, inventor, computer scientist, and polymath	What was the birth date of John Von Neumann?
He published 150 papers in his life; 60 in pure mathematics, 20 in physics, and 60 in applied mathematics	How many papers did Von Neumann publish?
Von Neumann's mathematical analysis of the structure of self-replication preceded the discovery of the structure of DNA	Von Neumann's study of what preceded the discovery of DNA?
After the war, he served on the General Advisory Committee of the United States Atomic Energy Commission, and later as one of its commissioners	Post World War II, in what role did Von Neumann work?
Von Neumann was born Neumann János Lajos , Hebrew name Yonah, in Budapest, Kingdom of Hungary, which was then part of the Austro-Hungarian Empire, to wealthy Jewish parents of the Haskalah	Where was Von Neumann born?
In 1913, his father was elevated to the nobility for his service to the Austro-Hungarian Empire by Emperor Franz Joseph	In what year was Von Neumann's father elevated to nobility?
Formal schooling did not start in Hungary until the age of ten	At what age did schooling begin in Hungary?
Von Neumann entered the Lutheran Fasori Evangelikus Gimnázium in 1911	What did Von Neumann enter in 1911?
At the age of 15, he began to study advanced calculus under the renowned analyst Gábor Szegő	At what age did Von Neumann begin to study advance calculus?
So it was decided that the best career path was to become a chemical engineer	What career path was decided upon for Von Neuman?
Von Neumann's habilitation was completed on December 13, 1927, and he started his lectures as a privatdozent at the University of Berlin in 1928	Where did Von Neumann begin to lecture in 1928?
On New Year's Day in 1930, von Neumann married Mariette Kövesi, who had studied economics at the Budapest University	When did Von Neumann get married?
In 1933, von Neumann was offered a lifetime professorship on the faculty of the Institute for Advanced Study when the institute's plan to appoint Hermann Weyl fell through	In what year was Von Neumann offered a lifetime professorship?

At the beginning of the 20th century, efforts to base mathematics on naive set theory suffered a setback due to Russell's paradox 	What caused a setback in naive set theory at the beginning of 20th century?
To demonstrate that the addition of this new axiom to the others did not produce contradictions, von Neumann introduced a method of demonstration, called the method of inner models, which later became an essential instrument in set theory	What is the method to demonstrate that no contradictions were created by the addition of axiom of foundation?
The second approach to the problem took as its base the notion of class, and defines a set as a class which belongs to other classes, while a proper class is defined as a class which does not belong to other classes	What is a proper class?
A strongly negative answer arrived in September 1930 at the historic mathematical Congress of Königsberg, in which Kurt Gödel announced his first theorem of incompleteness: the usual axiomatic systems are incomplete, in the sense that they cannot prove every truth which is expressible in their language	In 1930 who gave a strongly negative answer to Von Neuman's approach to the axiomatic system of theory of sets?
But von Neumann, who had participated at the Congress, confirmed his fame as an instantaneous thinker, and in less than a month was able to communicate to Gödel himself an interesting consequence of his theorem: namely that the usual axiomatic systems are unable to demonstrate their own consistency	How long did it take von Neumann to figure a response to theory of incompleteness?
Von Neumann was motivated by his discovery of von Neumann algebras with a dimension function taking a continuous range of dimensions, and the first example of a continuous geometry other than projective space was the projections of the hyperfinite type II factor	What was the first example of continuous geometry?
In a series of famous papers, von Neumann made spectacular contributions to measure theory	In what way did von Neumann make spectacular contributions to measure theory?
In a number of von Neumann's papers, the methods of argument he employed are considered even more significant than the results	What is often considered more important than the results of von Neumann's papers?
A von Neumann algebra is a *-algebra of bounded operators on a Hilbert space that is closed in the weak operator topology and contains the identity operator	What is von Neumann algebra?
Von Neumann worked on lattice theory between 1937 and 1939	What did von Neumann work on in 1937 - 39?
This conclusion is the culmination of 140 pages of brilliant and incisive algebra involving entirely novel axioms	What type of axioms were used by von Neumann in his lattice work?
Von Neumann was the first to establish a rigorous mathematical framework for quantum mechanics, known as the Dirac–von Neumann axioms, with his 1932 work Mathematical Foundations of Quantum Mechanics	Who established the framework for quantum mechanics?
The physics of quantum mechanics was thereby reduced to the mathematics of Hilbert spaces and linear operators acting on them	What are the physics of quantum mechanics?
"Von Neumann's abstract treatment permitted him also to confront the foundational issue of determinism versus non-determinism, and in the book he presented a proof that the statistical results of quantum mechanics could not possibly be averages of an underlying set of determined ""hidden variables,"" as in classical statistical mechanics"	Von Neumann's abstract treatment allowed him to work on what foundational issue?
He concluded that the entire physical universe could be made subject to the universal wave function	What results came from von Neumann's deep analysis of the measurement problem?
In a famous paper of 1936 with Garrett Birkhoff, the first work ever to introduce quantum logics, von Neumann and Birkhoff first proved that quantum mechanics requires a propositional calculus substantially different from all classical logics and rigorously isolated a new algebraic structure for quantum logics	With whom did von Neuman work on a paper in 1936 that introduce quantum logic?
Von Neumann proved his minimax theorem in 1928	What year was game theory established?
The reason for this is that a quantum disjunction, unlike the case for classical disjunction, can be true even when both of the disjuncts are false and this is, in turn, attributable to the fact that it is frequently the case, in quantum mechanics, that a pair of alternatives are semantically determinate, while each of its members are necessarily indeterminate	What is the difference of quantum disjunction from classic?
Such strategies, which minimize the maximum loss for each player, are called optimal	What is optimal strategy?
Von Neumann raised the intellectual and mathematical level of economics in several stunning publications	How did von Neumann raise the level of economics?
"In this model, the probability vector p represents the prices of the goods while the probability vector q represents the ""intensity"" at which the production process would run"	In von Neumann's model what does p represent?
Von Neumann's results have been viewed as a special case of linear programming, where von Neumann's model uses only nonnegative matrices	What were von Neumann's model an example of?
His interest in economics that led to that paper began as follows: When lecturing at Berlin in 1928 and 1929 he spent his summers back home in Budapest, and so did the economist Nicholas Kaldor, and they hit it off	When did von Neumann's interest in economics begin?
Later, von Neumann suggested a new method of linear programming, using the homogeneous linear system of Gordan , which was later popularized by Karmarkar's algorithm	What was the new method of linear programming that von Neumann suggested?
In 1941, he derived the exact distribution of the ratio of the mean square of successive differences to the sample variance for independent and identically normally distributed variables	When did von NEumann establish mean square ratio?
Von Neumann made fundamental contributions in exploration of problems in numerical hydrodynamics	The algorithm defining artificial viscosity is a fundamental contribution to what area?
Von Neumann's principal contribution to the atomic bomb was in the concept and design of the explosive lenses needed to compress the plutonium core of the Fat Man weapon that was later dropped on Nagasaki	What principal contribution did von Neumann make to atomic bomb?
When it turned out that there would not be enough uranium-235 to make more than one bomb, the implosive lens project was greatly expanded and von Neumann's idea was implemented	what change was made when shortage of uranium 235 was apparent?
Along with four other scientists and various military personnel, von Neumann was included in the target selection committee responsible for choosing the Japanese cities of Hiroshima and Nagasaki as the first targets of the atomic bomb	What other people worked with von Neumann on target selection?
On July 16, 1945, with numerous other Manhattan Project personnel, von Neumann was an eyewitness to the first atomic bomb blast, code named Trinity, conducted as a test of the implosion method device, at the bombing range near Alamogordo Army Airfield, 35 miles southeast of Socorro, New Mexico	On what day was the first atomic blast?
"He then collaborated with Klaus Fuchs on further development of the bomb, and in 1946 the two filed a secret patent on ""Improvement in Methods and Means for Utilizing Nuclear Energy"", which outlined a scheme for using a fission bomb to compress fusion fuel to initiate nuclear fusion"	With whom did von Neumann collaborate for further development of the hydrogen bomb?
In 1950, von Neumann became a consultant to the Weapons Systems Evaluation Group , whose function was to advise the Joint Chiefs of Staff and the United States Secretary of Defense on the development and use of new technologies	In 1950 von Neumann became a consultant for what organization?
In 1955, von Neumann became a commissioner of the AEC	In what year did von Neumann become commissioner of the AEC?
Its purpose was to decide on the feasibility of building an ICBM large enough to carry a thermonuclear weapon	What was the purpose of top secret ICBM committee?
Von Neumann is credited with the equilibrium strategy of mutual assured destruction, providing the deliberately humorous acronym, MAD	What was MAD?
Von Neumann entered government service primarily because he felt that, if freedom and civilization were to survive, it would have to be because the US would triumph over totalitarianism from Nazism, Fascism and Soviet Communism	Why did von Neumann join government work?
Von Neumann was a founding figure in computing	Who was the inventor of the merge-sort algorithm?
Von Neumann's hydrogen bomb work was played out in the realm of computing, where he and Stanislaw Ulam developed simulations on von Neumann's digital computers for the hydrodynamic computations	Where were the computations for hydrogen bomb worked out?
While consulting for the Moore School of Electrical Engineering at the University of Pennsylvania on the EDVAC project, von Neumann wrote an incomplete First Draft of a Report on the EDVAC	What nullified patent claims of EDVAC designers?
The electronics of the new ENIAC ran at one-sixth the speed, but this in no way degraded the ENIAC's performance, since it was still entirely I/O bound	What was the speed difference with new ENIAC?
Stochastic computing was first introduced in a pioneering paper by von Neumann in 1953	When was stochastic computing introduced?
Von Neumann's team performed the world's first numerical weather forecasts on the ENIAC computer; von Neumann published the paper Numerical Integration of the Barotropic Vorticity Equation in 1950	On what computer was the first numerical weather forecast produced?
Von Neumann's ability to instantaneously perform complex operations in his head stunned other mathematicians	How quickly was von Neumann able to complete math in his head?
"Lothar Wolfgang Nordheim described von Neumann as the ""fastest mind I ever met"", and Jacob Bronowski wrote ""He was the cleverest man I ever knew, without exception"	How did Lothar Wolfgang Nordheim describe von Neumann? 
"""I have sometimes wondered whether a brain like von Neumann's does not indicate a species superior to that of man"", said Nobel Laureate Hans Bethe of Cornell University"	What did Nobel Laureate Hans Bethe think of von NEumann's ability?

In the United Kingdom, for instance, the sovereign may appear personally in the House of Lords or may appoint Lords Commissioners, who announce that royal assent has been granted at a ceremony held at the Palace of Westminster	When royal assent takes place in the UK, where does the sovereign make an appearance?
Royal assent is the method by which a country's constitutional monarch formally approves an act of that nation's parliament, thus making it a law or letting it be promulgated as law	Royal assent is a process of approving a nation's legislative acts by whom?
Under modern constitutional conventions, the sovereign acts on the advice of his or her ministers	Modern-day sovereigns often acts on the advice of whom?
Originally, legislative power was exercised by the sovereign acting on the advice of the Curia Regis, or Royal Council, in which important magnates and clerics participated and which evolved into parliament	"What is another name for ""Curia Regis""?"
Charles I dissolved parliament in 1629, after it passed motions critical of and bills seeking to restrict his arbitrary exercise of power	Which monarch was responsible for dissolving parliament in 1629?
During the rule of the succeeding Hanoverian dynasty, power was gradually exercised more by parliament and the government	During whose rule was power transferred more to parliament?
After a bill has been passed, the Presiding Officer of the Scottish Parliament submits it to the monarch for royal assent after a four-week period, during which the Advocate General for Scotland, the Lord Advocate, the Attorney General or the Secretary of State for Scotland may refer the bill to the Supreme Court of the United Kingdom for review of its legality	In Scotland, who is responsible for submitting a bill for royal assent?

Instead, the monarch directly grants royal assent by Order in Council	The sovereign grants assent by which order?

While royal assent has not been withheld in the United Kingdom since 1708, it has often been withheld in British colonies and former colonies by governors acting on royal instructions	Which year was royal assent last withheld in the UK?

Special procedures apply to legislation passed by Tynwald, the legislature of the Isle of Man	What term refers to the legislature of the Isle of man?
In Commonwealth realms other than the UK, royal assent is granted or withheld either by the realm's sovereign or, more frequently, by the representative of the sovereign, the governor-general	In Commonwealth realms, who is the representative of the sovereign?
Since the Balfour Declaration of 1926 and the Statute of Westminster 1931, the all Commonwealth realms have been sovereign kingdoms, the monarch and governors-general acting solely on the advice of the local ministers who generally maintain the support of the legislature and are the ones who secure the passage of bills	What two documents declared all Commonwealth realms as sovereign kingdoms?
In the United Kingdom, a bill is presented for royal assent after it has passed all the required stages in both the House of Commons and the House of Lords	Which Houses in the UK must approve a bill before it is assented?
The Clerk of the Parliaments, an official of the House of Lords, traditionally states a formula in Anglo-Norman Law French, indicating the sovereign's decision	In what language does the Clerk of the Parliaments announce Parliament's decision?
The Clerk of the Crown, standing on the sovereign's right, then read aloud the titles of the bills 	When assention was formally granted in person, who read the titles of the bills?
In 1542, Henry sought to execute his fifth wife, Catherine Howard, whom he accused of committing adultery; the execution was to be authorised not after a trial but by a bill of attainder, to which he would have to personally assent after listening to the entire text	Why did Henry VIII wish to execute his fifth wife?
When granting assent by commission, the sovereign authorises three or more lords who are Privy Counsellors to grant assent in his or her name	How many lords are usually present during assent by Commissioner?
During the 1960s, the ceremony of assenting by commission was discontinued and is now only employed once a year, at the end of the annual parliamentary session	During which decade was assention by commission discontinued?
Thus, unlike the granting of royal assent by the monarch in person or by Royal Commissioners, the method created by the Royal Assent Act 1967 does not require both houses to meet jointly for the purpose of receiving the notice of royal assent	What is unique about the method used for assention allowed by the Royal Assent Act 1967?
When the act is assented to by the sovereign in person, or by empowered Royal Commissioners, royal assent is considered given at the moment when the assent is declared in the presence of both houses jointly assembled	When assent is granted in person, when is it formally considered final?
Independently of the method used to signify royal assent, it is the responsibility of the Clerk of the Parliaments, once the assent has been duly notified to both houses, not only to endorse the act in the name of the monarch with the formal Norman French formula, but to certify that assent has been granted	Whose responsibility is it to assure that assent has been granted?
A similar practice is followed in New Zealand, where the governor-general has not personally granted the Royal Assent in parliament since 1875	In what year did the New Zealand governor-general last personally grant the royal assent in parliament?
In Canada, the traditional ceremony for granting assent in parliament was regularly used until the 21st century, long after it had been discontinued in the United Kingdom and other Commonwealth realms	When did Canada finally cease to use the traditional ceremony for granting assent as regular practice?
The Royal Assent ceremony takes place in the Senate, as the sovereign is traditionally barred from the House of Commons	From where is the sovereign typically forbidden?
In Belgium, the sanction royale has the same legal effect as royal assent; the Belgian constitution requires a theoretically possible refusal of royal sanction to be countersigned—as any other act of the monarch—by a minister responsible before the House of Representatives	What is royal assent called in Belgium?

In mathematics, a group is an algebraic structure consisting of a set of elements equipped with an operation that combines any two elements to form a third element	What is an arithmetical structure comprising of a set of elements including an operation that joins any two elements to form a third element?
Groups share a fundamental kinship with the notion of symmetry	What shares an essential relationship to groups?
The concept of a group arose from the study of polynomial equations, starting with Évariste Galois in the 1830s	Where did the idea of a group come from?
The set G is called the underlying set of the group 	What is known as underlying set of the group?
These symmetries are represented by functions	What sends a point in the square to the relating point under the symmetry? 
The modern concept of an abstract group developed out of several fields of mathematics	What modern concept was created from many fields of mathematics?
The convergence of these various sources into a uniform theory of groups started with Camille Jordan's Traité des substitutions et des équations algébriques 	When did the uniform theory of groups develop from different sources? 
The University of Chicago's 1960–61 Group Theory Year brought together group theorists such as Daniel Gorenstein, John G	Where did the group of theorists first meet?
To understand groups beyond the level of mere symbolic manipulations as above, more structural concepts have to be employed	What ideas are used to understand groups beyond symbols?
Two groups G and H are called isomorphic if there exist group homomorphisms a: G → H and b: H → G, such that applying the two functions one after another in each of the two possible orders gives the identity functions of G and H	What are two groups called if they include homomorphisms?
In the example above, the identity and the rotations constitute a subgroup R = {id, r1, r2, r3}, highlighted in red in the group table above: any two rotations composed are still a rotation, and a rotation can be undone by (i	What is composed of two rotations?
the rotation operations are irrelevant to the question whether a reflection has been performed	When is it preferable to consider two group elements to be the same?
This set inherits a group operation from the original group G: • = N for all g and h in G	What is another term for coset multiplication?
Quotient groups and subgroups together form a way of describing every group by its presentation: any group is the quotient of the free group over the generators of the group, quotiented by the subgroup of relations	What groups can be combined to describe every group?
Sub- and quotient groups are related in the following way: a subset H of G can be seen as an injective map H → G, i	What map shows the relation between sub and quotient groups?
Mathematical objects are often examined by associating groups to them and studying the properties of the corresponding groups	What are usually analyzed by associating groups to them and studying the elements of the corresponding groups?
In modular arithmetic, two integers are added and then the sum is divided by a positive integer called the modulus	What positive integer is used to divide the sum of two positive integers in modular mathematics?
For any prime number p, there is also the multiplicative group of integers modulo p	What term describes the group of integers related to a prime number?
p	What is the result of modular multiplication divided by?
In the groups Z/nZ introduced above, the element 1 is primitive, so these groups are cyclic	What is a group labeled when the element 1 is primitive?
1	What element is not primitive in groups Z/nZ?
Symmetry groups are groups consisting of symmetries of given mathematical objects—be they of geometric nature, such as the introductory symmetry group of the square, or of algebraic nature, such as polynomial equations and their solutions	What are groups consisting of symmetries of given arithmetic concepts?
Likewise, group theory helps predict the changes in physical properties that occur when a material undergoes a phase transition, for example, from a cubic to a tetrahedral crystalline form	What aids in predicting changes of physical traits?
Finite symmetry groups such as the Mathieu groups are used in coding theory, which is in turn applied in error correction of transmitted data, and in CD players	What are examples of finite symmetry groups used in coding theory?
Matrix groups consist of matrices together with matrix multiplication	What groups combine matrices with matrix multiplication?
Similar formulae are known for cubic and quartic equations, but do not exist in general for degree 5 and higher	What degree does not include simple formulas for cubic and quatric equations?
A group is called finite if it has a finite number of elements	What does a finite group include?
Mathematicians often strive for a complete classification of a mathematical notion	What level of finality do mathematicians try to reach with math concepts? 
In order for the group law and the topology to interweave well, the group operations must be continuous functions, that is, g • h, and g−1 must not vary wildly if g and h vary only little	What group operations must occur for group law and topology to integrate well?
Matrix groups over these fields fall under this regime, as do adele rings and adelic algebraic groups, which are basic to number theory	What concepts are fundamental to number theory?
Lie groups are of fundamental importance in modern physics: Noether's theorem links continuous symmetries to conserved quantities	What concept is of basic importance in modern physics?
For example, if the requirement that every element has an inverse is eliminated, the resulting algebraic structure is called a monoid	What product is created if the requirement that every element has an inverse is eliminated?

The Central African Republic , or Centrafrique ) is a landlocked country in Central Africa	Where is the Central African Republic located?
What is today the Central African Republic has been inhabited for millennia; however, the country's current borders were established by France, which ruled the country as a colony starting in the late 19th century	Who established CAR's borders?
Approximately 10,000 years ago, desertification forced hunter-gatherer societies south into the Sahel regions of northern Central Africa, where some groups settled and began farming as part of the Neolithic Revolution	How long ago did people start living in the area?
During the 16th and 17th centuries slave traders began to raid the region as part of the expansion of the Saharan and Nile River slave routes	When did the slave trade hit the CAR region?
In 1920 French Equatorial Africa was established and Ubangi-Shari was administered from Brazzaville	When was Equatorial Africa established?
In September 1940, during the Second World War, pro-Gaullist French officers took control of Ubangi-Shari and General Leclerc established his headquarters for the Free French Forces in Bangui	During what war did French officers setup headquarters in CAR?
In the Ubangi-Shari Territorial Assembly election in 1957, MESAN captured 347,000 out of the total 356,000 votes, and won every legislative seat, which led to Boganda being elected president of the Grand Council of French Equatorial Africa and vice-president of the Ubangi-Shari Government Council	What was the overwhelming amount of votes MESAN captured?
In April 1979, young students protested against Bokassa's decree that all school attendees would need to buy uniforms from a company owned by one of his wives	What caused a violent uprising?
By 1990, inspired by the fall of the Berlin Wall, a pro-democracy movement arose	What was inspired by the fall of the Berlin wall?
When a second round of elections were finally held in 1993, again with the help of the international community coordinated by GIBAFOR, Ange-Félix Patassé won in the second round of voting with 53% of the vote while Goumba won 45	When was a second democratic election held?
A new constitution was approved on 28 December 1994 but had little impact on the country's politics	When was the new constitution for CAR approved?
In the aftermath of the failed coup, militias loyal to Patassé sought revenge against rebels in many neighborhoods of Bangui and incited unrest including the murder of many political opponents	The failed coup caused what effects?
In 2004 the Central African Republic Bush War began as forces opposed to Bozizé took up arms against his government	What war started in 2004?
The Syrte Agreement in February and the Birao Peace Agreement in April 2007 called for a cessation of hostilities, the billeting of FDPC fighters and their integration with FACA, the liberation of political prisoners, integration of FDPC into government, an amnesty for the UFDR, its recognition as a political party, and the integration of its fighters into the national army	What agreement called for the stop of Hostilities?

Asthma is thought to be caused by a combination of genetic and environmental factors	What two factors cause asthma?
There is no cure for asthma	Is there a cure for asthma?
Asthma is characterized by recurrent episodes of wheezing, shortness of breath, chest tightness, and coughing	What are the characteristics of asthma?
A number of other health conditions occur more frequently in those with asthma, including gastro-esophageal reflux disease , rhinosinusitis, and obstructive sleep apnea	Do other health concerns happen less frequently or more frequently with asthma?
Many environmental factors have been associated with asthma's development and exacerbation including allergens, air pollution, and other environmental chemicals	What are some of the enviromental factors that have been linked to asthma?
The hygiene hypothesis attempts to explain the increased rates of asthma worldwide as a direct and unintended result of reduced exposure, during childhood, to non-pathogenic bacteria and viruses	What hypothesis tries to explain the increased amount of asthma world wide?
Family history is a risk factor for asthma, with many different genes being implicated	What else is a risk factor for asthma?
Asthma is the result of chronic inflammation of the conducting zone of the airways , which subsequently results in increased contractability of the surrounding smooth muscles	What is asthma the result of?
While asthma is a well recognized condition, there is not one universal agreed upon definition	Is there a universal definition of astham?
There is currently no precise test with the diagnosis typically based on the pattern of symptoms and response to therapy over time	Is there a test to determine asthma in an individual?
Spirometry is recommended to aid in diagnosis and management	What is recommended to help in the diagnosis of asthma?
Other supportive evidence includes: a ≥20% difference in peak expiratory flow rate on at least three days in a week for at least two weeks, a ≥20% improvement of peak flow following treatment with either salbutamol, inhaled corticosteroids or prednisone, or a ≥20% decrease in peak flow following exposure to a trigger	What is the rate that is used in most of the evidence?
Asthma may also be classified as atopic or non-atopic , based on whether symptoms are precipitated by allergens or not 	When asthma is caused by allergens that is called what? 
Although asthma is a chronic obstructive condition, it is not considered as a part of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease as this term refers specifically to combinations of disease that are irreversible such as bronchiectasis, chronic bronchitis, and emphysema	What kind of condition is asthma?
Exercise-induced bronchoconstriction is common in professional athletes	Exercise-induced bronchoconstriction is common in what profession?
E	What percentage of cyclists used inhaled beta 2 agonists?
Asthma as a result of workplace exposures, is a commonly reported occupational disease	Asthma that is the result of or made worse by workplace exposure is reported as what?
In children, other upper airway diseases such as allergic rhinitis and sinusitis should be considered as well as other causes of airway obstruction including: foreign body aspiration, tracheal stenosis or laryngotracheomalacia, vascular rings, enlarged lymph nodes or neck masses	What is a condition that can cause symptoms of astham in children?
Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease can coexist with asthma and can occur as a complication of chronic asthma	What is a complication of chronic asthma?
The evidence for the effectiveness of measures to prevent the development of asthma is weak	What is weak that is not helping prevent the development of asthma?
Avoidance of triggers is a key component of improving control and preventing attacks	What is a key component of control and preventing asthma attacks?
For those with severe persistent asthma not controlled by inhaled corticosteroids and LABAs, bronchial thermoplasty may be an option	What type of person would use bronchial thermoplasty as an option?
The prognosis for asthma is generally good, especially for children with mild disease	What is the prognosis for asthma?

Federalism refers to the mixed or compound mode of government, combining a general government with regional governments in a single political system	What is federalism? 
Until recently, in the absence of prior agreement on a clear and precise definition, the concept was thought to mean 'a division of sovereignty between two levels of government'	Before new research, what was the definition of federalism? 
The terms 'federalism' and 'confederalism' both have a root in the Latin word foedus, meaning treaty, pact or covenant	What is the Latin word for federalism? 
Whilst it is often perceived as an optimal solution for states comprising different cultural or ethnic communities, the federalist model seems to work best in largely homogeneous states such as the United States, Germany or Australia, but there is also evidence to the contrary such as in Switzerland	Where does the federalist model work best in?
