In 1981 a team of researchers from the Maison de l'Orient et de la Méditerranée, including Jacques Cauvin and Oliver Aurenche divided Near East neolithic chronology into ten periods based on social, economic and cultural characteristics	What are the names of two researchers who divided neolithic chronology into ten periods?
Domestication of sheep and goats reached Egypt from the Near East possibly as early as 6,000 BC	When did the domestication of sheep first appear in Egypt?
In southeast Europe agrarian societies first appeared in the 7th millennium BC, attested by one of the earliest farming sites of Europe, discovered in Vashtëmi, southeastern Albania and dating back to 6,500 BC	When did agrarian societies start to arise in Southeast Europe?
In 2012, news was released about a new farming site discovered in Munam-ri, Goseong, Gangwon Province, South Korea, which may be the earliest farmland known to date in east Asia	When was the earliest known Asian farm site found in South Korea?
, crop domestication and sedentary lifestyles) occurred by around 4500 BC, but possibly as early as 11,000–10,000 BC	What major trends appeared in Mesoamerica during 4500 BC?
During most of the Neolithic age of Eurasia, people lived in small tribes composed of multiple bands or lineages	What social groups were formed during the Neolithic age of Eurasia?
The domestication of large animals (c	What caused a major increase in social inequality?
Families and households were still largely independent economically, and the household was probably the center of life	What was the cultural aspect was the major center of life?
There is a large body of evidence for fortified settlements at Linearbandkeramik sites along the Rhine, as at least some villages were fortified for some time with a palisade and an outer ditch	Where was evidence of fortified settlements found?
Control of labour and inter-group conflict is characteristic of corporate-level or 'tribal' groups, headed by a charismatic individual; whether a 'big man' or a proto-chief, functioning as a lineage-group head	What production trait existed in tribal groups that were controlled by charismatic leaders?
The shelter of the early people changed dramatically from the paleolithic to the neolithic era	What lifestyle element changed significantly from the paleolithic to the neolithic era?
A significant and far-reaching shift in human subsistence and lifestyle was to be brought about in areas where crop farming and cultivation were first developed: the previous reliance on an essentially nomadic hunter-gatherer subsistence technique or pastoral transhumance was at first supplemented, and then increasingly replaced by, a reliance upon the foods produced from cultivated lands	What trend led to a major shift in the livelihoods of early cultures?
However, early farmers were also adversely affected in times of famine, such as may be caused by drought or pests	What were the causes of famine in early farm towns?
Another significant change undergone by many of these newly agrarian communities was one of diet	What food related trend was significant in the new agrarian societies?
Neolithic people were skilled farmers, manufacturing a range of tools necessary for the tending, harvesting and processing of crops and food production (e	What type of occupation were Neolithic people considered to be proficient at?
Neolithic peoples in the Levant, Anatolia, Syria, northern Mesopotamia and Central Asia were also accomplished builders, utilizing mud-brick to construct houses and villages	What did Neolithic people use mud-brick to build?
Most clothing appears to have been made of animal skins, as indicated by finds of large numbers of bone and antler pins which are ideal for fastening leather	What did early humans use to make clothing?
Friedrich Hayek CH ; 8 May 1899 – 23 March 1992), born in Austria-Hungary as Friedrich August von Hayek and frequently referred to as F	In which nation was Friedrich Hayek born?
"In 1984, he was appointed a member of the Order of the Companions of Honour by Queen Elizabeth II on the advice of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher for his ""services to the study of economics"""	Hayek became a member of which group in 1984?
Friedrich August von Hayek was born in Vienna to August von Hayek and Felicitas Hayek 	Who was Hayek's father?
His father's career as a university professor influenced Friedrich's goals later in life	Who's occupation inspired Hayek when he was older?
On his mother's side, Hayek was second cousin to the philosopher Ludwig Wittgenstein	Who was among the first readers of Ludwig Wittgenstein's book?
In his unpublished autobiographical notes, Hayek recalled a division between him and his younger brothers who were only few years younger than him, but he believed that they were somehow of a different generation	What did Hayek conclude regarding his brothers?
At the University of Vienna, Hayek earned doctorates in law and political science in 1921 and 1923 respectively; and he also studied philosophy, psychology, and economics	Where did Hayek acquire his doctorates?
Between 1923 and 1924 Hayek worked as a research assistant to Prof	What work did Hayek begin in 1923?
Initially sympathetic to Wieser's democratic socialism, Hayek's economic thinking shifted away from socialism and toward the classical liberalism of Carl Menger after reading von Mises' book Socialism	What ideology was Hayek originally in support of?
With the help of Mises, in the late 1920s Hayek founded and served as director of the Austrian Institute for Business Cycle Research, before joining the faculty of the London School of Economics in 1931 at the behest of Lionel Robbins	What position did Hayek gain at the Austrian Institute?
Hayek was concerned about the general view in Britain's academia that fascism was a capitalist reaction to socialism and The Road to Serfdom arose from those concerns	What did Hayek write regarding fascism and socialism?
In 1950, Hayek left the London School of Economics for the University of Chicago, where he became a professor in the Committee on Social Thought	Upon leaving London, for what college did he choose to work?
of Chicago in the 1940s, with Hayek's The Road to Serfdom playing a seminal role in transforming how Milton Friedman and others understood how society works	Which of Hayek's works had a profound influence on those at the University of Chicago?
"After editing a book on John Stuart Mill's letters he planned to publish two books on the liberal order, The Constitution of Liberty and ""The Creative Powers of a Free Civilization"" "	What topic were Hayek's next two books going to cover?
From 1962 until his retirement in 1968, he was a professor at the University of Freiburg, West Germany, where he began work on his next book, Law, Legislation and Liberty	What country did Hayek move to in 1962?
In February 1975, Margaret Thatcher was elected leader of the British Conservative Party	What political party was Margaret Thatcher the head of in 1975?
In 1977, Hayek was critical of the Lib-Lab pact, in which the British Liberal Party agreed to keep the British Labour government in office	What was the name of the agreement Hayek criticized in 1977?
"In 1978, Hayek came into conflict with the Liberal Party leader, David Steel, who claimed that liberty was possible only with ""social justice and an equitable distribution of wealth and power, which in turn require a degree of active government intervention"" and that the Conservative Party were more concerned with the connection between liberty and private enterprise than between liberty and democracy"	Which party was criticized for being less concerned about liberty and democracy?
"In 1984, he was appointed as a member of the Order of the Companions of Honour by Queen Elizabeth II of the United Kingdom on the advice of the British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher for his ""services to the study of economics"""	What group was Hayek inducted into by the Queen of England?
"Bush awarded Hayek the Presidential Medal of Freedom, one of the two highest civilian awards in the United States, for a ""lifetime of looking beyond the horizon"""	What was the reason given for Hayek's 1991 award from the President?
"Mises had earlier applied the concept of marginal utility to the value of money in his Theory of Money and Credit , in which he also proposed an explanation for ""industrial fluctuations"" based on the ideas of the old British Currency School and of Swedish economist Knut Wicksell"	What is the name of Mises' 1912 book?
In 1929, Lionel Robbins assumed the helm of the London School of Economics 	Lionel Robbins came to head which school in 1929?
"Keynes"" and published his lectures at the LSE in book form as Prices and Production"	Hayek's critical analysis of Keyne's work was published under what title?
Hayek continued his research on monetary and capital theory, revising his theories of the relations between credit cycles and capital structure in Profits, Interest and Investment and The Pure Theory of Capital , but his reputation as an economic theorist had by then fallen so much that those works were largely ignored, except for scathing critiques by Nicholas Kaldor	What was the result of Hayek's Prices and Production?
"Hayek never produced the book-length treatment of ""the dynamics of capital"" that he had promised in the Pure Theory of Capital"	What topic did Hayek never write a book about as he said he would?
Building on the earlier work of Ludwig von Mises and others, Hayek also argued that while in centrally planned economies an individual or a select group of individuals must determine the distribution of resources, these planners will never have enough information to carry out this allocation reliably	What did Hayek claim those who must distribute resources would lack most?
Dickinson and Oskar Lange, responded by invoking general equilibrium theory, which they argued disproved Mises's thesis	What did some socialists bring up as a rebuttal to Hayek's resource distribution argument?
In The Use of Knowledge in Society , Hayek argued that the price mechanism serves to share and synchronise local and personal knowledge, allowing society's members to achieve diverse, complicated ends through a principle of spontaneous self-organization	Which of Hayek's books argued against the socialist price mechanism?
Hayek was one of the leading academic critics of collectivism in the 20th century	What was the name of the ideology Hayek criticized?
"Hayek also wrote that the state can play a role in the economy, and specifically, in creating a ""safety net"""	Hayek believed the state could aid the economy by doing what?
Hayek's work on the microeconomics of the choice theoretics of investment, non-permanent goods, potential permanent resources, and economically-adapted permanent resources mark a central dividing point between his work in areas of macroeconomics and that of almost all other economists	In what economic field of study does Hayek's views differ from those in macroeconomics?
During World War II, Hayek began the ‘Abuse of Reason’ project	When did Hayek start working on Abuse of Reason?
"In The Sensory Order: An Inquiry into the Foundations of Theoretical Psychology , Hayek independently developed a ""Hebbian learning"" model of learning and memory – an idea which he first conceived in 1920, prior to his study of economics"	In what year was the book published in which Hayek developed Hebbian learning?
In the latter half of his career Hayek made a number of contributions to social and political philosophy, which he based on his views on the limits of human knowledge, and the idea of spontaneous order in social institutions	When did Hayek begin presenting his ideas on the limits of human knowledge?
Hayek disapproved of the notion of 'social justice'	What concept did Hayek dislike?
Hayek’s concept of the market as a spontaneous order has been recently applied to ecosystems to defend a broadly non-interventionist policy	What has Hayek's views on the market been used to defend?
"With regard to a safety net, Hayek advocated ""some provision for those threatened by the extremes of indigence or starvation, be if only in the interest of those who require protection against acts of desperation on the part of the needy"	According to Wapshott, who was promoting the implementation of universal health care?
Diamond argues Hayek's problems arise when he goes beyond claims that can be evaluated within economic science	Diamond believes Hayek's weaknesses come out when he steps beyond the bounds of what topic?
But a dictatorship may be a necessary system for a transitional period	At what point did Hayek claim dictatorships may be necessary?
For Hayek, the supposedly stark difference between authoritarianism and totalitarianism has much importance and Hayek places heavy weight on this distinction in his defence of transitional dictatorship	Hayek believed that authoritarianism was very different from what?
In 1932, Hayek suggested that private investment in the public markets was a better road to wealth and economic co-ordination in Britain than government spending programs, as argued in a letter he co-signed with Lionel Robbins and others in an exchange of letters with John Maynard Keynes in The Times	What did Hayek claim to be better than investing in government spending programs?
Hayek is the second-most frequently cited economist in the Nobel lectures of the prize winners in economics, which is particularly striking since his own lecture was critical of the field of orthodox economics and neo-classical modelisation	Which economist is cited the most by winners of the Nobel prize in that field?
"The ""informal"" economics presented in Milton Friedman's massively influential popular work Free to Choose , is explicitly Hayekian in its account of the price system as a system for transmitting and co-ordinating knowledge"	"Whose 1980 book mentions ""informal"" economics?"
Hayek had a long-standing and close friendship with philosopher of science Karl Popper, also from Vienna	Which fellow Vienna native was Hayek friends with?
For example, Hayek's discussion in The Road to Serfdom about truth, falsehood and the use of language influenced some later opponents of postmodernism	Which of Hayek's books had an impact on those against postmodernism?
After winning the United Kingdom general election, 1979, Margaret Thatcher appointed Keith Joseph, the director of the Hayekian Centre for Policy Studies, as her secretary of state for industry in an effort to redirect parliament's economic strategies	In what year was Margaret Thatcher elected Prime Minister?
"Hayek wrote an essay, ""Why I Am Not a Conservative"" , in which he disparaged conservatism for its inability to adapt to changing human realities or to offer a positive political program, remarking, ""Conservatism is only as good as what it conserves"	What ideology did Hayek not agree with in an essay appended to The Constitution of Liberty?
"However, for his part, Hayek found this term ""singularly unattractive"" and offered the term ""Old Whig"" instead"	What did Hayek suggest as an alternative to being called a libertarian?
"His opponents have attacked Hayek as a leading promoter of ""neoliberalism"""	What term do those who disagree with Hayek use to describe his ideals?
In Why F A Hayek is a Conservative, British policy analyst Madsen Pirie claims Hayek mistakes the nature of the conservative outlook	Who makes the claim that Hayek was actually a conservative?
Diarrhea, also spelled diarrhoea, is the condition of having at least three loose or liquid bowel movements each day	What is diarrhea?
The most common cause is an infection of the intestines due to either a virus, bacteria, or parasite; a condition known as gastroenteritis	What is the most common cause of diarrhea?
Prevention of infectious diarrhea is by improved sanitation, clean drinking water, and hand washing with soap	What are some ways to prevent diarrhea?
It is most common in developing countries, where young children get diarrhea on average three times a year	How often do kids get diarrhea in developing countries?
Secretory diarrhea means that there is an increase in the active secretion, or there is an inhibition of absorption	What is secretory diarrhea?
Osmotic diarrhea occurs when too much water is drawn into the bowels	What occures with osmotic diarrhea?
Inflammatory diarrhea occurs when there is damage to the mucosal lining or brush border, which leads to a passive loss of protein-rich fluids and a decreased ability to absorb these lost fluids	When does inflammatory diarrhea occur?
Diarrheal disease may have a negative impact on both physical fitness and mental development	Diarrheal disease has what effects on a person?
Another possible cause of diarrhea is irritable bowel syndrome , which usually presents with abdominal discomfort relieved by defecation and unusual stool for at least 3 days a week over the previous 3 months	What is IBS?
Poverty is a good indicator of the rate of infectious diarrhea in a population	What is a good indicator of the rate of infectious diarrhea?
Proper nutrition is important for health and functioning, including the prevention of infectious diarrhea	Why is proper nutrition important?
According to two researchers, Nesse and Williams, diarrhea may function as an evolved expulsion defense mechanism	What did Nesse and Williams learn?
Basic sanitation techniques can have a profound effect on the transmission of diarrheal disease	What has had major effects on the transmission of diarrheal diseases?
Given that water contamination is a major means of transmitting diarrheal disease, efforts to provide clean water supply and improved sanitation have the potential to dramatically cut the rate of disease incidence	What is a major means of the spread of diarrhea disease?
Immunization against the pathogens that cause diarrheal disease is a viable prevention strategy, however it does require targeting certain pathogens for vaccination	What is the downfall of using immunization against the pathogens that cause disease?
Dietary deficiencies in developing countries can be combated by promoting better eating practices	What can be done to combate dietary deficiences?
In many cases of diarrhea, replacing lost fluid and salts is the only treatment needed	What is the basic treatment many cases of diarrhea need?
Oral rehydration solution can be used to prevent dehydration	What can be used to prevent dehydration?
Drinks especially high in simple sugars, such as soft drinks and fruit juices, are not recommended in children under 5 years of age as they may increase dehydration	What are not recommended for younger kids because it can casue more dehydration?
WHO recommends a child with diarrhea continue to be fed	What does WHO recommend?
While antibiotics are beneficial in certain types of acute diarrhea, they are usually not used except in specific situations	Are antibiotics used in diarrhea instances?
Madrasa (Arabic: مدرسة‎, madrasah, pl	What are the origins of the word madrasa?
"The word madrasah derives from the triconsonantal Semitic root د-ر-س D-R-S 'to learn, study', through the wazn مفعل‎; mafʻal, meaning ""a place where something is done"""	What are the root origins of the word madrasah?
However, in English, the term madrasah usually refers to the specifically Islamic institutions	What is the English connotative understanding of the word madrash? 
People of all ages attend, and many often move on to becoming imams	What age groups are usually enrolled in madaris?
"The term ""Islamic education"" means education in the light of Islam itself, which is rooted in the teachings of the Quran - holy book of Muslims"	What is the meaning of Islamic education?
The first institute of madrasa education was at the estate of Hazrat Zaid bin Arkam near a hill called Safa, where Hazrat Muhammad was the teacher and the students were some of his followers	Where was the first madrasa located?
During the rule of the Fatimid and Mamluk dynasties and their successor states in the medieval Middle East, many of the ruling elite founded madaris through a religious endowment known as the waqf	Which class of people founded the madaris during the medieval period?
The madaris, however, were not centres of advanced scientific study; scientific advances in Islam were usually carried out by scholars working under the patronage of royal courts	Who traditionally paid for scholars to study natural sciences?
In the medieval Islamic world, an elementary school was known as a maktab, which dates back to at least the 10th century	When were the first recorded Islamic elementary schools?
Ibn Sīnā refers to the secondary education stage of maktab schooling as a period of specialisation when pupils should begin to acquire manual skills, regardless of their social status	What type of skills did Ibn Sina state children should learn in secondary education?
"During its formative period, the term madrasah referred to a higher education institution, whose curriculum initially included only the ""religious sciences"", whilst philosophy and the secular sciences were often excluded"	What discipline was studied in traditional madrasah?
Madaris were largely centred on the study of fiqh 	What term refers to Islamic law?
According to Makdisi, the Latin title licentia docendi 'licence to teach' in the European university may have been a translation of the Arabic, but the underlying concept was very different	What did earning the ijazat al-tadris award students?
Much of the study in the madrasah college centred on examining whether certain opinions of law were orthodox	What determination of the study of law was held to much debate?
Green and Seyyed Hossein Nasr have argued that starting in the 10th century, some medieval Islamic madaris indeed became universities	When did some madaris become considered like traditional colleges?
al-Qarawīyīn University in Fez, Morocco is recognised by many historians as the oldest degree-granting university in the world, having been founded in 859 by Fatima al-Fihri	When was al-Qarawiyin University founded?
Al-Azhar University, founded in Cairo, Egypt in 975 by the Ismaʻīlī Shīʻī Fatimid dynasty as a jāmiʻah, had individual faculties for a theological seminary, Islamic law and jurisprudence, Arabic grammar, Islamic astronomy, early Islamic philosophy and logic in Islamic philosophy	When was Al-Azhar University founded?
In madaris, the ijāzahs were only issued in one field, the Islamic religious law of sharīʻah, and in no other field of learning	What field does the ijazah signify expertise in?
In a sense, the madrasa resembles a university college in that it has most of the features of a university, but lacks the corporate element	What do scholars believe is missing from madaris that prevent them from being considered universities?
"In central and eastern Islamic lands, the view that the madrasa, as a charitable endowment, will remain under the control of the donor , resulted in a ""spurt"" of establishment of madaris in the 11th and 12th centuries"	When did more madaris begin to form more rapidly?
Nevertheless, Makdisi has asserted that the European university borrowed many of its features from the Islamic madrasa, including the concepts of a degree and doctorate	What institutions have been considered to take some its ideas from madaris?
"Generally, some reviewers have pointed out the strong inclination of Makdisi of overstating his case by simply resting on ""the accumulation of close parallels"", but all the while failing to point to convincing channels of transmission between the Muslim and Christian world"	What other religion was considered to share parallels in teaching styles with the Muslim faith?
Prior to the 12th century, women accounted for less than one percent of the world’s Islamic scholars	What percentage of Islamic women were educated before the 1200s?
In particular, many well known women of the time were trained from childhood in music, dancing and poetry	What disciplines were women trained in during the first century?
According to the Sunni scholar Ibn ʻAsākir in the 12th century, there were opportunities for female education in the medieval Islamic world, writing that women could study, earn ijazahs , and qualify as scholars and teachers	What titles could women earn by going to Islamic schools?
""" İnalcık also mentions that while scholars from for example Persia travelled to the Ottomans in order to share their knowledge, Ottomans travelled as well to receive education from scholars of these Islamic lands, such as Egypt, Persia and Turkestan"	Who traveled abroad to get an education at madaris?
Although Ottoman madaris had a number of different branches of study, such as calligraphic sciences, oral sciences, and intellectual sciences, they primarily served the function of an Islamic centre for spiritual learning	What was the essential mission of Islamic schools in the Ottoman Empire?
Medreses were built in as part of a Mosque complex where many programmes, such as aid to the poor through soup kitchens, were held under the infrastructure of a mosque, which reveals the interconnectedness of religion and social life during this period	What kind of social service was provided through the madaris?
The religious establishment forms part of the mainly two large divisions within the country, namely the Deobandis, who dominate in numbers and the Barelvis, who also make up a sizeable portion 	What group makes up a larger percentage of people in India?
In 2005, an estimated 6,000 Muslim Arabic teachers taught in Kerala government schools, with over 500,000 Muslim students	How many Muslim students are there in Kerala?
In Southeast Asia, Muslim students have a choice of attending a secular government or an Islamic school	Who decides if Muslims attend secular schools or traditional madaris?
There are six Madrasahs in Singapore, catering to students from Primary 1 to Secondary 4	How many madrasahs are in Sinagapore?
In 2004, madaris were mainstreamed in 16 Regions nationwide, primarily in Muslim-majority areas in Mindanao under the auspices of the Department of Education 	How many regions in Singapore have widely accepted madaris?
The first Madressa established in North America, Al-Rashid Islamic Institute, was established in Cornwall, Ontario in 1983 and has graduates who are Hafiz and Ulama	When was the first madrasa started in North America?
Western commentators post-9/11 often perceive madaris as places of radical revivalism with a connotation of anti-Americanism and radical extremism, frequently associated in the Western press with Wahhabi attitudes toward non-Muslims	What is the common western perception of the teaching received at madaris?

Downtown Miami is home to the largest concentration of international banks in the United States, and many large national and international companies	What does downtown Miami possess more of than any other US city?

During the beginning of the 20th century, migrants from the Bahamas and African-Americans constituted 40 percent of the city's population	In the early 1900s, what percentage of Miami's population was of African origin?

After Fidel Castro rose to power in Cuba in 1959, many wealthy Cubans sought refuge in Miami, further increasing the population	In what year did Fidel Castro take over Cuba?
Miami and its suburbs are located on a broad plain between the Florida Everglades to the west and Biscayne Bay to the east, which also extends from Florida Bay north to Lake Okeechobee	Where are the Everglades in relation to Miami?
The surface bedrock under the Miami area is called Miami oolite or Miami limestone	What is another name for Miami limestone?
Beneath the plain lies the Biscayne Aquifer, a natural underground source of fresh water that extends from southern Palm Beach County to Florida Bay, with its highest point peaking around the cities of Miami Springs and Hialeah	Along with Miami Springs, where is the highest point of the Biscayne Aquifer?
Miami is partitioned into many different sections, roughly into North, South, West and Downtown	Along with West, Downtown and North, what is the other notable area of Miami?
The southern side of Miami includes Coral Way, The Roads and Coconut Grove	Along with Coconut Grove and Coral Way, what is notably present in southern Miami?
The northern side of Miami also has notable African American and Caribbean immigrant communities such as Little Haiti, Overtown , and Liberty City	What notable theater is present in Overtown?
Miami has a tropical monsoon climate with hot and humid summers and short, warm winters, with a marked drier season in the winter	What is Miami's Köppen climate classification?
The wet season begins some time in May, ending in mid-October	When is the beginning of Miami's wet season?
The city proper is home to less than one-thirteenth of the population of South Florida	What fraction of the southern Florida population lives in Miami?
In 1960, non-Hispanic whites represented 80% of Miami-Dade county's population	What percentage of Miami-Dade's population was non-Hispanic white in 1960?

:20–21 The matua were located in the coastal villages, which meant they had the best access to fishing grounds, whereas the mana'chang were located in the interior of the island	Where were the matua located on the island?
The first European to discover Guam was Portuguese navigator Ferdinand Magellan, sailing for the King of Spain, when he sighted the island on March 6, 1521 during his fleet's circumnavigation of the globe	What was the nationality of Magellan?
Despite Magellan's visit, Guam was not officially claimed by Spain until January 26, 1565 by General Miguel López de Legazpi	In what year was Guam claimed by Spain?
Spanish colonization commenced on June 15, 1668 with the arrival of Diego Luis de San Vitores and Pedro Calungsod, who established the first Catholic church	When did Spanish colonization commence?
Intermittent warfare lasting from July 23, 1670 until July 1695, plus the typhoons of 1671 and 1693, and in particular the smallpox epidemic of 1688, reduced the Chamorro population from 50,000 to 10,000 to less than 5,000	When did the Smallpox epidemic take place?
After his arrival in 1674, Captain Damian de Esplana ordered the arrest of rebels who attacked the population of certain towns	When did Captain Damian de Esplana arrive?

This view is commonly contrasted with rationalism, which states that knowledge may be derived from reason independently of the senses	What is commonly contrasted with empiricism?
Aristotle's explanation of how this was possible was not strictly empiricist in a modern sense, but rather based on his theory of potentiality and actuality, and experience of sense perceptions still requires the help of the active nous	What theory was Aristotle's explanation based on?
Stoic epistemology generally emphasized that the mind starts blank, but acquires knowledge as the outside world is impressed upon it	What is the Stoic view?
During the Middle Ages Aristotle's theory of tabula rasa was developed by Islamic philosophers starting with Al Farabi, developing into an elaborate theory by Avicenna and demonstrated as a thought experiment by Ibn Tufail	Whose idea was 'tabula rasa'?
"In the 12th century CE the Andalusian Muslim philosopher and novelist Abu Bakr Ibn Tufail included the theory of tabula rasa as a thought experiment in his Arabic philosophical novel, Hayy ibn Yaqdhan in which he depicted the development of the mind of a feral child ""from a tabula rasa to that of an adult, in complete isolation from society"" on a desert island, through experience alone"	What was 'Abubacer' normally called?
"Their contemporary, Leonardo da Vinci said, ""If you find from your own experience that something is a fact and it contradicts what some authority has written down, then you must abandon the authority and base your reasoning on your own findings"	When was da Vinci born?
1520–1591), father of Galileo and the inventor of monody, made use of the method in successfully solving musical problems, firstly, of tuning such as the relationship of pitch to string tension and mass in stringed instruments, and to volume of air in wind instruments; and secondly to composition, by his various suggestions to composers in his Dialogo della musica antica e moderna 	When did Vincenzo Galilei die?
British empiricism, though it was not a term used at the time, derives from the 17th century period of early modern philosophy and modern science	When was the British empiricism period?
"In response to the early-to-mid-17th century ""continental rationalism"" John Locke proposed in An Essay Concerning Human Understanding a very influential view wherein the only knowledge humans can have is a posteriori, i"	When was 'An Essay Concerning Human Understanding' published?
A generation later, the Irish Anglican bishop, George Berkeley , determined that Locke's view immediately opened a door that would lead to eventual atheism	Who wrote 'Treatise Concerning the Principles of Human Knowledge'?
The Scottish philosopher David Hume responded to Berkeley's criticisms of Locke, as well as other differences between early modern philosophers, and moved empiricism to a new level of skepticism	What did Hume bring to empiricism?
Hume divided all of human knowledge into two categories: relations of ideas and matters of fact 	What types of human knowledge did Hume say there are?
Rather, he maintained, our beliefs are more a result of accumulated habits, developed in response to accumulated sense experiences	What did Hume think our beliefs are?
Most of Hume's followers have disagreed with his conclusion that belief in an external world is rationally unjustifiable, contending that Hume's own principles implicitly contained the rational justification for such a belief, that is, beyond being content to let the issue rest on human instinct, custom and habit	What conclusion do most of Hume's followers disagree with?
Mill's empiricism thus held that knowledge of any kind is not from direct experience but an inductive inference from direct experience	What did Mill say knowledge comes from?
The phenomenalist phase of post-Humean empiricism ended by the 1940s, for by that time it had become obvious that statements about physical things could not be translated into statements about actual and possible sense data	What phase of empiricism ended in the 1940s?
Logical empiricism was an early 20th-century attempt to synthesize the essential ideas of British empiricism (e	What are other terms for logical empiricism?
They saw in the logical symbolism elaborated by Frege and Bertrand Russell a powerful instrument that could rationally reconstruct all scientific discourse into an ideal, logically perfect, language that would be free of the ambiguities and deformations of natural language	When was Bertrand Russell born?
In the extreme empiricism of the neopositivists—at least before the 1930s—any genuinely synthetic assertion must be reducible to an ultimate assertion that expresses direct observations or perceptions	Who were extreme empiricists?
In the late 19th and early 20th century several forms of pragmatic philosophy arose	When did pragmatism arise?
Charles Peirce was highly influential in laying the groundwork for today's empirical scientific method	When was Peirce born?
Among Peirce's major contributions was to place inductive reasoning and deductive reasoning in a complementary rather than competitive mode, the latter of which had been the primary trend among the educated since David Hume wrote a century before	How long before Peirce did Hume write?
"In his Harvard ""Lectures on Pragmatism"" , Peirce enumerated what he called the ""three cotary propositions of pragmatism"" , saying that they ""put the edge on the maxim of pragmatism"""	Who wrote 'Lectures on Pragmatism'?
"Around the beginning of the 20th century, William James coined the term ""radical empiricism"" to describe an offshoot of his form of pragmatism, which he argued could be dealt with separately from his pragmatism – though in fact the two concepts are intertwined in James's published lectures"	Who came up with 'radical empiricism'?
John Dewey modified James' pragmatism to form a theory known as instrumentalism	Who came up with 'instrumentalism'?
In philosophy, idealism is the group of philosophies which assert that reality, or reality as we can know it, is fundamentally mental, mentally constructed, or otherwise immaterial	What do idealist philosophies say is constructed in our minds?

Subjective idealists like George Berkeley are anti-realists in terms of a mind-independent world, whereas transcendental idealists like Immanuel Kant are strong skeptics of such a world, affirming epistemological and not metaphysical idealism	Who is a notable subjective idealist?
Christian theologians have held idealist views, often based on Neoplatonism, despite the influence of Aristotelian scholasticism from the 12th century onward	In what philosophy was Christian idealism often rooted?
"Plato's theory of forms or ""ideas"" describes ideal forms , as universals existing independently of any particular instance"	What was another term for forms in Plato's theory of forms?

Czech ), formerly known as Bohemian , is a West Slavic language strongly influenced by Latin and German language, spoken by over 10 million people and it is the official language of the Czech Republic	What was Czech formerly known as?

Post-punk is a heterogeneous type of rock music that emerged in the wake of the punk movement of the 1970s	When did post-punk arrive on the scene?
"The term ""post-punk"" was first used by journalists in the late 1970s to describe groups moving beyond punk's sonic template into disparate areas"	Who coined the term post-punk?
"Though the music varied widely between regions and artists, the post-punk movement has been characterized by its ""conceptual assault"" on rock conventions and rejection of aesthetics perceived of as traditionalist, hegemonic or rockist in favor of experimentation with production techniques and non-rock musical styles such as dub, electronic music, disco, noise, jazz, krautrock, world music and the avant-garde"	What were the things that post-punk really got into?
"Nicholas Lezard described post-punk as ""a fusion of art and music"""	How did Nicholas Lezard describe post-punk?
"While some critics, such as AllMusic's Stephen Thomas Erlewine, have employed the term ""post-punk"" to denote ""a more adventurous and arty form of punk"", others have suggested it pertains to a set of artistic sensibilities and approaches rather than any unifying style"	"Who described post-punk as ""a more adventurous and arty form of punk""?"
Generally, post-punk music is defined as music that emerged from the cultural milieu of punk rock in the late 1970s, although many groups now categorized as post-punk were initially subsumed under the broad umbrella of punk or new wave music, only becoming differentiated as the terms came to signify more narrow styles	What is post-punk?
During the initial punk era, a variety of entrepreneurs interested in local punk-influenced music scenes began founding independent record labels, including Rough Trade and Factory 	WHich independent music company was founded by Geoff Travis?
"In late 1977, music writers for Sounds first used the terms ""New Musick"" and ""post punk"" to describe British acts such as Siouxsie and the Banshees and Wire, who began experimenting with sounds, lyrics and aesthetics that differed significantly from their punk contemporaries"	"When did writers for Sounds first mention ""post punk""?"
As the initial punk movement dwindled, vibrant new scenes began to coalesce out of a variety of bands pursuing experimental sounds and wider conceptual territory in their work	When the punk movement started shrinking, what began to fill the void left by their demise?

"British post-punk entered the 1980s with support from members of the critical community—American critic Greil Marcus characterised ""Britain's postpunk pop avant-garde"" in a 1980 Rolling Stone article as ""sparked by a tension, humour and sense of paradox plainly unique in present day pop music""—as well as media figures such as BBC DJ John Peel, while several groups, such as PiL and Joy Division, achieved some success in the popular charts"	How did critics respond to British post-punk groups in the 1980s?
However, during this period, major figures and artists in the scene began leaning away from underground aesthetics	Many of the big players in the post-punk scene began leaning away from what as time progressed?

Play stops when the ball carrier's knee, elbow, or any other body part aside from the feet and hands, is forced to the ground ; when a forward pass is not caught on the fly ; when a touchdown or a field goal is scored; when the ball leaves the playing area by any means ; or when the ball carrier is in a standing position but can no longer move forwards 	What is the term for play stopped because the ball carrier, although not fully tackled, can no longer advance the ball?
Before scrimmage, an official places the ball at the spot it was at the stop of clock, but no nearer than 24 yards from the sideline or 1 yard from the goal line	What minimum distance from the sideline does the official place the ball before play starts?

The history of the Seven Years' War in North America, particularly the expulsion of the Acadians, the siege of Quebec, the death of Wolfe, and the Battle of Fort William Henry generated a vast number of ballads, broadsides, images, and novels , maps and other printed materials, which testify to how this event held the imagination of the British and North American public long after Wolfe's death in 1759	Name two major events of the Seven Years' War In North America.

Richard Phillips Feynman was an American theoretical physicist known for his work in the path integral formulation of quantum mechanics, the theory of quantum electrodynamics, and the physics of the superfluidity of supercooled liquid helium, as well as in particle physics for which he proposed the parton model	Feynman proposed a integral model in particle physics, what was it?
Feynman was a keen popularizer of physics through both books and lectures, including a 1959 talk on top-down nanotechnology called There's Plenty of Room at the Bottom, and the three-volume publication of his undergraduate lectures, The Feynman Lectures on Physics	What was the name of Feynman's 1959 talk on nanotech?
Richard Phillips Feynman was born on May 11, 1918, in Queens, New York City, the son of Lucille , a homemaker, and Melville Arthur Feynman, a sales manager	What was the date of Feynman's birth?
From his mother he gained the sense of humor that he had throughout his life	What personality trait did Feynman acquire from his mother?
When Richard was five years old, his mother gave birth to a younger brother, but this brother died at four weeks of age	What happened to Feyman's younger brother?
"An unspecified school-administered IQ test estimated his IQ at 123—high, but ""merely respectable"" according to biographer James Gleick"	What IQ score did Feyman attain in high school?
He attained a perfect score on the graduate school entrance exams to Princeton University in mathematics and physics—an unprecedented feat—but did rather poorly on the history and English portions	Which two sections of the graduate exam did Feynman excel in?
Wilson encouraged Feynman to participate in the Manhattan Project—the wartime U	Which weaponry research did Feynman engage in?

Following the completion of his PhD in 1942, Feynman held an appointment at the University of Wisconsin–Madison as an assistant professor of physics	Where did Feynman receive a job after getting his PhD?
After the war, Feynman declined an offer from the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton, New Jersey, despite the presence there of such distinguished faculty members as Albert Einstein, Kurt Gödel and John von Neumann	At which college did Feyman turn down a job?
Despite yet another offer from the Institute for Advanced Study, Feynman rejected the Institute on the grounds that there were no teaching duties: Feynman felt that students were a source of inspiration and teaching was a diversion during uncreative spells	Why did Feynman decide to turn down an offer from the Institute of Advanced Study?
"Feynman has been called the ""Great Explainer"""	Which nickname did Feynman receive?
He also developed Feynman diagrams, a bookkeeping device that helps in conceptualizing and calculating interactions between particles in spacetime, including the interactions between electrons and their antimatter counterparts, positrons	What did Feynman produce that help in understanding calculations between particles in space and time?

 1942 – 20 October 2011), commonly known as Colonel Gaddafi, was a Libyan revolutionary, politician, and political theorist	When was Gaddafi born, and when did he die?

Muammar Gaddafi was born in a tent near Qasr Abu Hadi, a rural area outside the town of Sirte in the deserts of western Libya	Describe Gaddafi's humble upbringing.

Gaddafi's earliest education was of a religious nature, imparted by a local Islamic teacher	Describe Gaddafi's first experience with education.
He read voraciously on the subjects of Nasser and the French Revolution of 1789, as well as the works of Syrian political theorist Michel Aflaq and biographies of Abraham Lincoln, Sun Yat-sen, and Mustafa Kemal Atatürk	Gaddafi was an avid reader. Name three biographies that he read.

Idris' government was increasingly unpopular by the latter 1960s; it had exacerbated Libya's traditional regional and tribal divisions by centralising the country's federal system in order to take advantage of the country's oil wealth, while corruption and entrenched systems of patronage were widespread throughout the oil industry	What was happening to Idris' government in the 1960s?
"Gaddafi's Free Officers recognized this as their chance to overthrow the monarchy, initiating ""Operation Jerusalem"""	What was Gaddafi's coup called?

They purged monarchists and members of Idris' Senussi clan from Libya's political world and armed forces; Gaddafi believed this elite were opposed to the will of the Libyan people and had to be expunged	What did the RCC do with remnants of the monarchy?
Ruling by decree, the RCC maintained the monarchy's ban on political parties, in May 1970 banned trade unions, and in 1972 outlawed workers' strikes and suspended newspapers	What was the RCC's view of political parties?
With crude oil as the country's primary export, Gaddafi sought to improve Libya's oil sector	What was Libya's main export?
In turn, the Libyans' standard of life greatly improved over the first decade of Gaddafi's administration, and by 1979 the average per-capita income was at $8,170, up from $40 in 1951; this was above the average of many industrialized countries like Italy and the U	In 1979, how much did the average per capita income change for Libyans?
The RCC attempted to suppress regional and tribal affiliation, replacing it with a unified pan-Libyan identity	What sort of identity was promoted by the RCC?
The RCC implemented measures for social reform, adopting sharia as a basis	On what philosophy was the RCC's social reforms based?
The influence of Nasser's Arab nationalism over the RCC was immediately apparent	What philosophy influenced the RCC?
After Nasser died in November 1970, his successor, Anwar Sadat, suggested that rather than a unified state, they create a political federation, implemented in April 1971; in doing so, Egypt, Syria and Sudan got large grants of Libyan oil money	Who did Anwar Sadat succeed?
After the 1969 coup, representatives of the Four Powers – France, the United Kingdom, the United States and the Soviet Union – were called to meet RCC representatives	What nations comprised the Four Powers?
Moving to reduce Italian influence, in October 1970 all Italian-owned assets were expropriated and the 12,000-strong Italian community expelled from Libya alongside a smaller number of Jews	How many Italians lived in Libya prior to October of 1970?

Gaddafi was indiscriminate in the causes he funded, sometimes switching from supporting one side in a conflict to the other, as in the Eritrean War of Independence	During what conflict did Gaddafi notably switch sides?
"On 16 April 1973, Gaddafi proclaimed the start of a ""Popular Revolution"" in a Zuwarah speech"	"On what date did Gaddafi declare the beginning of a ""Popular Revolution""?"
As part of this Popular Revolution, Gaddafi invited Libya's people to found General People's Committees as conduits for raising political consciousness	What were the Libyan people instructed to create in conjunction with the Popular Revolution?
The People's Committees led to a high percentage of public involvement in decision making, within the limits permitted by the RCC, but exacerbated tribal divisions	What negative consequence did the People's Committees lead to?
In June 1973, Gaddafi created a political ideology as a basis for the Popular Revolution	In what month and year did Gaddafi begin Third International Theory?
Gaddafi summarized Third International Theory in three short volumes published between 1975 and 1979, collectively known as The Green Book	Gaddafi's written work on Third International Theory consisted of how many volumes?
In September 1975, Gaddafi purged the army, arresting around 200 senior officers, and in October he founded the clandestine Office for the Security of the Revolution	In what year was the Office for the Security of the Revolution founded?
Following Anwar Sadat's ascension to the Egyptian presidency, Libya's relations with Egypt deteriorated	Whose rise to the presidency of Egypt led to the decline in relations between Egypt and Libya?
Gaddafi was later infuriated when Egypt and Syria planned the Yom Kippur War against Israel without consulting him, and was angered when Egypt conceded to peace talks rather than continuing the war	Who was allied with Egypt during the Yom Kippur War?
Gaddafi sought to develop closer links in the Maghreb; in January 1974 Libya and Tunisia announced a political union, the Arab Islamic Republic	What country formed a political union with Libya in 1974?

"Debate remained limited, and major decisions regarding the economy and defence were avoided or dealt with cursorily; the GPC largely remained ""a rubber stamp"" for Gaddafi's policies"	What was the GPC accused of being vis-à-vis Gaddafi?
"With preceding legal institutions abolished, Gaddafi envisioned the Jamahiriya as following the Qur'an for legal guidance, adopting sharia law; he proclaimed ""man-made"" laws unnatural and dictatorial, only permitting Allah's law"	What book did the Jamahiriya look to for legal advice?
In December 1978, Gaddafi stepped down as Secretary-General of the GPC, announcing his new focus on revolutionary rather than governmental activities; this was part of his new emphasis on separating the apparatus of the revolution from the government	In what year did Gaddafi resign from his position in the GPC?
"In September, Gaddafi called for the People's Committees to eliminate the ""bureaucracy of the public sector"" and the ""dictatorship of the private sector""; the People's Committees took control of several hundred companies, converting them into worker cooperatives run by elected representatives"	In September of 1978, what bureaucracy did Gaddafi speak out against?
On 2 March 1979, the GPC announced the separation of government and revolution, the latter being represented by new Revolutionary Committees, who operated in tandem with the People's Committees in schools, universities, unions, the police force and the military	On what date did the GPC separate the revolution from the government?
In 1979, the committees began the redistribution of land in the Jefara plain, continuing through 1981	Where did land redistribution begin in 1979?

Cyprus ; Turkish: Kıbrıs IPA: ), officially the Republic of Cyprus , is an island country in the Eastern Mediterranean Sea, off the coasts of Syria and Turkey	What is the official name of Cypus?
The earliest known human activity on the island dates to around the 10th millennium BC	What is the date of the earliest known human activity on Cyprus?
Cyprus was placed under British administration based on Cyprus Convention in 1878 and formally annexed by Britain in 1914	When was Cyprus placed under British administration?
The Republic of Cyprus has de jure sovereignty over the island of Cyprus and its surrounding waters, according to international law, except for the British Overseas Territory of Akrotiri and Dhekelia, administered as Sovereign Base Areas	The Republic of Cyprus does not have de jure sovereignty over what two British territories? 
During the late Bronze Age the island experienced two waves of Greek settlement	During what Age did Cyprus experience two waves of Greek settlement?
Following the death in 1473 of James II, the last Lusignan king, the Republic of Venice assumed control of the island, while the late king's Venetian widow, Queen Catherine Cornaro, reigned as figurehead	In what year did James II die?
In 1570, a full-scale Ottoman assault with 60,000 troops brought the island under Ottoman control, despite stiff resistance by the inhabitants of Nicosia and Famagusta	In what year did Cyprus face a full-scale Ottoman assault?
The Ottomans abolished the feudal system previously in place and applied the millet system to Cyprus, under which non-Muslim peoples were governed by their own religious authorities	What system did the Ottomans abolish in favor of the millet system?
In 1777–78, 47,000 Muslims constituted a majority over the island's 37,000 Christians	How many Muslims made up the island's population in 1777-78?
As soon as the Greek War of Independence broke out in 1821, several Greek Cypriots left for Greece to join the Greek forces	What year did the Greek war of independence break out?
The island would serve Britain as a key military base for its colonial routes	The island of Cyprus serves as a key military base to what western country?
The idea of enosis was historically part of the Megali Idea, a greater political ambition of a Greek state encompassing the territories with Greek inhabitants in the former Ottoman Empire, including Cyprus and Asia Minor with a capital in Constantinople, and was actively pursued by the Cypriot Orthodox Church, which had its members educated in Greece	Historically, the idea of enosis was part of which other idea?
Initially, the Turkish Cypriots favoured the continuation of the British rule	Initially Turkish Cypriots favoured the continued rule of what Western power?
In January 1950, the Church of Cyprus organised a referendum under the supervision of clerics and with no Turkish Cypriot participation, where 96% of the participating Greek Cypriots voted in favour of enosis, The Greeks were 80	In what year did the Church of Cyprus organize a referendum?
On 16 August 1960, Cyprus attained independence after the Zürich and London Agreement between the United Kingdom, Greece and Turkey	What is the date that Cyrpus attained independence?
However, the division of power as foreseen by the constitution soon resulted in legal impasses and discontent on both sides, and nationalist militants started training again, with the military support of Greece and Turkey respectively	National militants had the support of what two countries?
Intercommunal violence erupted on December 21, 1963, when two Turkish Cypriots were killed at an incident involving the Greek Cypriot police	In December of what year did intercommunal violence erupt?
In 1964, Turkey tried to invade Cyprus in response to the continuing Cypriot intercommunal violence	Who tried to invade Cyprus in 1964?
On 15 July 1974, the Greek military junta under Dimitrios Ioannides carried out a coup d'état in Cyprus, to unite the island with Greece	What date was a coup d'etat carried out in Cyprus?
Three days later, when a ceasefire had been agreed, Turkey had landed 30,000 troops on the island and captured Kyrenia, the corridor linking Kyrenia to Nicosia, and the Turkish Cypriot quarter of Nicosia itself	What did the Turkish troops capture first on the island?
International pressure led to a ceasefire, and by then 37% of the island had been taken over by the Turks and 180,000 Greek Cypriots had been evicted from their homes in the north	How much of the island was controlled by Turks after international pressure led to a ceasefire?
Following the invasion and the capture of its northern territory by Turkish troops, the Republic of Cyprus announced that all of its ports of entry in the north were closed, as they were effectively not under its control	What happened to ports on Cyprus after capture of its northern territory by Turkish troops?
The last major effort to settle the Cyprus dispute was the Annan Plan in 2004, drafted by the then Secretary General, Kofi Annan	In what year did the last major effort to settle the Cyprus dispute take place?
The physical relief of the island is dominated by two mountain ranges, the Troodos Mountains and the smaller Kyrenia Range, and the central plain they encompass, the Mesaoria	What two mountains ranges are located on the island of Cyprus?
Cyprus has one of the warmest climates in the Mediterranean part of the European Union	What type of climate does Cyprus have?
Among all cities in the Mediterranean part of the European Union, Limassol has one of the warmest winters, in the period January – February average temperature is 17–18 °C during the day and 7–8 °C at night, in other coastal locations in Cyprus is generally 16–17 °C during the day and 6–8 °C at night	Which cities has one of the warmest winters in the European Union?
The middle of summer is hot – in July and August on the coast the average temperature is usually around 33 °C during the day and around 22 °C at night ) while in the June and September on the coast the average temperature is usually around 30 °C during the day and around 20 °C at night in Limassol, while is usually around 28 °C during the day and around 18 °C at night in Paphos	When does the middle of summer occur on Cyprus?
Cyprus suffers from a chronic shortage of water	What resource is scarce on Cyprus?
Dams remain the principal source of water both for domestic and agricultural use; Cyprus has a total of 107 dams and reservoirs, with a total water storage capacity of about 330,000,000 m3 (1	What do the people of Cyprus rely on for domestic and agricultural supply of water?
The 1960 Constitution provided for a presidential system of government with independent executive, legislative and judicial branches as well as a complex system of checks and balances including a weighted power-sharing ratio designed to protect the interests of the Turkish Cypriots	What types of branches did the 1960 Constitution provide?
In 1974 Cyprus was divided de facto when the Turkish army occupied the northern third of the island	In what years was Cyprus divided?
The House of Representatives currently has 59 members elected for a five-year term, 56 members by proportional representation and 3 observer members representing the Armenian, Latin and Maronite minorities	How many members are currently in the House of Representatives?

The traditional folk music of Cyprus has several common elements with Greek, Turkish, and Arabic music including Greco-Turkish dances such as the sousta, syrtos, zeibekikos, tatsia, and karsilamas as well as the Middle Eastern-inspired tsifteteli and arapies	Traditional Cyprus music has what other types of genres in common?
Popular music in Cyprus is generally influenced by the Greek Laïka scene; artists who play in this genre include international platinum star Anna Vissi, Evridiki, and Sarbel	What influences popular music in Cyprus?
"Epic poetry, notably the ""acritic songs"", flourished during Middle Ages"	What type of artistic form flourished at the time of the Middle Ages?

In 1852, Elisha Otis introduced the safety elevator, which prevented the fall of the cab if the cable broke	Who created the safety elevator in 1852?
Construction for Peter Cooper's Cooper Union Foundation building in New York began in 1853	What year did constructrion begin for the Cooper Union Foundation?
The first electric elevator was built by Werner von Siemens in 1880 in Germany	Who built the first electric elevator?
"A modern-day elevator consists of a cab mounted on a platform within an enclosed space called a shaft or sometimes a ""hoistway"""	What is another name for an elevator shaft?
The most common configuration is to have two panels that meet in the middle, and slide open laterally	How do most elevator doors work?
Historically, AC motors were used for single or double speed elevator machines on the grounds of cost and lower usage applications where car speed and passenger comfort were less of an issue, but for higher speed, larger capacity elevators, the need for infinitely variable speed control over the traction machine becomes an issue	Throughout history, what type of engines were used for elevator machines?
In this case, the drive sheave is directly attached to the end of the motor	In a gearless traction engine, what is the drive sheave attached to?
"In each case, cables are attached to a hitch plate on top of the cab or may be ""underslung"" below a cab, and then looped over the drive sheave to a counterweight attached to the opposite end of the cables which reduces the amount of power needed to move the cab"	What reduces the amount of force needed to propel the cab?
This is a separate set of cables or a chain attached to the bottom of the counterweight and the bottom of the elevator cab	"""Compensation"" consists of what?"
The low mechanical complexity of hydraulic elevators in comparison to traction elevators makes them ideal for low rise, low traffic installations	What type of installations are hydraulic elevators best suited for?
A climbing elevator is a self-ascending elevator with its own propulsion	What defines a climbing elevator?
"A elevator of this kind uses a vacuum on top of the cab and a valve on the top of the ""shaft"" to move the cab upwards and closes the valve in order to keep the cab at the same level"	What does this type of elevator use to propel the cage?
In the first half of the twentieth century, almost all elevators had no automatic positioning of the floor on which the cab would stop	Until the mid 1900s most elevators lacked what?
The elevator motor was located at the top of the shaft or beside the bottom of the shaft	Where is the elevator motor found?
Some skyscraper buildings and other types of installation feature a destination operating panel where a passenger registers their floor calls before entering the car	"What function does a ""destination operating panel"" feature?"
One problem is that the system is subject to gaming	What is one example of a limitation on the system? 
To prevent this problem, in one implementation of destination control, every user gets an RFID card to identify himself, so the system knows every user call and can cancel the first call if the passenger decides to travel to another destination to prevent empty calls	What is one way to implement destination control?
During up-peak mode , elevator cars in a group are recalled to the lobby to provide expeditious service to passengers arriving at the building, most typically in the morning as people arrive for work or at the conclusion of a lunch-time period	What is another name for up-peak mode?
It is activated by a key switch either inside the elevator itself or on a centralized control panel in the lobby	How is the special sercice mode enabled?
Inspection service is designed to provide access to the hoistway and car top for inspection and maintenance purposes by qualified elevator mechanics	Who is authorized to provide inspection and/or maintenance of the elevator?
Phase one mode is activated by a corresponding smoke sensor or heat sensor in the building	What initiates Phase one mode?
Phase-two mode can only be activated by a key switch located inside the elevator on the centralized control panel	How is the Phase-two mode enabled?
Once the elevator arrives at the floor, it will park with its doors open and the car buttons will be disabled to prevent a passenger from taking control of the elevator	Upon arriving at the desinated floor, what does the elevator do?
One by one, each car in the group will return to the lobby floor, open its doors and shut down	What sequence of events happens when the power shuts off in a traction elevator and the elevators all stop?
In hydraulic elevator systems, emergency power will lower the elevators to the lowest landing and open the doors to allow passengers to exit	How do hydraulic elevators work in emergencies?
Statistically speaking, cable-borne elevators are extremely safe	What types of elevator hold the highest safety record?
Past problems with hydraulic elevators include underground electrolytic destruction of the cylinder and bulkhead, pipe failures, and control failures	Underground electrolytic malfunctions in hydraulic elevators can result in the destruction of what?

A freight elevator, or goods lift, is an elevator designed to carry goods, rather than passengers	What is another name for a freight elevator?
Stage lifts and orchestra lifts are specialized elevators, typically powered by hydraulics, that are used to raise and lower entire sections of a theater stage	How are stage lifts powered?
A residential elevator is often permitted to be of lower cost and complexity than full commercial elevators	What type of elevators are generally less costly than full commercial elevators?
Some types of residential elevators do not use a traditional elevator shaft, machine room, and elevator hoistway	What types of elevators occassionaly do not use a traditional elevator shaft, machine room or hoistway?
Dumbwaiters are small freight elevators that are intended to carry food, books or other small freight loads rather than passengers	What are small freight elevators used for things such as food, called?
Material transport elevators generally consist of an inclined plane on which a conveyor belt runs	An inclined plane with a conveyor belt describes what type of elevator?

In addition to the call buttons, elevators usually have floor indicators and direction lanterns	Modern elevator position or floor indicaters often use what type of bulbs?
Direction lanterns are also found both inside and outside elevator cars, but they should always be visible from outside because their primary purpose is to help people decide whether or not to get on the elevator	What is the main function of direction lanterns?

Neptune is 17 times the mass of Earth and is slightly more massive than its near-twin Uranus, which is 15 times the mass of Earth and slightly larger than Neptune	What planet is Neptune's near-twin? 
Neptune is not visible to the unaided eye and is the only planet in the Solar System found by mathematical prediction rather than by empirical observation	How was Neptune found? 
Neptune is similar in composition to Uranus, and both have compositions that differ from those of the larger gas giants, Jupiter and Saturn	Which planet is compositionally similar to Neptune? 
For example, at the time of the Voyager 2 flyby in 1989, the planet's southern hemisphere had a Great Dark Spot comparable to the Great Red Spot on Jupiter	What weather did Voyager 2 observe on Neptune? 
Some of the earliest recorded observations ever made through a telescope, Galileo's drawings on 28 December 1612 and 27 January 1613, contain plotted points that match up with what is now known to be the position of Neptune	Who drew Neptune after observing it with a telescope? 
In 1821, Alexis Bouvard published astronomical tables of the orbit of Neptune's neighbour Uranus	What year did Alexis Bouvard publish relevant astronomical tables? 
Heinrich d'Arrest, a student at the observatory, suggested to Galle that they could compare a recently drawn chart of the sky in the region of Le Verrier's predicted location with the current sky to seek the displacement characteristic of a planet, as opposed to a fixed star	Who was Henrich d'Arrest? 
In the wake of the discovery, there was much nationalistic rivalry between the French and the British over who deserved credit for the discovery	What two countries argued over credit for the discovery of Neptune? 
Claiming the right to name his discovery, Le Verrier quickly proposed the name Neptune for this new planet, though falsely stating that this had been officially approved by the French Bureau des Longitudes	Who claimed the right to name Neptune? 
"However, in Chinese, Japanese, and Korean, the planet's name was translated as ""sea king star"" , because Neptune was the god of the sea"	What is the Chinese, Japanese, and Korean translations for Neptune? 
From its discovery in 1846 until the subsequent discovery of Pluto in 1930, Neptune was the farthest known planet	What was Neptune before Pluto was discovered? 
0243×1026 kg, is intermediate between Earth and the larger gas giants: it is 17 times that of Earth but just 1/19th that of Jupiter	How much more mass does Neptune have compared to Earth? 
The mantle is equivalent to 10 to 15 Earth masses and is rich in water, ammonia and methane	What is Neptune's mantle rich in? 
At high altitudes, Neptune's atmosphere is 80% hydrogen and 19% helium	What is Neptune's atmosphere made of? 
Models suggest that Neptune's troposphere is banded by clouds of varying compositions depending on altitude	What is Neptune's clouds competition variants dependent on? 
High-altitude clouds on Neptune have been observed casting shadows on the opaque cloud deck below	On Neptune, which clouds cast shadows on the cloud deck below it? 
For reasons that remain obscure, the planet's thermosphere is at an anomalously high temperature of about 750 K	What is Neptune's temperature in the thermosphere? 
Neptune also resembles Uranus in its magnetosphere, with a magnetic field strongly tilted relative to its rotational axis at 47° and offset at least 0	What is the rotational axis of Neptune's magnetic field? 
Neptune's magnetic field has a complex geometry that includes relatively large contributions from non-dipolar components, including a strong quadrupole moment that may exceed the dipole moment in strength	What is one of Neptune's non-dipolar component what may exceed the dipole moment in strength? 
Neptune has a planetary ring system, though one much less substantial than that of Saturn	What system, like Saturn, does Neptune have? 
Neptune's weather is characterised by extremely dynamic storm systems, with winds reaching speeds of almost 600 m/s —nearly reaching supersonic flow	What dynamic weather does Neptune have?
In 2007, it was discovered that the upper troposphere of Neptune's south pole was about 10 K warmer than the rest of its atmosphere, which averages approximately 73 K 	How much warmer is Neptune's south pole to the rest of it's atmosphere? 
The Scooter is another storm, a white cloud group farther south than the Great Dark Spot	What white cloud group on Neptune is farther south than the dark great spot?
Neptune's dark spots are thought to occur in the troposphere at lower altitudes than the brighter cloud features, so they appear as holes in the upper cloud decks	Where are Neptune's dark spots thought to occur? 
Neptune's more varied weather when compared to Uranus is due in part to its higher internal heating	Why might Neptune have more varied weather than Uranus?
On 11 July 2011, Neptune completed its first full barycentric orbit since its discovery in 1846, although it did not appear at its exact discovery position in the sky, because Earth was in a different location in its 365	When did Neptune complete it's first barycentric orbit since it's discovery?
Neptune's orbit has a profound impact on the region directly beyond it, known as the Kuiper belt	What is the region behind Neptune called? 
The most heavily populated resonance in the Kuiper belt, with over 200 known objects, is the 2:3 resonance	What is the fraction of the most heavily populated resonance in the Kuiper belt? 
Neptune trojans can be viewed as being in a 1:1 resonance with Neptune	What is the resonance of Neptune trojans?
One is that the ice giants were not formed by core accretion but from instabilities within the original protoplanetary disc and later had their atmospheres blasted away by radiation from a nearby massive OB star	What could have blasted Neptune and Uranus's atmosphere with radiation, aiding in creation? 
An alternative concept is that they formed closer to the Sun, where the matter density was higher, and then subsequently migrated to their current orbits after the removal of the gaseous protoplanetary disc	If Neptune formed closer to the sun, what is the matter density?

In comparison to the principal alternative, the diesel engine, electric railways offer substantially better energy efficiency, lower emissions and lower operating costs	What is the principal alternative to electric railways?
Different regions may use different supply voltages and frequencies, complicating through service	What issue can complicate electric railway service?
Railways must operate at variable speeds	What is speed limit for railways?
Motors have very little room for electrical insulation so they generally have low voltage ratings	Why do motors have little space for insulation?

3 kV DC is used in Belgium, Italy, Spain, Poland, the northern Czech Republic, Slovakia, Slovenia, South Africa, Chile, and former Soviet Union countries 	What voltage is being used in railway system of South Africa and Chile?
Most electrification systems use overhead wires, but third rail is an option up to about 1,200 V	What type is mostly used third rail or overhead wires?

The London Underground in England is one of the few networks that uses a four-rail system	What type of system does London Underground use?
The key advantage of the four-rail system is that neither running rail carries any current	What is the crucial advantage of four-rail system?
On tracks that London Underground share with National Rail third-rail stock , the centre rail is connected to the running rails, allowing both types of train to operate, at a compromise voltage of 660 V	What is the voltage shared two types of trains UK railroad system?
A few lines of the Paris Métro in France operate on a four-rail power scheme because they run on rubber tyres which run on a pair of narrow roadways made of steel and, in some places, concrete	Why some lines of Paris Metro have to operate on a four-rail system?
An early advantage of AC is that the power-wasting resistors used in DC locomotives for speed control were not needed in an AC locomotive: multiple taps on the transformer can supply a range of voltages	What was a disadvantage of DC system?

Summer is the wettest season; almost half of the annual rainfall occurs from June to September in the form of thundershowers	What season is the wettest in Charleston?
The highest temperature recorded within city limits was 104 °F , on June 2, 1985, and June 24, 1944, and the lowest was 7 °F on February 14, 1899, although at the airport, where official records are kept, the historical range is 105 °F on August 1, 1999 down to 6 °F on January 21, 1985	What is hottest temperature recorded with Charleston's city limits?

In addition to the dead and wounded, government leaders feared mass psychological trauma from aerial attack and a resulting collapse of civil society	What was the biggest fear aerial attacks would cause besides death and wounded?
4 million from London	The government planned to evacuate 1.4 million from which city?
Much civil-defence preparation in the form of shelters was left in the hands of local authorities, and many areas such as Birmingham, Coventry, Belfast and the East End of London did not have enough shelters	What civil-defense efforts were left to local authorities to handle?
The government did not build them for large populations before the war because of cost, time to build, and fears that their very safety would cause occupants to refuse to leave to return to work, or that anti-war sentiment would develop in large groups	What kind of sentiment did the government fear would developed in large group shelters? 
Although many civilians had used them as such during the First World War, the government in 1939 refused to allow the stations to be used as shelters so as not to interfere with commuter and troop travel, and the fears that occupants might refuse to leave	Why did the government refuse to allow the London Underground stations to be used as shelters?
Peak use of the Underground as shelter was 177,000 on 27 September 1940, and a November 1940 census of London found that about 4% of residents used the Tube and other large shelters; 9% in public surface shelters; and 27% in private home shelters, implying that the remaining 60% of the city likely stayed at home	What was the largest number to use Underground shelters in September 27, 1940?
Public demand caused the government in October 1940 to build new deep shelters:189–190 within the Underground to hold 80,000 people but were not completed until the period of heaviest bombing had passed	What year did the government start to build new deep shelters?

Public notice is given through legal notices in newspapers, and communicated to state and county agencies within the species' area	How is public notice given regarding a listing?
The provision of the law in Section 4 that establishes critical habitat is a regulatory link between habitat protection and recovery goals, requiring the identification and protection of all lands, water and air necessary to recover endangered species	What section of the Endangered Species Act establishes critical habitat regulations?
"All federal agencies are prohibited from authorizing, funding or carrying out actions that ""destroy or adversely modify"" critical habitats )"	What does the Endangered Species Act detail about government action regarding critical habitats?

Fish and Wildlife Service and National Marine Fisheries Service are required to create an Endangered Species Recovery Plan outlining the goals, tasks required, likely costs, and estimated timeline to recover endangered species (i	What four topics are required in an Endangered Species Recovery Plan?
The question to be answered is whether a listed species will be harmed by the action and, if so, how the harm can be minimized	What is the primary consideration for determining if projects may be carried out in areas with endangered species?

"The ""Safe Harbor"" agreement is a voluntary agreement between the private landowner and FWS"	"What two groups are bound by a ""Safe Harbor"" agreement?"
"The Candidate Conservation Agreement is closely related to the ""Safe Harbor"" agreement, the main difference is that the Candidate Conservation Agreements With Assurances are meant to protect unlisted species by providing incentives to private landowners and land managing agencies to restore, enhance or maintain habitat of unlisted species which are declining and have the potential to become threatened or endangered if critical habitat is not protected"	How does a CCA impact unlisted species?
