As of September 2012, fifty-six species have been delisted; twenty-eight due to recovery, ten due to extinction , ten due to changes in taxonomic classification practices, six due to discovery of new populations, one due to an error in the listing rule, and one due to an amendment to the Endangered Species Act specifically requiring the species delisting	As of September 2012, how many species had been delisted due to recovery?

Aristotle believed that no void could occur naturally, because the denser surrounding material continuum would immediately fill any incipient rarity that might give rise to a void	What did Aristotle believe about a void?

The farmer, or specifically the small landowner-cultivator, was ranked just below scholars and officials in the social hierarchy	Who were considered to be below the social rank that scholars held?

Women were expected to obey the will of their father, then their husband, and then their adult son in old age	Which gender was exempt from performing the yearly corvee labor duties?

During the Eastern Han, conscription could be avoided if one paid a commutable tax	How could conscription into military service be avoided?
The Han dynasty inherited the ban liang coin type from the Qin	Where did the Han dynasty receive their coin type from?
Emperor Wu introduced another in 120 BC, but a year later he abandoned the ban liangs entirely in favor of the wuzhu coin, weighing 3	Who introduced new coinage in the year of 120 BC?
The small landowner-cultivators formed the majority of the Han tax base; this revenue was threatened during the latter half of Eastern Han when many peasants fell into debt and were forced to work as farming tenants for wealthy landlords	Which group made up the bulk of the Han tax base?
To eliminate the influence of such private entrepreneurs, Emperor Wu nationalized the salt and iron industries in 117 BC and allowed many of the former industrialists to become officials administering the monopolies	In which year did Emperor Wu monopolize several industries?
Liquor was another profitable private industry nationalized by the central government in 98 BC	What industry was monopolized by the government in 98 BC?
Evidence suggests that blast furnaces, that convert raw iron ore into pig iron, which can be remelted in a cupola furnace to produce cast iron by means of a cold blast and hot blast, were operational in China by the late Spring and Autumn period 	What type of furnace was functional in China in 722 BC?
The three-legged iron seed drill, invented by the 2nd century BC, enabled farmers to carefully plant crops in rows instead of casting seeds out by hand	What was an invention that allowed farmers to place their crops into rows?
To protect crops from wind and drought, the Grain Intendant Zhao Guo created the alternating fields system during Emperor Wu's reign	What helped insure the safety of crops from wind?
Timber was the chief building material during the Han dynasty; it was used to build palace halls, multi-story residential towers and halls and single-story houses	What building material was used primarily during the Han dynasty?
Monumental stone pillar-gates, twenty-nine of which survive from the Han period, formed entrances of walled enclosures at shrine and tomb sites	How many stone pillar-gates survive from the Han era?
Evidence of Han-era mechanical engineering comes largely from the choice observational writings of sometimes disinterested Confucian scholars	What type of scholars have provided proof that mechanical engineering was prominent during the Han period?
Modern archaeology has led to the discovery of Han artwork portraying inventions which were otherwise absent in Han literary sources	During which period was the odometer cart first created?
Waterwheels were also used to power chain pumps that lifted water to raised irrigation ditches	What was used to power chain pumps to raise water to irrigation ditches?
Using a water clock, waterwheel and a series of gears, the Court Astronomer Zhang Heng was able to mechanically rotate his metal-ringed armillary sphere	Who was responsible for the invention of the seismometer?
Three Han mathematical treatises still exist	What type of treatise is the Book on Numbers and Computation considered to be?
Negative numbers first appeared in the Nine Chapters on the Mathematical Art as black counting rods, where positive numbers were represented by red counting rods	In what treatise did negative numbers first appear?
Han-era astronomers adopted a geocentric model of the universe, theorizing that it was shaped like a sphere surrounding the earth in the center	In what era was a geocentric view of the universe adopted?
Some of the earliest Han maps discovered were ink-penned silk maps found amongst the Mawangdui Silk Texts in a 2nd-century-BC tomb	What textile were some of the early Han maps made from?
The junk design was developed and realized during Han	What type of boat design was first invented during the Han era?
Han-era medical physicians believed that the human body was subject to the same forces of nature that governed the greater universe, namely the cosmological cycles of yin and yang and the five phases	Who believed that the same forces that controlled the universe also controlled the human body?
Muslims believe the Quran was verbally revealed by God to Muhammad through the angel Gabriel , gradually over a period of approximately 23 years, beginning on 22 December 609 CE, when Muhammad was 40, and concluding in 632, the year of his death	Which angel is believed to have communicated the Quran to Muhammad?
According to the traditional narrative, several companions of Muhammad served as scribes and were responsible for writing down the revelations	Who first recorded Muhammad revelations?
During prayers, the Quran is recited only in Arabic	In which language is the Quran spoken during prayer?
"It is a verbal noun of the Arabic verb qaraʼa , meaning ""he read"" or ""he recited"""	"From which Arabic verb might ""Quran"" be derived?"
Such terms include kitāb ; āyah ; and sūrah 	"Which term used in the Quran to indicate itself means ""book""?"

The Sana'a manuscripts contain palimpsests, a manuscript page from which the text has been washed off to make the parchment reusable again—a practice which was common in ancient times due to scarcity of writing material	What is the term for recycled parchments used in ancient manuscripts?

The Quran consists of 114 chapters of varying lengths, each known as a sura	What is a chapter of the Quran called?
The 30 juz' can be used to read through the entire Quran in a month	What division of the Quran is used for a month-long reading?

"The language of the Quran has been described as ""rhymed prose"" as it partakes of both poetry and prose; however, this description runs the risk of failing to convey the rhythmic quality of Quranic language, which is more poetic in some parts and more prose-like in others"	What description of the writing in the Quran highlights its poetic aspect?
The textual arrangement is sometimes considered to exhibit lack of continuity, absence of any chronological or thematic order and repetitiousness	What is lacking in the arrangement of the Quranic text?
"Self-referentiality is evident in those passages where the Quran refers to itself as revelation , remembrance , news , criterion in a self-designating manner (explicitly asserting its Divinity, ""And this is a blessed Remembrance that We have sent down; so are you now denying it"	What metatextual character does Stefan Wild focus on in his discussion of the Quran?
Tafsir is one of the earliest academic activities of Muslims	What is the name of the activity of explaining what Quranic verses mean?
Because the Quran is spoken in classical Arabic, many of the later converts to Islam did not always understand the Quranic Arabic, they did not catch allusions that were clear to early Muslims fluent in Arabic and they were concerned with reconciling apparent conflict of themes in the Quran	In which language is the Quran recited?
Esoteric or Sufi interpretation attempts to unveil the inner meanings of the Quran	What is another term for Sufi Quranic interpretation?

Robert of Ketton's 1143 translation of the Quran for Peter the Venerable, Lex Mahumet pseudoprophete, was the first into a Western language 	In which year was the Quran first translated into a Western language?
The proper recitation of the Quran is the subject of a separate discipline named tajwid which determines in detail how the Quran should be recited, how each individual syllable is to be pronounced, the need to pay attention to the places where there should be a pause, to elisions, where the pronunciation should be long or short, where letters should be sounded together and where they should be kept separate, etc	What discipline concerns the way the Quran is correctly recited?
Vocalization markers indicating specific vowel sounds were introduced into the Arabic language by the end of the 9th century	The absence of which language feature made early Quranic recitation more diverse?

The Great Plains lie west of the Mississippi River and east of the Rocky Mountains	What area is located in between the Mississippi River and the Rocky Mountains?

The Intermontane Plateaus come to an end at the Cascade Range and the Sierra Nevada	What is the name of the range where the Intermontane plateaus end?
These areas contain some spectacular scenery as well, as evidenced by such national parks as Yosemite and Mount Rainier	What are two national parks located in the mountainous regions?

The east coast Appalachian system, originally forest covered, is relatively low and narrow and is bordered on the southeast and south by an important coastal plain	What originally covered the east coast of the Appalachians?

The climate is temperate in most areas, subtropical in the Southern United States, tropical in Hawaii and southern Florida, polar in Alaska, semiarid in the Great Plains west of the 100th meridian, Mediterranean in coastal California and arid in the Great Basin	What is the climate like in the Southern United States?
The Great Basin and Columbia Plateau are arid or semiarid regions that lie in the rain shadow of the Cascades and Sierra Nevada	Which areas have arid regions?
Much of California consists of a Mediterranean climate, with sometimes excessive rainfall from October–April and nearly no rain the rest of the year	What is the most prevalent type of climate nCalifornia?

In the east, while snowfall does not approach western levels, the region near the Great Lakes and the mountains of the Northeast receive the most	Which regions in the East receives the most amount of snowfall?
, tornadoes are more common than anywhere else on Earth and touch down most commonly in the spring and summer	During which seasons are tornados most common?

Audio CDs and audio CD players have been commercially available since October 1982	When did Audio CDs become available for purchase?
In 2014, revenues from digital music services matched those from physical format sales for the first time	In what year were digital and physical music sales the same?
Prototypes were developed by Philips and Sony independently in the late 1970s	Who created Compact Disc prototypes in the 1970s?
In 1977, Philips then established a laboratory with the mission of creating a digital audio disc	In what year did Philips institute a laboratory to create a digital audio disc?
Technical details of Sony's digital audio disc were presented during the 62nd AES Convention, held on 13–16 March 1979, in Brussels	Where was the 62nd AES Convention held?
As a result, in 1979, Sony and Philips set up a joint task force of engineers to design a new digital audio disc	In what year did Sony and Philips band together to design a new digital audio disc?
The first artist to sell a million copies on CD was Dire Straits, with their 1985 album Brothers in Arms	Who first sold a million copies on CD?
In June 1985, the computer-readable CD-ROM and, in 1990, CD-Recordable were introduced, also developed by both Sony and Philips	What does ROM stand for?
As of 2012, CDs and DVDs made up only 34 percent of music sales in the United States	What portion of music sales did CDs and DVDs account for in the United States as of 2012?
Replicated CDs are mass-produced initially using a hydraulic press	How are CDs mass produced?
After a metallic reflecting layer is applied to the clear blank substrate, the disc goes under a UV light for curing and it is ready to go to press	What materials can be used to make the reflective layer on a CD?
The die is a negative image of the glass master: typically, several are made, depending on the number of pressing mills that are to make the CD	What is the term for a negative image of the glass master?
The most expensive part of a CD is the jewel case	What is the priciest component of a CD?
The design life is from 20 to 100 years, depending on the quality of the discs, the quality of the writing drive, and storage conditions	How long are CDs expected to last?
These consumer audio CD recorders use the Serial Copy Management System , an early form of digital rights management , to conform to the United States' Audio Home Recording Act 	What does SCMS stand for?
Due to technical limitations, the original ReWritable CD could be written no faster than 4x speed	How fast could the first ReWritable CD be written?
In order to accommodate the spiral pattern of data, the semiconductor laser is placed on a swing arm within the disc tray of any CD player	Where is the semiconductor laser found in a CD player?
Instead, non-return-to-zero, inverted encoding is used: a change from pit to land or land to pit indicates a one, while no change indicates a series of zeros	What type of encoding do CDs implement?
Consequently, CDs are more likely to suffer damage on the label side of the disc	Where can one expect to find damage on a disc?
The digital data on a CD begins at the center of the disc and proceeds toward the edge, which allows adaptation to the different size formats available	Where is the start of data on a CD?
The document is known colloquially as the Red Book CD-DA after the colour of its cover	Where does the Red Book get it's name from?

A transistor is a semiconductor device used to amplify or switch electronic signals and electrical power	What is the use of a transistor?
First conceived by Julius Lilienfeld in 1926 and practically implemented in 1947 by American physicists John Bardeen, Walter Brattain, and William Shockley, the transistor revolutionized the field of electronics, and paved the way for smaller and cheaper radios, calculators, and computers, among other things	When was the first transistor created?
The thermionic triode, a vacuum tube invented in 1907, enabled amplified radio technology and long-distance telephony	When was the thermionic triode invented?
From November 17, 1947 to December 23, 1947, John Bardeen and Walter Brattain at AT&T's Bell Labs in the United States performed experiments and observed that when two gold point contacts were applied to a crystal of germanium, a signal was produced with the output power greater than the input	At what time did Bardeen and Brattain experiment on increasing signal output?
In 1948, the point-contact transistor was independently invented by German physicists Herbert Mataré and Heinrich Welker while working at the Compagnie des Freins et Signaux, a Westinghouse subsidiary located in Paris	In what year was the point-contact transistor invented?
A logic gate consists of up to about twenty transistors whereas an advanced microprocessor, as of 2009, can use as many as 3 billion transistors 	How many transistors make up a logic gate?
This property is called gain	Why is a transistor so useful?
There are two types of transistors, which have slight differences in how they are used in a circuit	How many types of transistors are there?
The collector voltage drops because of reduced resistance from collector to emitter	Why does the collector voltage drop in grounded-emitter transistor circuits?
Providing sufficient base drive current is a key problem in the use of bipolar transistors as switches	What is a major problem with using bipolar transistors as switches?
"Parameters are chosen such that the ""off"" output is limited to leakage currents too small to affect connected circuitry; the resistance of the transistor in the ""on"" state is too small to affect circuitry; and the transition between the two states is fast enough not to have a detrimental effect"	How are parameters chosen in a switching circuit?
Bipolar transistors are so named because they conduct by using both majority and minority carriers	What gives bipolar transistors their name?
BJTs have three terminals, corresponding to the three layers of semiconductor—an emitter, a base, and a collector	How many terminals do BJTs have?
The conductivity is varied by the electric field that is produced when a voltage is applied between the gate and source terminals; hence the current flowing between the drain and source is controlled by the voltage applied between the gate and source	What determines the conductivity in a FET?
FETs are divided into two families: junction FET and insulated gate FET 	How many groups are FETs split into?
FETs are further divided into depletion-mode and enhancement-mode types, depending on whether the channel is turned on or off with zero gate-to-source voltage	How are FET's separated?
The bipolar junction transistor was the most commonly used transistor in the 1960s and 70s	What was the most frequently used transistor in the 1960s and 70s?
The Pro Electron standard, the European Electronic Component Manufacturers Association part numbering scheme, begins with two letters: the first gives the semiconductor type ; the second letter denotes the intended use (A for diode, C for general-purpose transistor, etc	What is the Pro Electron standard?
"The JEDEC EIA370 transistor device numbers usually start with ""2N"", indicating a three-terminal device , then a 2, 3 or 4-digit sequential number with no significance as to device properties "	What does the JEDEC EIA370 transistor number start with?
3	What is the most common amount of extra digits in a device number?
Since devices are second-sourced, a manufacturer's prefix now is an unreliable indicator of who made the device	What was once an indicator of the devices creator?
The junction forward voltage is the voltage applied to the emitter–base junction of a BJT in order to make the base conduct a specified current	What is the junction forward voltage?
Because the electron mobility is higher than the hole mobility for all semiconductor materials, a given bipolar n–p–n transistor tends to be swifter than an equivalent p–n–p transistor	What is quicker, a bipolar n-p-n transistor or a p-n-p transistor?
Discrete transistors are individually packaged transistors	What is a discrete transistor?

The Scientific Revolution was a period when European ideas in classical physics, astronomy, biology, human anatomy, chemistry, and other classical sciences were rejected and led to doctrines supplanting those that had prevailed from Ancient Greece to the Middle Ages which would lead to a transition to modern science	What s the Scientific Revolution?

The American Revolution begun with fighting at Lexington and Concord	Where did the American Revolution start?

An antenna , or aerial, is an electrical device which converts electric power into radio waves, and vice versa	What device is able to change electric powerinto radio waves and also do the reverse?
Typically an antenna consists of an arrangement of metallic conductors , electrically connected to the receiver or transmitter	What is frequently used to connect elements to the receiver?
The words antenna and aerial are used interchangeably	What is an acceptable synonym for antenna?
The origin of the word antenna relative to wireless apparatus is attributed to Italian radio pioneer Guglielmo Marconi	Who is most associated with the emergence of the word antenna?
Antennas are required by any radio receiver or transmitter to couple its electrical connection to the electromagnetic field	What is essential for the mating of the elements that create radio waves?
One example of omnidirectional antennas is the very common vertical antenna or whip antenna consisting of a metal rod 	What is the main element of an omnidirectional antenna?
Both the vertical and dipole antennas are simple in construction and relatively inexpensive	Are basic antennas expensive?
Antennas more complex than the dipole or vertical designs are usually intended to increase the directivity and consequently the gain of the antenna	What are different designs aimed at increasing?
For instance, a phased array consists of two or more simple antennas which are connected together through an electrical network	How many antenna would make up a phased array?
However a log-periodic dipole array consists of a number of dipole elements of different lengths in order to obtain a somewhat directional antenna having an extremely wide bandwidth: these are frequently used for television reception in fringe areas	What type of antenna formation is made up of multiple dipole elements of varying lengths?
At low frequencies , arrays of vertical towers are used to achieve directionality and they will occupy large areas of land	For radio broadcast that one would hear in their car what type of towers are used?
An antenna lead-in is the transmission line which connects the antenna to a transmitter or receiver	What is mainly responsible for the connection of the antenna to its end destinations?
Monopole antennas consist of a single radiating element such as a metal rod, often mounted over a conducting surface, a ground plane	Monopole antennas consist of what element?
The most widely used class of antenna, a dipole antenna consists of two symmetrical radiators such as metal rods or wires, with one side of the balanced feedline from the transmitter or receiver attached to each	What is the most widley used antenna class?
A necessary condition for the aforementioned reciprocity property is that the materials in the antenna and transmission medium are linear and reciprocal	What must be true of the antenna and transmission medium for the repiprocity rule to apply ?
Antennas are characterized by a number of performance measures which a user would be concerned with in selecting or designing an antenna for a particular application	How could one deide what type of antenna is nedded for a project?
Resonant antennas are expected to be used around a particular resonant frequency; an antenna must therefore be built or ordered to match the frequency range of the intended application	Which antenna type would be best for a project requiring a specific frequency?
An antenna transmits and receives radio waves with a particular polarization which can be reoriented by tilting the axis of the antenna in many cases	What is the essential difference in radio waves transmitted by an antenna?
The majority of antenna designs are based on the resonance principle	What is the basis for the way most antennas are developed?
The radio signal's electrical component induces a voltage in the conductor	What part of the radio signal creates voltage?
The ordinary half-wave dipole is probably the most widely used antenna design	What is the most popular antenna type?
The standing wave forms with this desired pattern at the design frequency, f0, and antennas are normally designed to be this size	What frequency are antennas normally designed to be?
The quarter-wave elements imitate a series-resonant electrical element due to the standing wave present along the conductor	How do quarter wave elements act in relation to a series relevant electrical element?
By adding an inductance in series with the antenna, a so-called loading coil, the capacitive reactance of this antenna can be cancelled leaving a pure resistance which can then be matched to the transmission line	What could be coupled with an antenna to form pure resistance?
The end result is that the resonant antenna will efficiently feed a signal into the transmission line only when the source signal's frequency is close to that of the design frequency of the antenna, or one of the resonant multiples	 If your were unable to match the source frequency with the design frequency of the antenna what could you use?
The amount of signal received from a distant transmission source is essentially geometric in nature due to the inverse square law, and this leads to the concept of effective area	What accounts for the geometry involved in the use of an antenna?
Returning to the basic concept of current flows in a conductor, consider what happens if a half-wave dipole is not connected to a feed point, but instead shorted out	What is a half wave dipole need to be coupled with in most instances?
A Yagi-Uda array uses passive elements to greatly increase gain	What can take advantage of these elements to add more gain?
It is also possible to use multiple active elements and combine them together with transmission lines to produce a similar system where the phases add up to reinforce the output	What can be paired with transmission lines to create phases that would support output?
Reflection of the original signal also occurs when it hits an extended conductive surface, in a fashion similar to a mirror	If you wanted to somehow clone the original signal you could use?
Resonating such an inductor with a capacitor at the frequency of operation not only cancels the reactance but greatly magnifies the very small radiation resistance of such a loop	What magnifies the small radiation resistance of a loop?
Antenna tuning generally refers to cancellation of any reactance seen at the antenna terminals, leaving only a resistive impedance which might or might not be exactly the desired impedance 	Where does cancellation of any reactance seen?
Although a resonant antenna has a purely resistive feed-point impedance at a particular frequency, many applications require using an antenna over a range of frequencies	What type of antenna has impedance at a specific frequency?
It turns out that the amount of reactance seen at the terminals of a resonant antenna when the frequency is shifted, say, by 5%, depends very much on the diameter of the conductor used	What characteristic would be better if it were steady?
Rather than just using a thick tube, there are similar techniques used to the same effect such as replacing thin wire elements with cages to simulate a thicker element	What type of tubes are generally used for sturdier always of antennas?
A high-gain antenna will radiate most of its power in a particular direction, while a low-gain antenna will radiate over a wider angle	What is an acknowledgement of the range of possible direction for and antenna?
High-gain antennas have the advantage of longer range and better signal quality, but must be aimed carefully at the other antenna	Antennas with higher gain have what positive feature?
Due to reciprocity the gain of an antenna used for transmitting must be proportional to its effective area when used for receiving	What must the relationship of an antenna and the receiving area be due to reciprocity?
The radiation pattern of an antenna is a plot of the relative field strength of the radio waves emitted by the antenna at different angles	A plot of the radiation behaviors of an antenna would show what?
"The radiation of many antennas shows a pattern of maxima or ""lobes"" at various angles, separated by ""nulls"", angles where the radiation falls to zero"	What is the term that refers to areas where an antennas radiation is zero? 
As an electro-magnetic wave travels through the different parts of the antenna system it may encounter differences in impedance (E/H, V/I, etc	What is one piece that makes up an antenna system?
Efficiency of a transmitting antenna is the ratio of power actually radiated to the power absorbed by the antenna terminals	A measure of the power that is useable and the power absorbed by the terminals?
For instance, if a transmitter delivers 100 W into an antenna having an efficiency of 80%, then the antenna will radiate 80 W as radio waves and produce 20 W of heat	What would need to be placed into the transmitter to create ten W oh warmth? 
However loss resistance will generally affect the feedpoint impedance, adding to its resistive component	What can increase the feedpoint impedance of a component?
According to reciprocity, the efficiency of an antenna used as a receiving antenna is identical to the efficiency as defined above	In what type of programs would low efficiency antennas not make a difference in effectiveness?
The definition of antenna gain or power gain already includes the effect of the antenna's efficiency	What else is also known as power gain?
This is fortunate, since antennas at lower frequencies which are not rather large are inevitably inefficient 	Small and minimal frequency antennas are know to be what?
The polarization of an antenna refers to the orientation of the electric field of the radio wave with respect to the Earth's surface and is determined by the physical structure of the antenna and by its orientation; note that this designation is totally distinct from the antenna's directionality	What is another name for electric-field?
Reflections generally affect polarization	What mostly affects polarization?
Polarization is predictable from an antenna's geometry, although in some cases it is not at all obvious 	Whats predictable about an antenna's geometry?
Polarization is the sum of the E-plane orientations over time projected onto an imaginary plane perpendicular to the direction of motion of the radio wave	What are electrical fields projected on to?
It is best for the receiving antenna to match the polarization of the transmitted wave for optimum reception	What is the best for an recieving antenna for optimum reception?
Maximum power transfer requires matching the impedance of an antenna system to the complex conjugate of the impedance of the receiver or transmitter	What requires matching of the empedance to an antenna system?

"Pain is a distressing feeling often caused by intense or damaging stimuli, such as stubbing a toe, burning a finger, putting alcohol on a cut, and bumping the ""funny bone"""	What type of stimuli causes pain?
Pain is the most common reason for physician consultation in most developed countries	What is the most common reason people go to the doctor in first world countries?
In 1994, responding to the need for a more useful system for describing chronic pain, the International Association for the Study of Pain classified pain according to specific characteristics: region of the body involved (e	What year did the IASP respond to the need to create a more useful system for describing pain?
Pain is usually transitory, lasting only until the noxious stimulus is removed or the underlying damage or pathology has healed, but some painful conditions, such as rheumatoid arthritis, peripheral neuropathy, cancer and idiopathic pain, may persist for years	What is usually temporary?
Nociceptive pain is caused by stimulation of peripheral nerve fibers that respond to stimuli approaching or exceeding harmful intensity , and may be classified according to the mode of noxious stimulation	Stimulating nociceptors will induce which type of pain?
"Nociceptive pain may also be divided into ""visceral"", ""deep somatic"" and ""superficial somatic"" pain"	What type of of pain is visceral a division of?
The prevalence of phantom pain in upper limb amputees is nearly 82%, and in lower limb amputees is 54%	What percentage of people who've had upper limbs amputated feel phantom pain?
Local anesthetic injections into the nerves or sensitive areas of the stump may relieve pain for days, weeks, or sometimes permanently, despite the drug wearing off in a matter of hours; and small injections of hypertonic saline into the soft tissue between vertebrae produces local pain that radiates into the phantom limb for ten minutes or so and may be followed by hours, weeks or even longer of partial or total relief from phantom pain	What happens when an anesthetic injection is directed into the nerves a limb stump?
Paraplegia, the loss of sensation and voluntary motor control after serious spinal cord damage, may be accompanied by girdle pain at the level of the spinal cord damage, visceral pain evoked by a filling bladder or bowel, or, in five to ten per cent of paraplegics, phantom body pain in areas of complete sensory loss	What is paraplegia?
People with long-term pain frequently display psychological disturbance, with elevated scores on the Minnesota Multiphasic Personality Inventory scales of hysteria, depression and hypochondriasis 	When people have long-term pain, what do they frequently display?

"A much smaller number of people are insensitive to pain due to an inborn abnormality of the nervous system, known as ""congenital insensitivity to pain"""	An abnormality of the nervous system can render a small number of people insensitive to what?
In 1644, René Descartes theorized that pain was a disturbance that passed down along nerve fibers until the disturbance reached the brain, a development that transformed the perception of pain from a spiritual, mystical experience to a physical, mechanical sensation	When was Descartes pontificating about his theories regarding pain?
In 1955, DC Sinclair and G Weddell developed peripheral pattern theory, based on a 1934 suggestion by John Paul Nafe	What year was peripheral pattern theory developed? 
"In 1968 Ronald Melzack and Kenneth Casey described pain in terms of its three dimensions: ""sensory-discriminative"" , ""affective-motivational"" , and ""cognitive-evaluative"" "	How many dimensions did Melzack and Casey describe pain in terms of?
"Wilhelm Erb's ""intensive"" theory, that a pain signal can be generated by intense enough stimulation of any sensory receptor, has been soundly disproved"	What type of signal can be generated by intense enough stimulation of any sensory receptor?
The pain signal travels from the periphery to the spinal cord along an A-delta or C fiber	How does the pain signal travel from the periphery to the spinal cord?
Spinal cord fibers dedicated to carrying A-delta fiber pain signals, and others that carry both A-delta and C fiber pain signals up the spinal cord to the thalamus in the brain have been identified	What are some spinal cord fibers exclusive to?
In his book, The Greatest Show on Earth: The Evidence for Evolution, biologist Richard Dawkins grapples with the question of why pain has to be so very painful	"Who wrote ""The Greatest Show on Earth: The Evidence for Evolution""?"

When a person is non-verbal and cannot self-report pain, observation becomes critical, and specific behaviors can be monitored as pain indicators	What become critical when a person is non-verbal?

A database management system is a computer software application that interacts with the user, other applications, and the database itself to capture and analyze data	What does DBMS stand for?
"Access to these data is usually provided by a ""database management system"" consisting of an integrated set of computer software that allows users to interact with one or more databases and provides access to all of the data contained in the database "	How is data accessed?
Database servers are usually multiprocessor computers, with generous memory and RAID disk arrays used for stable storage	What is used to recover data if disks suffer a failure?
A DBMS has evolved into a complex software system and its development typically requires thousands of human years of development effort	How long can it take to create a DBMS?
Many other databases have application software that accesses the database on behalf of end-users, without exposing the DBMS interface directly	How are many databases accessed?
Codd, departed from this tradition by insisting that applications should search for data by content, rather than by following links	Instead of using links, how was information found in a relational model?
As computers grew in speed and capability, a number of general-purpose database systems emerged; by the mid-1960s a number of such systems had come into commercial use	When were DBMSs first used commercially?
IBM also had their own DBMS in 1966, known as Information Management System 	What was the DBMS created by IBM called?
"Instead of records being stored in some sort of linked list of free-form records as in CODASYL, Codd's idea was to use a ""table"" of fixed-length records, with each table used for a different type of entity"	Who proposed using a table to store data?
The relational model also allowed the content of the database to evolve without constant rewriting of links and pointers	How was the relational model able to improve over time?
For instance, a common use of a database system is to track information about users, their name, login information, various addresses and phone numbers	How is a database system frequently used?
"In the relational model, some bit of information was used as a ""key"", uniquely defining a particular record"	How is information accessed in a relational model?
Just as the navigational approach would require programs to loop in order to collect records, the relational approach would require loops to collect information about any one record	How does a program collect information using a navigational system?

 XML databases are a type of structured document-oriented database that allows querying based on XML document attributes	What kind of database is XML?
In recent years there was a high demand for massively distributed databases with high partition tolerance but according to the CAP theorem it is impossible for a distributed system to simultaneously provide consistency, availability and partition tolerance guarantees	What explains the difficulty in a system containing availability, consistency, and partition tolerance guarantees?
The first task of a database designer is to produce a conceptual data model that reflects the structure of the information to be held in the database	What should a conceptual data model do?
Having produced a conceptual data model that users are happy with, the next stage is to translate this into a schema that implements the relevant data structures within the database	In what form is the output of a logical database design?
The final stage of database design is to make the decisions that affect performance, scalability, recovery, security, and the like	What decisions must be made in the last stage of database design?
While there is typically only one conceptual and physical view of the data, there can be any number of different external views	How many conceptual or physical views of data are there?
The conceptual view provides a level of indirection between internal and external	What does the conceptual view offer?
Putting data into permanent storage is generally the responsibility of the database engine a	What is responsible for putting information into permanent storage?
, record types, specific records, data structures), certain computations over certain objects (e	What are examples of database objects?

Armenia is a unitary, multi-party, democratic nation-state with an ancient cultural heritage	What kind of government does Armenia have?
Between the 16th century and 19th century, the traditional Armenian homeland composed of Eastern Armenia and Western Armenia came under the rule of the Ottoman and successive Iranian empires, repeatedly ruled by either of the two over the centuries	Which two empires ruled Armenia between the 16 and 19th Century?
According to the histories of both Moses of Chorene and Michael Chamchian, Armenia derives from the name of Aram, a lineal descendant of Hayk	What name did Armenia gain it's name from?
A large cuneiform lapidary inscription found in Yerevan established that the modern capital of Armenia was founded in the summer of 782 BC by King Argishti I	When was the capital of Armenia established?
The kingdom became fully sovereign from the sphere of influence of the Seleucid Empire in 190 BC under King Artaxias I and begun the rule of the Artaxiad dynasty	Under who did Areminia become fully sovereign?
In the next centuries, Armenia was in the Persian Empire's sphere of influence during the reign of Tiridates I, the founder of the Arsacid dynasty of Armenia, which itself was a branch of the eponymous Arsacid dynasty of Parthia	Who established the Arsacid dynasty of Armenia?
After the Marzpanate period , Armenia emerged as the Emirate of Armenia, an autonomous principality within the Arabic Empire, reuniting Armenian lands previously taken by the Byzantine Empire as well	When was the Marzpanate era?
In 1045, the Byzantine Empire conquered Bagratid Armenia	Who vanquished Bagratid Armenia?
In the early 12th century, Armenian princes of the Zakarid noble family drove out the Seljuk Turks and established a semi-independent Armenian principality in Northern and Eastern Armenia, known as Zakarid Armenia, which lasted under the patronage of the Georgian Kingdom	Which family overthrew the Seljuk Turks?
In the 16th century, the Ottoman Empire and Safavid Empire divided Armenia	Which empires seperated Armenia?
When they began pushing for more rights within the Ottoman Empire, Sultan ‘Abdu’l-Hamid II, in response, organized state-sponsored massacres against the Armenians between 1894 and 1896, resulting in an estimated death toll of 80,000 to 300,000 people	How many Armenians were slaughtered between 1894-1896
During the 1890s, the Armenian Revolutionary Federation, commonly known as Dashnaktsutyun, became active within the Ottoman Empire with the aim of unifying the various small groups in the empire that were advocating for reform and defending Armenian villages from massacres that were widespread in some of the Armenian-populated areas of the empire	What is another name for the Armenian Revolutionary Federation?
In April 1909, the Adana massacre occurred in the Adana Vilayet of the Ottoman Empire resulting in the deaths of as many as 20,000–30,000 Armenians	When did the Adana massacre take place?
When World War I broke out leading to confrontation between the Ottoman Empire and the Russian Empire in the Caucasus and Persian Campaigns, the new government in Istanbul began to look on the Armenians with distrust and suspicion	What instigated conflict between the Ottoman and Russian Empire?
The events of 1915 to 1917 are regarded by Armenians and the vast majority of Western historians to have been state-sponsored mass killings, or genocide	What do the Armenians see the events of 1915-1917 as?
Toynbee, an estimated 600,000 Armenians died during deportation from 1915–16)	How many Armenians died during the second phase of the Armenian Genocide between 1915-1916??
Although the Russian Caucasus Army of Imperial forces commanded by Nikolai Yudenich and Armenians in volunteer units and Armenian militia led by Andranik Ozanian and Tovmas Nazarbekian succeeded in gaining most of Ottoman Armenia during World War I, their gains were lost with the Bolshevik Revolution of 1917	Who was in charge of the Russian Caucasus Army of Imperial forces?
Signed between the Allied and Associated Powers and Ottoman Empire at Sèvres on 10 August 1920, the Treaty of Sèvres promised to maintain the existence of the Armenian republic and to attach the former territories of Ottoman Armenia to it	When was the Treaty of Sevres signed?
The violent conflict finally concluded with the Treaty of Alexandropol on 2 December 1920	When was the Treaty of Alexandropol sanctioned?
Armenia was annexed by Bolshevist Russia and along with Georgia and Azerbaijan, it was incorporated into the Soviet Union as part of the Transcaucasian SFSR on 4 March 1922	When was the Transcaucasian SFSR formed?
After the death of Vladimir Lenin, Joseph Stalin took the reins of power and began an era of renewed fear and terror for Armenians	Who succeeded Vladimir Lenin?
Fears decreased when Stalin died in 1953 and Nikita Khruschev emerged as the Soviet Union's new leader	Who succeeded Stalin?
About 484,000 Armenians lived in Azerbaijan in 1970	How man Armenians resided in Azerbaijan in 1970?
In May 1990, the New Armenian Army was established, serving as a defence force separate from the Soviet Red Army	What does NAA stand for?
Further firefights between Armenian militiamen and Soviet troops occurred in Sovetashen, near the capital and resulted in the deaths of over 26 people, mostly Armenians	Continued fighting transpired between the Armenians and Soviets in which city?
In 1993, Turkey joined the blockade against Armenia in support of Azerbaijan	When did Turkey decide to become part of the blockade against Armenia?
The Karabakh war ended after a Russian-brokered cease-fire was put in place in 1994	When did the Karabakh War end?

In addition, the effects of the 1988 Spitak earthquake, which killed more than 25,000 people and made 500,000 homeless, are still being felt	How many people died because of the Spitak earthquake?

In addition, 35% of eligible children attended preschools	What percent of Armenian children go to preschool?

Bacteria constitute a large domain of prokaryotic microorganisms	What is a large domain of prokaryotic microorganisms?
There are typically 40 million bacterial cells in a gram of soil and a million bacterial cells in a millilitre of fresh water	What amount of bacteria can be found in a gram of soil?
There are approximately ten times as many bacterial cells in the human flora as there are human cells in the body, with the largest number of the human flora being in the gut flora, and a large number on the skin	What is the ratio of human/bacteria cells in human flora?
Once regarded as plants constituting the class Schizomycetes, bacteria are now classified as prokaryotes	What living organisms are bacteria being reffered as?
The ancestors of modern bacteria were unicellular microorganisms that were the first forms of life to appear on Earth, about 4 billion years ago	When did the first antecedents of bacteria appear on Earth?
Bacteria display a wide diversity of shapes and sizes, called morphologies	What is the common name for shapes and forms of bacteria?
Most bacterial species are either spherical, called cocci (sing	What shape does usually cocci type of bacteria can be?
"Many bacterial species exist simply as single cells, others associate in characteristic patterns: Neisseria form diploids , Streptococcus form chains, and Staphylococcus group together in ""bunch of grapes"" clusters"	What is the usual form for Neiserria bacteria?
Bacteria often attach to surfaces and form dense aggregations called biofilms or bacterial mats	What does bacteria use to adhere to surfaces?
For example, when starved of amino acids, Myxobacteria detect surrounding cells in a process known as quorum sensing, migrate toward each other, and aggregate to form fruiting bodies up to 500 micrometres long and containing approximately 100,000 bacterial cells	What is the vital nutriment for Myxobacteria?
The bacterial cell is surrounded by a cell membrane 	What is a cell membrane?
Many important biochemical reactions, such as energy generation, use concentration gradients across membranes	What is crucial for biochemical reactions?
Bacteria do not have a membrane-bound nucleus, and their genetic material is typically a single circular DNA chromosome located in the cytoplasm in an irregularly shaped body called the nucleoid	What is genetic make of bacteria?
Some bacteria produce intracellular nutrient storage granules for later use, such as glycogen, polyphosphate, sulfur or polyhydroxyalkanoates	What types of intracellar nutrient can bacteria produce?
The cell membrane and cell wall comprise the cell envelope	What composes the cell envelope?
Gram-positive bacteria possess a thick cell wall containing many layers of peptidoglycan and teichoic acids	What does gram-positive bacteria have?
The high mycolic acid content of Mycobacteria, is responsible for the staining pattern of poor absorption followed by high retention	What helps Mycobacteria be resistant to decolorization?
Fimbriae are fine filaments of protein, usually 2–10 nanometres in diameter and up to several micrometers in length	What are fimbriae?
Certain genera of Gram-positive bacteria, such as Bacillus, Clostridium, Sporohalobacter, Anaerobacter, and Heliobacterium, can form highly resistant, dormant structures called endospores	What are highly resistant dormant structures of certain gram-positive bacteria called?
Endospores show no detectable metabolism and can survive extreme physical and chemical stresses, such as high levels of UV light, gamma radiation, detergents, disinfectants, heat, freezing, pressure, and desiccation	Is there a metabolism in endospores?
The distribution of metabolic traits within a group of bacteria has traditionally been used to define their taxonomy, but these traits often do not correspond with modern genetic classifications	What is commonly used to determine taxonomy of bacteria?
Carbon metabolism in bacteria is either heterotrophic, where organic carbon compounds are used as carbon sources, or autotrophic, meaning that cellular carbon is obtained by fixing carbon dioxide	How does heterotrophic carbon metabolism occur?
Bacteria are further divided into lithotrophs that use inorganic electron donors and organotrophs that use organic compounds as electron donors	What do lithotrophs use ?
These processes are also important in biological responses to pollution; for example, sulfate-reducing bacteria are largely responsible for the production of the highly toxic forms of mercury in the environment	What is sulfate-reducing bacteria accountable for?
Common inorganic electron donors are hydrogen, carbon monoxide, ammonia , ferrous iron and other reduced metal ions, and several reduced sulfur compounds	What are hydrogen and carbon monoxide for Lithotrophic bacteria?
Regardless of the type of metabolic process they employ, the majority of bacteria are able to take in raw materials only in the form of relatively small molecules, which enter the cell by diffusion or through molecular channels in cell membranes	How can bacteria obtain raw materials from the environment?
Bacteria grow to a fixed size and then reproduce through binary fission, a form of asexual reproduction	How size and reproduction are linked in bacteria?
In the laboratory, bacteria are usually grown using solid or liquid media	In what environment are bacteria being cultivated in labs?
Most laboratory techniques for growing bacteria use high levels of nutrients to produce large amounts of cells cheaply and quickly	What is the simple way of producing large volume of bacteria cells?
Bacterial growth follows four phases	How many phase are in the growth of bacteria?
Most bacteria have a single circular chromosome that can range in size from only 160,000 base pairs in the endosymbiotic bacteria Candidatus Carsonella ruddii, to 12,200,000 base pairs in the soil-dwelling bacteria Sorangium cellulosum	What shape is chromosome of bacteria?
Bacteria, as asexual organisms, inherit identical copies of their parent's genes (i	What makes bacteria an asexual organism?
Transduction of bacterial genes by bacteriophage appears to be a consequence of infrequent errors during intracellular assembly of virus particles, rather than a bacterial adaptation	What is the aftermath of infrequent errors during intracellular assembly of virus particles?
Transformation, unlike transduction or conjugation, depends on numerous bacterial gene products that specifically interact to perform this complex process, and thus transformation is clearly a bacterial adaptation for DNA transfer	What does transformation of bacteria depends on?
In ordinary circumstances, transduction, conjugation, and transformation involve transfer of DNA between individual bacteria of the same species, but occasionally transfer may occur between individuals of different bacterial species and this may have significant consequences, such as the transfer of antibiotic resistance	Between what species do usually transduction, conjugation and transformation take place?
Bacteriophages are viruses that infect bacteria	What are Bacteriophages?
Bacterial species differ in the number and arrangement of flagella on their surface; some have a single flagellum , a flagellum at each end , clusters of flagella at the poles of the cell , while others have flagella distributed over the entire surface of the cell 	What is monotrichous?
Classification seeks to describe the diversity of bacterial species by naming and grouping organisms based on similarities	How can we classify the vast variety of bacterial species?
"The term ""bacteria"" was traditionally applied to all microscopic, single-cell prokaryotes"	"What would original term ""bacteria"" determine?"
The Gram stain, developed in 1884 by Hans Christian Gram, characterises bacteria based on the structural characteristics of their cell walls	What was developed by Hans Christian Gram?
As with bacterial classification, identification of bacteria is increasingly using molecular methods	What technique has becoming more popular in classification of bacteria?
Some species of bacteria kill and then consume other microorganisms, these species are called predatory bacteria	Why are certain bacteria called predatory?
Certain bacteria form close spatial associations that are essential for their survival	What helps bacteria to survive?
In soil, microorganisms that reside in the rhizosphere carry out nitrogen fixation, converting nitrogen gas to nitrogenous compounds	Where do bacteria stay in soil?
If bacteria form a parasitic association with other organisms, they are classed as pathogens	What are the pathogenes?
Each species of pathogen has a characteristic spectrum of interactions with its human hosts	How pathogenes interact with it's human host?
Bacterial infections may be treated with antibiotics, which are classified as bacteriocidal if they kill bacteria, or bacteriostatic if they just prevent bacterial growth	What type of antibiotics called bacterocidal?
The ability of bacteria to degrade a variety of organic compounds is remarkable and has been used in waste processing and bioremediation	What quality of bacteria is being widely used re-cyling?
Because of their ability to quickly grow and the relative ease with which they can be manipulated, bacteria are the workhorses for the fields of molecular biology, genetics and biochemistry	What sciences use bacteria?
Bacteria were first observed by the Dutch microscopist Antonie van Leeuwenhoek in 1676, using a single-lens microscope of his own design	When was the first time bacteria were observed?
In 1910, Paul Ehrlich developed the first antibiotic, by changing dyes that selectively stained Treponema pallidum — the spirochaete that causes syphilis — into compounds that selectively killed the pathogen	When was the first antibiotic discovered?
When the board has no embedded components it is more correctly called a printed wiring board or etched wiring board	What's the more appropriate, but mostly unused, name for a printed circuit board when it doesn't have embedded components?
Initially PCBs were designed manually by creating a photomask on a clear mylar sheet, usually at two or four times the true size	What did PCB designers used to employ on a mylar sheet?
Panelization is a procedure whereby a number of PCBs are grouped for manufacturing onto a larger board - the panel	What process groups PCBs before transfer to a panel?
The panel is eventually broken apart into individual PCBs; this is called depaneling	What is the process called whereby the individual PCBs are separated?
In additive methods the pattern is electroplated onto a bare substrate using a complex process	Do additive or subtractive methods use less raw materials?
(Unlike a subtractive process mask, this mask exposes those parts of the substrate that will eventually become the traces	In the semi-additive process, what do the areas exposed by the mask become at the end?
The simplest method, used for small-scale production and often by hobbyists, is immersion etching, in which the board is submerged in etching solution such as ferric chloride	What non-professionals might use immersion etching, since it's the easiest way to make a PCB?
For example, a four-layer PCB can be fabricated by starting from a two-sided copper-clad laminate, etch the circuitry on both sides, then laminate to the top and bottom pre-preg and copper foil	If you started with a two-sided laminate etched on either side, laminated to the top and bottom, and processed it again to get traces on the outside layers, how many layers would your final PCB have?
Holes through a PCB are typically drilled with small-diameter drill bits made of solid coated tungsten carbide	What kind of drill bit do you need to drill holes in a PCB?
The hole walls for boards with two or more layers can be made conductive and then electroplated with copper to form plated-through holes	What do the hole walls in two-layer PCBs have to be before they can be electroplated?
The places to which components will be mounted are typically plated, because untreated bare copper oxidizes quickly, and therefore is not readily solderable	What happens to untreated copper that makes it difficult to solder?
Other platings used are OSP , immersion silver , immersion tin, electroless nickel with immersion gold coating , electroless nickel electroless palladium immersion gold and direct gold plating 	What does OSP stand for?
Electrochemical migration is the growth of conductive metal filaments on or in a printed circuit board under the influence of a DC voltage bias	What's the process whereby metal filaments are grown on or in a PCB via DC voltage?
Areas that should not be soldered may be covered with solder resist 	If part of a PCB isn't solderable, what can be used instead?
"Unpopulated boards are usually bare-board tested for ""shorts"" and ""opens"""	"What are bare-board tests looking for besides ""opens""?"
Often, through-hole and surface-mount construction must be combined in a single assembly because some required components are available only in surface-mount packages, while others are available only in through-hole packages	Surface-mount is one type of construction used in PCB assembly; what's the other one?
In boundary scan testing, test circuits integrated into various ICs on the board form temporary connections between the PCB traces to test that the ICs are mounted correctly	Do test circuits create permanent or temporary connections between traces?
PCBs intended for extreme environments often have a conformal coating, which is applied by dipping or spraying after the components have been soldered	If a PCB is intended for use in an setting with extreme conditions, what would probably be applied?
Many assembled PCBs are static sensitive, and therefore must be placed in antistatic bags during transport	What special protection are most PCBs shipped in?
Leads may be soldered either manually or by a wave soldering machine	If a lead wasn't soldered manually, what device was used?
Through-hole manufacture adds to board cost by requiring many holes to be drilled accurately, and limits the available routing area for signal traces on layers immediately below the top layer on multi-layer boards since the holes must pass through all layers to the opposite side	Which type of construction is more expensive?
Surface-mount technology emerged in the 1960s, gained momentum in the early 1980s and became widely used by the mid-1990s	When did surface-mount become a commonly used manufacturing process?
Each trace consists of a flat, narrow part of the copper foil that remains after etching	What process is a trace left over from?
The cloth or fiber material used, resin material, and the cloth to resin ratio determine the laminate's type designation (FR-4, CEM-1, G-10, etc	What element of a laminate is designated by the cloth to resin ratio, among other things?
Some of these dielectrics are polytetrafluoroethylene , FR-4, FR-1, CEM-1 or CEM-3	What's the common name of polytetrafluoroethylene?
The reinforcement type defines two major classes of materials - woven and non-woven	Along with the non-woven class, what makes up the reinforcement type materials?
At the glass transition temperature the resin in the composite softens and significantly increases thermal expansion; exceeding Tg then exerts mechanical overload on the board components - e	What's the temperature at which resin softens and expands called?
Moisture absorption occurs when the material is exposed to high humidity or water	What will happen to the materials when a board gets wet or is in a humid area?
The printed circuit board industry defines heavy copper as layers exceeding three ounces of copper, or approximately 0	"What's the minimum amount of copper a layer in a PCB can have to be considered ""heavy copper""?"
Since it was quite easy to stack interconnections inside the embedding matrix, the approach allowed designers to forget completely about the routing of wires : Anywhere the designer needs a connection, the machine will draw a wire in straight line from one location/pin to another	What arduous aspect of the process can designers skip in Multiwire?
Cordwood construction can save significant space and was often used with wire-ended components in applications where space was at a premium and in high-speed computers, where short traces were important	What type of construction is best for applications that need to portion space carefully?
In 1903, a German inventor, Albert Hanson, described flat foil conductors laminated to an insulating board, in multiple layers	Who was the German inventor who wrote in 1903 about conductors being laminated in layers to a board?

Other influential Muslim philosophers include al-Jahiz, a pioneer in evolutionary thought; Ibn al-Haytham , a pioneer of phenomenology and the philosophy of science and a critic of Aristotelian natural philosophy and Aristotle's concept of place ; Al-Biruni, a critic of Aristotelian natural philosophy; Ibn Tufail and Ibn al-Nafis, pioneers of the philosophical novel; Shahab al-Din Suhrawardi, founder of Illuminationist philosophy; Fakhr al-Din al-Razi, a critic of Aristotelian logic and a pioneer of inductive logic; and Ibn Khaldun, a pioneer in the philosophy of history	Which philosopher of the Muslim world is considered an important author of work on evolution?

Muslim physicians contributed to the field of medicine, including the subjects of anatomy and physiology: such as in the 15th century Persian work by Mansur ibn Muhammad ibn al-Faqih Ilyas entitled Tashrih al-badan which contained comprehensive diagrams of the body's structural, nervous and circulatory systems; or in the work of the Egyptian physician Ibn al-Nafis, who proposed the theory of pulmonary circulation	What work is Mansur ibn Muhammad ibn al-Faqih Ilyas known for writing?

In 550 BC, Cyrus the Great, son of Mandane and Cambyses I, took over the Median Empire, and founded the Achaemenid Empire by unifying other city states	Who founded the Achaemenid Empire when the city states in Iran came together in unification?
At its greatest extent, the Achaemenid Empire included the modern territories of Iran, Azerbaijan, Armenia, Georgia, Turkey, much of the Black Sea coastal regions, northeastern Greece and southern Bulgaria , northern Greece and Macedonia , Iraq, Syria, Lebanon, Jordan, Israel, Palestine, all significant ancient population centers of ancient Egypt as far west as Libya, Kuwait, northern Saudi Arabia, parts of the UAE and Oman, Pakistan, Afghanistan, and much of Central Asia, making it the first world government and the largest empire the world had yet seen	What was the first world goverment the world had seen at the time it existed?
In Greek history, the Achaemenid Empire is considered as the antagonist of the Greek city states, for the emancipation of slaves including the Jewish exiles in Babylon, building infrastructures such as road and postal systems, and the use of an official language, the Imperial Aramaic, throughout its territories	The Achaemenid Empire was the known enemy of what nation's histories during its existence?

The style of Georgian buildings is very variable, but marked by a taste for symmetry and proportion based on the classical architecture of Greece and Rome, as revived in Renaissance architecture	What classical architecture is Georgian architecture based on?
In towns, which expanded greatly during the period, landowners turned into property developers, and rows of identical terraced houses became the norm	During the period of Georgian architecture what did landowners turn into?
"The period saw the growth of a distinct and trained architectural profession; before the mid-century ""the high-sounding title, 'architect' was adopted by anyone who could get away with it"""	What high sounding title was adopted by anyone who could get away with it?
Georgian succeeded the English Baroque of Sir Christopher Wren, Sir John Vanbrugh, Thomas Archer, William Talman, and Nicholas Hawksmoor; this in fact continued into at least the 1720s, overlapping with a more restrained Georgian style	What style did Georgian succeed?
In the mainstream of Georgian style were both Palladian architecture— and its whimsical alternatives, Gothic and Chinoiserie, which were the English-speaking world's equivalent of European Rococo	What are the whimsical alternatives of Palladian architecture?
Georgian architecture is characterized by its proportion and balance; simple mathematical ratios were used to determine the height of a window in relation to its width or the shape of a room as a double cube	Georgian architecture is characterized by?
Versions of revived Palladian architecture dominated English country house architecture	What revived style dominated English country house architecture?
Windows in all types of buildings were large and regularly placed on a grid; this was partly to minimize window tax, which was in force throughout the period in the United Kingdom	What tax was in force throughout the United Kingdom during this time?
Internal courtyards became more rare, except beside the stables, and the functional parts of the building were placed at the sides, or in separate buildings nearby hidden by trees	What was often used to hide functional parts of buildings?
Inside ornament was far more generous, and could sometimes be overwhelming	Where could sometimes overwhelming ornament be found?
In towns even most better-off people lived in terraced houses, which typically opened straight onto the street, often with a few steps up to the door	Most town people lived in what type of houses?
Town terraced houses for all social classes remained resolutely tall and narrow, each dwelling occupying the whole height of the building	What shape and size did most town terraced houses take on?

Beginning in the late 1910s and early 1920s, Whitehead gradually turned his attention from mathematics to philosophy of science, and finally to metaphysics	What did Whitehead first study?
Alfred North Whitehead was born in Ramsgate, Kent, England, in 1861	Where was Alfred North Whitehead born? 
In 1918 Whitehead's academic responsibilities began to seriously expand as he accepted a number of high administrative positions within the University of London system, of which Imperial College London was a member at the time	When did Whitehead accept administrative positions?
The two volume biography of Whitehead by Victor Lowe is the most definitive presentation of the life of Whitehead	How many volumes is the biography of Whitehead?
In addition to numerous articles on mathematics, Whitehead wrote three major books on the subject: A Treatise on Universal Algebra , Principia Mathematica , and An Introduction to Mathematics 	What did Whitehead publish numerous articles about?
At the time structures such as Lie algebras and hyperbolic quaternions drew attention to the need to expand algebraic structures beyond the associatively multiplicative class	Lie algebras and hypobolic quanternions drew attention to the need for what?
Whitehead and Russell had thought originally that Principia Mathematica would take a year to complete; it ended up taking them ten years	How long did Whitehead and Russell think it would take them to complete Principia Mathematica?
It is generally accepted that Kurt Gödel's incompleteness theorem of 1931 definitively demonstrated that for any set of axioms and inference rules proposed to encapsulate mathematics, there would in fact be some truths of mathematics which could not be deduced from them, and hence that Principia Mathematica could never achieve its aims	When was Kurt Godel's incompleteness theorem?
Whitehead's most complete work on education is the 1929 book The Aims of Education and Other Essays, which collected numerous essays and addresses by Whitehead on the subject published between 1912 and 1927	What year was The Aims of Education and Other Essays published?
Rather than teach small parts of a large number of subjects, Whitehead advocated teaching a relatively few important concepts that the student could organically link to many different areas of knowledge, discovering their application in actual life	Whitehead's education style was to teach what?
In fact, he never had any formal training in philosophy beyond his undergraduate education	What is the highest Whitehead was trained in philosophy? 
""" In Whitehead's view, scientists and philosophers make metaphysical assumptions about how the universe works all the time, but such assumptions are not easily seen precisely because they remain unexamined and unquestioned"	What do philosophers do, in Whitehead's view?
"Perhaps foremost among what Whitehead considered faulty metaphysical assumptions was the Cartesian idea that reality is fundamentally constructed of bits of matter that exist totally independently of one another, which he rejected in favor of an event-based or ""process"" ontology in which events are primary and are fundamentally interrelated and dependent on one another"	What idea states that reality is fundamentally constructed of bits of matter?
His philosophical work is generally considered to be among the most difficult to understand in all of the western canon	In all of the western canon, what is Whitehead's work considered?

"Though Process and Reality has been called ""arguably the most impressive single metaphysical text of the twentieth century,"" it has been little-read and little-understood, partly because it demands – as Isabelle Stengers puts it – ""that its readers accept the adventure of the questions that will separate them from every consensus"	Which publication is considered the most impressive metaphysical text?
"These ""classical"" concepts fail to adequately account for change, and overlook the active and experiential nature of the most basic elements of the world"	Concepts such as quality, matter, and form fail to account for what?
"To put it another way, a thing or person is often seen as having a ""defining essence"" or a ""core identity"" that is unchanging, and describes what the thing or person really is"	The idea that people are unchanging and stay the same even through changes is considered what?
Whitehead pointed to the limitations of language as one of the main culprits in maintaining a materialistic way of thinking, and acknowledged that it may be difficult to ever wholly move past such ideas in everyday speech	What did Whitehead believe was a culprit in maintaining a materialistic way of thinking?
A second problem with materialism is that it obscures the importance of relations	What obscures the importance of relations according to Whitehead?
In fact, Whitehead describes any entity as in some sense nothing more and nothing less than the sum of its relations to other entities – its synthesis of and reaction to the world around it	Whitehead believes any entity is in some sense what?
Of course, most entities do not have consciousness	Most entities do not have what?
"The term he coined was ""prehension"", which comes from the Latin prehensio, meaning ""to seize"	What term did Whitehead describe that perception is not limited to the living?
"Whitehead describes causal efficacy as ""the experience dominating the primitive living organisms, which have a sense for the fate from which they have emerged, and the fate towards which they go"	What is the term for the experience dominating primitive organisms that have a sense for fate?
"In higher organisms , these two modes of perception combine into what Whitehead terms ""symbolic reference"", which links appearance with causation in a process that is so automatic that both people and animals have difficulty refraining from it"	What is Whitehead's term for the two modes of perceptions combining?
"Whitehead makes the startling observation that ""life is comparatively deficient in survival value"	Whitehead observes that life is deficient in what?
""" Here Whitehead is criticizing Christianity for defining God as primarily a divine king who imposes his will on the world, and whose most important attribute is power"	What qualities dis Whitehead state that Christians attributed to their version of God?
It should be emphasized, however, that for Whitehead God is not necessarily tied to religion	What was Whitehead's belief about God in relation to religion?
God's consequent nature, on the other hand, is anything but unchanging – it is God's reception of the world's activity	How does Whitehead define he consequent nature of God?
Whitehead thus sees God and the world as fulfilling one another	How does Whitehead view the relationship between God an the world?
For Whitehead the core of religion was individual	What did Whitehead believe was the basis of religion?
However, while Whitehead saw religion as beginning in solitariness, he also saw religion as necessarily expanding beyond the individual	In what state did Whitehead believe religion began?
""" In other words, religion takes deeply felt emotions and contextualizes them within a system of general truths about the world, helping people to identify their wider meaning and significance"	What did Whitehead believe religion did with strong emotions?

Early followers of Whitehead were found primarily at the University of Chicago's Divinity School, where Henry Nelson Wieman initiated an interest in Whitehead's work that would last for about thirty years	Where were the first followers mainly found?
But while Claremont remains the most concentrated hub of Whiteheadian activity, the place where Whitehead's thought currently seems to be growing the most quickly is in China	Where is interest in Whitehead's work growing the fastest today?
In English-speaking countries, his primary works are little-studied outside of Claremont and a select number of liberal graduate-level theology and philosophy programs	Where are Whitehead's works primarily studied in English-speaking countries?
Deleuze's and Latour's opinions, however, are minority ones, as Whitehead has not been recognized as particularly influential within the most dominant philosophical schools	What is the general opinion of Whitehead in most philosophical schools?

Antibiotics revolutionized medicine in the 20th century, and have together with vaccination led to the near eradication of diseases such as tuberculosis in the developed world	What is one disease that has been nearly eradicated thanks to vaccines and antibiotics?
In empirical therapy, a patient has proven or suspected infection, but the responsible microorganism is not yet unidentified	What is one kind of therapy that may be used when a patience has an infection, but it has not been identified?
Adverse effects range from fever and nausea to major allergic reactions, including photodermatitis and anaphylaxis	What are two examples of minor side effects caused by some antibiotics?
Exposure to antibiotics early in life is associated with increased body mass in humans and mouse models	What is one common result of using antibiotics from a young age?
The majority of studies indicate antibiotics do interfere with contraceptive pills, such as clinical studies that suggest the failure rate of contraceptive pills caused by antibiotics is very low 	Do antibiotics interact with birth control pills?
Interactions between alcohol and certain antibiotics may occur and may cause side-effects and decreased effectiveness of antibiotic therapy	What is one potential issue with drinking alcohol while taking antibiotics?
A bactericidal activity of antibacterials may depend on the bacterial growth phase, and it often requires ongoing metabolic activity and division of bacterial cells	What does the bactericidal activitty of antibacterials depend on what?

"Antibacterial-resistant strains and species, sometimes referred to as ""superbugs"", now contribute to the emergence of diseases that were for a while well controlled"	What are strains that are resistant to antibiotics called sometimes?
Inappropriate antibiotic treatment and overuse of antibiotics have contributed to the emergence of antibiotic-resistant bacteria	What are the two biggest reasons for resistance?
Common forms of antibiotic misuse include excessive use of prophylactic antibiotics in travelers and failure of medical professionals to prescribe the correct dosage of antibiotics on the basis of the patient's weight and history of prior use	What is a way of improperly using antibiotics for those traveling?
The issues of misuse and overuse of antibiotics have been addressed by the formation of the US Interagency Task Force on Antimicrobial Resistance	What is the name of a US government agency tasked with trying to stop improper use of antibiotics?
The emergence of antibiotic resistance has prompted restrictions on their use in the UK in 1970 , and the EU has banned the use of antibiotics as growth-promotional agents since 2003	When did the EU ban antibiotics for speeding up growth?
There has been extensive use of antibiotics in animal husbandry	What besides sick people are antibiotics used for?
